I bought this game with the intention of playing in VR.  I decided to learn it first without VR.  After the tutorial and a couple of houses....I don't know that I can do VR.  This game is scary.  I had constant chills and goosebumps.  My throat hurts from screaming.  I'm probably never sleeping again.  Every single time I started to get used to the pace, and relax and think "It's not so scary.  This isn't so bad."  Something would happen to up the ante and make me scream in terror. This game is horrifyingly scary, and fun.  The tutorial is a bit lacking, so it helps to have a friend who's got some experience to teach you the ropes and has gear.  

Overall, I'm very excited to see future updates and improvements to the game.  It is extremely fun so far, with less than two hours in, this is my initial impression of the game. 15/10 would recommend.  Best played with friends.

Please don't take my negative review as meaning that this is a bad game because it is great fun even with the issues I noticed.

It is a great concept with some great game mechanics.
I like the voice recognition, the way ghosts hunt after you, the map layouts are all pretty good, and it's loads of fun to play with friends

I do feel like the cons, however, are pretty glaring.
Movement speed is WAY too slow. You can sneak in most other games faster than you can "sprint" in this game. I feel like it needs to be at least doubled.
The push-to-talk only sometimes works and the Spirit Box glitches out too frequently.
The pathing of the ghosts seems a bit odd. I ended up getting a wraith trapped in a closet.
I feel like there should be some way to interact with the map while you are dead, like moving objects or making sounds.

I know this is still in early access, so I'm hoping the developer looks at reviews and gameplay to see what can be fixed and improved.

This game is exactly what I wanted it to be. It has the feel of going ghost hunting with your friends in an abandoned building. The ghost will autonomously do things like open and close doors, throw items, turn on sinks and radios, etc. Make sure you do a bit of research on how to communicate using Ouija boards and spirit boxes as there are specific voice command questions that can help you collect evidence. Maybe play a game blind to get the raw experience and then watch people play it on Twitch for a few tips? Anyways, it was definitely worth the money and lots of fun with a full group of four - even with just three. With as fun as it is this early, I can only imagine a little bit of fine-tuning and new content will make it even more fun in the future.

(but a lot deadlier). It can be rather difficult to determine the ghosts location sometimes and the game needs a lot of work when it comes to UI and the surveillance systems, but the game is still in very early development and I would expect many of these core aspects to improve over time. 

The game is enjoyable, that's enough for me.

As you can tell by my hours, I haven't played this game very long, but I can already tell a lot about it. First off, I haven't played with friends yet, and I also am too poor to get a VR headset, so I play in desktop mode alone mostly. Now that that's out of the way, let's talk about the game:

This is probably the scariest horror game I have ever played, while still managing to be fun. A lot of games try to be both, but fail. If you play FnaF, you're in it for the scares, but it isn't much fun. If you play a multiplayer horror game like Dead by Daylight, it's really fun, but it isn't scary. This game found a great balance, between making it terrifying and fun!

While the game is good alone, it's much better with friends. Working together to find out the ghost and determine their class with friends is quite fun. I highly recommend playing with people who have similar hours to you, however, so you will be as competent as each other.


The goal of the game is to find 3 pieces of evidence to determine what type of ghost is haunting the home. You have a few pieces of equipment to use, and can get more from the in game shop with the money you earn from successful investigations. You can also get money by taking pictures of the ghosts and doing optional objectives. There are currently 12 ghosts in the game, each with their own set of 3 pieces of evidence. Seems easy, right? Well, here's where the horror comes in.

The longer you stay in the game, the more sanity you lose. Lose too much, and the ghost will go into attack phase. Each ghost has their own strength and weakness, however all of them are able to kill you. The only way to survive is to run and hide until the ghost calms down. While the jumpscare itself isn't awful, the psychological horror is off the charts, especially when you're hiding in a bathroom praying the ghost leaves you alone.

One more thing as well: The game uses your microphone. A lot. This includes communicating with your team, but also with the ghost. Some ghosts can talk back with the spirit box, but some cannot. The lynchpin in this, however, is that the ghost can hear you. If you're hiding in a closet and telling your friends how scared you are, the ghost will find you and you will die. You have to remain quiet and remain calm the whole time, or else it's game over.

Overall, this game is great. I'm excited to follow it's development, and if I can get myself to play it more, I'm excited to see what the game has to offer, but it is very difficult to be brave enough to boot this thing up. If you've got nerves of steel, and preferably 1-3 friends, and even more preferably a VR headset, buy this game, and get ready for a chilling adventure.

After about 12 hours of this game, I've got to say, I'm impressed. I've tried the VR and the regular keyboard and mouse versions, and there both pretty solid. The VR version could be worked upon of, and I have some ideas that I think could be pretty cool in the final version of the game, but I'll get into that later. Phasmophobia drops you into a haunted house for you, the player, to figure out what kind of ghost you're dealing with. You have multiple tools to work with, only some locked by some questionable level system. You'll be using EMFs, motion sensors, photo cameras, etc...... One major feature of this game is the proximity chat, and the voice recognition. I'm not joking when I say this, but the voice chat in this game is amazing. It's incredible how they managed to make the sound quality of other players equal to, if not better than discords sound quality. But the really sad part of it is that the voice recognition doesn't really work as well. It does work sometimes, but sometimes when you're trying to talk to the ghost using a Oujia board, it doesn't really pick up. On the horror part of this game, it can be terrifying. When you're EMF starts going off to a level 5, or you're heart starts beating really fast, you know you're in trouble, and you start to panic and thoughts start rushing to you, "should i risk my life to get a picture for evidence? Or should I run away and see if I can survive just a little longer?" Let's just say it gets VERY stressful. Another really fun thing is too, there are multiple different types of ghosts, like Demons, Oni's, Spirits, Revenants, etc...... All in All, I've had a lot of fun playing this game with my friends and I recommend this to it's fullest, and is probably my favorite horror game of 2020, so this is going to be a solid

I'm always a little leery of early access games, but Phasmophobia has exceeded my expectations. It is the most fun I've had playing a game in a while. Pasmophobia is a paranormal horror coop, and it does everything it should do. The atmosphere is immediate upon entering each premise on every map.

Proximity chat, as well as radio communication creates a lot of the immersion, although buggy at times where even passing the test before going into a map, people around you may not be able to hear you. So make sure you mute/deafen discord while you play for the best experience.

There is a wide variety of ghosts to encounter, and this game promotes exploration. Replaying maps doesn't feel like a chore because there's always something different happening in the map, as well as in different areas of it.

The tools needed for each encounter are essential to your success, and are intertwined to the objectives, so you never have problems bringing the right tool(s) for the job. Just make sure the cash cow that just so happens to splurge on equipment for the team doesn't die...

Economy is about what I expected it to be, you get more money from guessing the correct ghost/demon. And you get a little treat for doing all of the objectives. They give you more of an incentive to go back into an activity 10 building, god help you need to do something that gets you right infront of the spirit.

Overall a good game, my only issues are the actual character models of the spirits. Yurei, or Oni having the same cliche looking zombie models somewhat cut off the immersion. When placing down journals for some of them to write on, satanic/luciferian/nordic sigils are not what I would expect from some of these ghosts.

15 bucks isn't asking for much, infact, what you're getting is a bargain. So why not give it a try.

Things i wish i knew when i started the game: 
- Ghost orbs usually appear outside of the room where the ghost is, this has made me lose a lot of games until i figured it out
- EMF doesn't give level 5 reading unless its directly in front of whatever the ghost touched.
- Ouija boards swallow your sanity, only use them whenever you're desperate for evidence, and even then they're RNG (they can spawn in closets and lockers, check everything you can open)
- Too many sound sensors in the same spot can overload the sensor mapping and not give you exact readings, but more of a general direction, maybe its a bug idk i hope they fix it though
- Wraiths can have footstep sounds (probably a bug right now)
- An attack and hunting isn't the same thing, if the ghost appears in front of you without the lights flickering, it's only attacking you, you can easily run away from it, or in most cases he'll disappear without touching you. Hunting is completely different
- The ghost AI's are dumb in hunting mode, you can easily hide behind something and play peeakaboo with the ghost and it wont attack you unless you make noise

Played this game for 23 hours now, constantly since i purchased it, Even gifted it to 5 of my friends to play with, they all love it even though they get scared shitless most of the time. 
To dispel any rumors of this, If you die you lose the stuff you brought with you on the hunt, BUT you get an insurance payout giving you back what i would assume to be roughly 60% of the total cost of stuff lost, Yes it is a punishment for dying, But it is not world ending and it doesn't make the game  unforgiving, it just means there's a learning curve for what to do when a ghost is hunting you.
Theres 12 ghosts, and about 8  different areas varying in sizes. and the ghost seems to be able to haunt any room in any of the buildings. There's a lot of issues with the spirit box, placement of the ghost writing book, and temperature readings, Dont get discouraged though, it's a 14$ early access game and they have been frequent bug fixes since i started playing. This game has a lot of potential and i would have paid 40$ for it.

[VR-less Review]
One of the more promising Early Access titles. Gather a team of 4 and witness the most horrifying thing this game has to offer; broken backs. Starting off, you're given no more than the basics of ghost hunting. Spirit boxes to communicate, UV lights to find finger prints or hand prints around the environment, flashlights to see your surroundings, EMF readers to detect ghost readings, video cameras to keep track of your pals and catch spirit orbs, a journal for the ghost to write in, and a regular picture camera to keep track of evidence, i.e the ghost, ouija boards, dead bodies and prints for extra cash. That cash can turn into a staggering amount of equipment, too. Parabolic microphones, candles, smudge sticks, crucifixes, motion sensors, sound sensors, head mounted cameras, thermometers, glowsticks, salt, you name it. 

The game plays slowly. At the start on easier difficulties, the ghost is typically tame, and the house is dark. You'll travel room to room finding clues. Is the room cold? Can you see your breath? Is there noises? Running sinks, creaking, voices, doors opening and closing? They're all clues to which room is haunted, and after that you're running into checkboxes. Is there ghost writing, are they communicating through the spirit box, fingerprints, you get the idea. Looking through and writing in your journal will help you decide what ghost it is. Revenant, Mare, Spirit, Oni, Shade, Wraith, Demon, all with different characteristics and weaknesses. 

The games atmosphere is surprisingly top notch [if you're not staring at your friends] and the maps feel fair, mostly. If you're not splitting up, it can be tough to find the room fast enough before the ghost enrages and start to hunt. If you get caught, you'll die and lose all equipment you brought with you. My complaints on the game are little and I'm hoping they'll be fixed in later updates, as in some equipment don't seem to work properly, lots of voice recognition issues [friends and I don't speak until we're all fully loaded so proximity and radio chat works], some ghosts seem to be tied to certain difficulties [citation needed], personally feel like the game shouldn't have a sprint button and the sprint should be the new walk.

It's a breath of fresh air that I'm sure not a lot of people have seen. It's terrifying, enjoyable, and might be the best <15$ you can spend on Steam, especially with friends. Lots of content to already be had and with more on the way, the future is bright and I can't wait to experience it in a great, cooperative horror game.

If you want to be spooked and scared with friends trying to figure out types of ghosts, then definitely play this game. I've always wanted to play a game like this, and I'm glad it's finally here.

Although this game is in early access, it's surprisingly very good and stable. It's rare that I find early access games enjoyable or fun so congrats to this one for actually being decent.

[h1][b]-Good-[/b][/h1]
-A fun and scary experience overall - especially with friends
-In-game voice chat and radio communication (would be nice for a voice chat volume boost to hear other people better)
-Great graphics and lighting, although some lighting and shadows do need improving
-Communication with the ghost and being able to say key words is a brilliant touch
-Sanity is a great feature
-Large amount of equipment to buy and use at your disposal
-Levelling up system which allows you to get more advanced and better equipment
-No microtransactions
-Maps are well designed
-No performance issues

[h1][b]-Bad/suggestions-[/b][/h1]
-Animations are very basic at the moment, but I'm sure they will improve later
-Walking and 'sprinting' speed is quite slow. You do get used to it, but I would like it to be a normal speed because sprinting feels slow motion, especially when looking at other players.
-Small amount of maps - looking forward to more.
-Same ambient atmosphere sound in every location. Hoping for different ones on each map.
-No object name when looking at items - when you purchase new items it's difficult trying to figure out which items is which in the van, especially when you have a lot of equipment loaded.
-Lack of spooky ghost sounds and scare tactics - so there are occasions where a ghost will make scary sounds etc. I think there's a lot of opportunity for spooktacular sounds such as knocking on the walls, writing on the wall, dragging dead bodies around etc. I know this game is in early access and its early days, but I think adding that in future will make it more fun and interesting.
-No workshop at this time, again I know it's early access but being able to have mods in this game would be amazing.
-Can't join friends through Steam, you have to use a code that they give when creating a lobby
-Objectives lack variety, looking forward to more of them in future.
-More ghosts and player models needed

I admit it has bugs but they aren't totally game breaking. Most of the issues I have experienced are microphone/comms-related and, usually, doing a few restart(s) fixes it. 

Atmosphere is pretty good as it doesn't heavily rely on jumpscares or loud noises to frighten you (but it does have a few). The game mechanics are fairly easy to understand. The tutorial is helpful but I'd say experience is the best teacher. For an early access game, it's pretty well-made.

Can't wait to see what other kinds of entities and/or game mechanics they're going to add. I do recommend people to purchase it and give it a try. 

I also have to mention the community. I can't say I've had a bad experience with them. People tend to be really friendly, funny, and pretty helpful too! You have a question? You won't get judged for asking. You don't need to play with friends to have fun. You can meet up with some players at public servers or opt to look for them at the official Discord.

I must say, I have high expectations. It's got potential. Something similar to Subnautica and, hopefully, the same regular updates and success.

I dont use the VR aspect of the game (although I really wish I could). From the standard desktop experience, this game still scares the shit outta me. Headphones are a must if you're going to play (IMO), preferably with a mic for the voice interactions. Menus are a bit wonky to navigate with a controller which I'm hoping gets better over time (there is probably no issue in VR as menu navigation seems built for it; I usually use a mouse). 

Pros:
Super atmospheric
Good controller support considering game was seemingly built with VR intentions
Great fun with friends
Scary as all hell even with friends or without

Cons:
Run isnt run ... its walk with a gait
Timer is a weird mechanic IMO. 
Some places are really, really large and sometimes trying to find evidence is almost impossible before being killed
Keyboard&Mouse/Controller requires pinpoint accuracy for interacting with objects sometimes, especially with things that are thin

All in all, fantastic game that should only get better over time. If you like horror games, DEFINITELY pick this up!

Only played for 3 hours so far and I've already gone through 3 pairs of pants. First ghost I got right (After like, 5 other attempts) was a Yurei, safe to say I'm gonna need a trip to get myself some new pants.

I live out my dreams of being an actual ghost hunter, but I can die! 10/10 worth it with friends.

All and all, the game is a very fun co-op game with friends.(haven't tried randoms.) You play as a group of ghost hunters. you have an EMF reader, temp taker, video and picture camera, and a lot more gear to use to help you track down the spirit you are hunting.

As far as how scary it can be? it can get pretty scary, but the good kind of scary. No "jump scares" but plenty of ways to get the heart racing. 

The game has a decent amount of maps to pick from, different ghosts that all act differently (and visuals too!)

Its still in early access, which gives me hope for a lot more content to be added. Im already having fun and excited for the next night of hunting, what more can be thrown at us?
Scary but fun. Just tell the ghost to "Scream" to have a good time.

Has a few flaws but overall I couldn't be happier and more scared out of my mind! The atmosphere of this game is absolutely wild. Never have I been so tense but so eager to play a game! The multiplayer Is great with its in game chat however I do wish there was a sorting system for difficulty and mic/no mic. I often get into games with professionals while at level 5 or get a full team without mics that end up finding clues without communicating. I do love the amount of team interaction when a game goes right however! The gameplay is amazing and aside from a few missed jumpscare opportunities and background horror possibilities such as a demon standing in a window at higher level difficulties such as to say "I'm ready to kill you already" I couldn't ask for much more feature wise to the actual gameplay.

She was taking a long time to come out and I started talking mad shit. The room was cold and the EMF was going level 5, and that was cool. Friend and I took turns trying to figure out the third piece of evidence so we could determine what kinda ghost she was. At one point, she snuck up in my ear and went "I'm here." I yelled. After a few more minutes of chilling in the bathroom yelling in the dark by myself, with homie in the van, hear a door slam. I decide to go back outside but, it was the front door that slammed. The front door is locked. I'm trapped inside. I turn around, and blink on the flashlight, and see a woman on all fours sprinting at me and she claws my eyes out. I scream a lot. I pull my headset off while yelling.

[b] Good [/b]

+has an VR version

-buggy at times, but too be expected from a one man developer crew

For a game that is in its extremely Early Access form, Phasmophobia does not disappoint. The game has a surprisingly vast amount of content. With its many different types of ghosts and levels, each game is diverse with new surprises every corner. I can see this game being a huge success, and most likely one of the best horror games this year. I am intrigued to see what new content that the developers will add to this fantastic game. I am very pleased with my purchase.

Pros: 
- Lots of equipment for ghost hunting, so everyone has some sort of task to do
- Different variants of ghosts, so each play style is different
- Has a lot of levels and difficulties so it never feels the same
- Having the ghosts respond to your microphone in the game is an extremely unique and horrifying concept

Cons:
- When players die, there is not much they can do besides sitting and waiting
- Some maps feel very large, so it may be hard to find some of the ghosts there
- Voice chat is a little bugged at times

At first you start out in small sites like tiny suburban homes. These small maps aren't that bad, except for the paralyzing fear every time my flashlight flickers and the ghost starts hunting me.

Then, you get to the medium maps where your puny flashlight isn't enough to reach from one end of the room to the other. There's nothing more terrifying than sitting in the dark classroom trying to get a response from the spirit box alone because the spirit only responds to people on their own.

I don't know if large maps are a thing, but I can't wait to be too scared to even set foot in the building.

This is game is great, it is the most thrilling game i've have ever played.

The game is in early access, so there are still a few kinks that pop up with hotfixes or patches that have to be smoothed - but all in all, for a 2 person project it's already quite a fleshed out experience. Recently I've gotten into the game with my family and now some close friends, and outside a couple of server issues when connecting we've all been having a great time. 

It's staggering how large the community for the game is considering its status as an early access (Primarily VR) title. 

It's got an immersive atmosphere, and it's quite easy to feel genuine fear when playing, though that hasn't diminished the experience, it only enhances it. I don't typically like or play horror games outside the likes of Condemned: Criminal Origins - but this game is fairly infinitely replayable, especially if you have a group of dedicated friends that are willing to play with you.

An all around fun to play game with friends, we got our spooks OFC, the ambient is great, although, needs some more graphical and SFX boost, to maximize the experience. Also, more "ghosts" should be a thing in a single place and all the more, more interaction in the stages. For example, in the Asylum, that is a huge stage, there is only one demon, and you only got your gear. You could add something, like clues, that exist in the stage, to add more mystery. 

Those were my comments, for an early access game, it is certainly worth your time and money and it is great as far as gameplay till now!

For the last 10 years, I have been telling people that this style of game could work with the TV show Supernatural. You would go from city to city, find out what fiend it is and fight them. Move on to the next town. This game has it's little flaws, but is in the shadows of it's major success of immersing you and your team into the Ghost Hunter role. The thrill of a ghost moving things, turning on and off things, and hunting you is enough to make you have goosebumps. Let alone the mic being open for the ghost to hear every sound you make. 

People, it is still in Early Access and has major room to grow. It will grow with the community that supports it. Thumbs up for the Devs on bringing us this fantasy. Thank you!

Constipated?  Got VR?  Need to shit yourself?  This game is definitely for you then.

What can I say about this game?  It's definitely something that'll freak you out immensely.  If you have a heart condition or anything that can put you out if you freak out by scares, then avoid this produce.  However, if you're adventurous enough, I fully recommend it, and it makes for a good bowl unblocker.

The Breakdown (on a 1-5 scale)
Graphics: 4.75  
I like the realism in this game.  The graphics to an amazing job creating the right atmosphere.  The only thing is it's ALWAYS RAINING AND STORMING!  I get that it's supposed to create the ambiance of the game, but every single home so far that I've visited had rain.

Sound: 5
I have to give it to the sound on this one; it's one of the main items that brings the fear level up.  Random noises can startle you and just the sound when you enter the house or place sends chills everywhere.  You suddenly hear doors creaking open or closed or maybe an object is thrown and hits the wall with an audible thud?  Yeah.....that'll get ya going.  Couple that with the fact that it uses your mic to actually call out to the ghost to cause all sorts of things to happen and you have something cooking.  The dynamic audio works very well here.  If you have a group of players, the audio cuts or muffles itself depending on how far away someone is from you and your voice can actually be used to call out a ghost by speaking its name and using the spirit box to have it respond to you.

Controls: 4
I'll give it to the classic PC keyboard/mouse; they're near flawless.
Where I'm taking points off of here is the controls for VR.  Depending on what equipment you're using will change the layout of the buttons.  I use a Rift S and the buttons aren't very clear on what does what because they don't have the proper layout for the controllers I use.  If they change the layout to explain the VR controls based on the equipment used, then I'll give it a full 5.  The controls themselves work very VERY well, but because it's not fully clear what does what, you'll fumble around with them.  Despite the learning curve, the VR controls do work.

Gameplay: 4.5
Oooh, this is goooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooood.  I can't give it a full-on score because of the cumbersome controls in VR, but for the keyboard/mouse, I'd say it's a 5.  The game is easy to pick up and play, but there are a few keyboard commands you'll want to look over.  Using the 2nd function of an item isn't the same as chucking something with "G".  For example, the video camera you use can be placed with F, but if you use G, the camera can land upside down.  It boils down to reading the controls once you get into the game.

Overall: 4.8
This game did scare me and it got me in the best way possible: the shade spawned in front of me as I re-entered the house and I nope'd the fuck outta there after that, not even bothering with the other evidence.  As a single-player experience, it's fun, but do expect to get frustrated if you can't figure out what evidence you collect.  I tried for 30 minutes trying to get something other than an EMF of 5 as my first evidence, but never could get any other evidence.  It's probably because you do have to buy certain equipment, but you start off with a basic camera, emf reader, book for spirits to write in, a UV flashlight, a regular flashlight, and video camera.  You have to earn money by completing objectives and finding out what kind of ghost is haunting a particular place.

All in all, for those looking for something in spooptember, I HIGHLY recommend this game.  It'll put some fear of ghost in ya for sure.

This is a fantastic game for the amount of time it's been out. I've screamed like a child and got terrified whenever my dog would do something behind me. 

I can find very few things wrong with this game, other than a few minor control issues, like the slow 'sprint' speed. 


I understand this is still early access, but I do have some suggestions that can add to replay value and make the game more difficult.

I think they should add a new clue line, such as extremely hot heat or sulfur in the air, the heat seen with thermometer and sulfuric air having some kind of gas detector. Doing this will make room for new ghosts and require more thought before taking gear to a location.

adding maps is always good, but for now, the largest maps are more than enough. 

Adding in additional dangers, like thrown objects being able to hit you and make you stumble or perhaps knock items out of your hands would be great and have more objects able to me moved by the ghost like computers or even beds. it would add to the creep factor a lot, in my opinion. 

a female and a child voice actor would go a long way in making things more diverse as well. 

Diverse killing animation other than a pair of hands grabbing your eyes, such as an axe or something swinging at you out of the darkness, or the ghost leaps at you from above/below.

So this is a game about hunting ghosts. You get paid for completing objectives, and you use that money to buy equipment to aid you in your ghost hunting.

There are several types of ghosts and you have to find clues, such as, cold temperatures, EMF meter readings, spirit box interactions, etc. You collect up to three clues and use those to determine what type of ghost is haunting the house. Some ghosts can be more dormant. Some ghosts can be very aggressive. But they are all capable of killing you if you aren't careful.

You'll know when a ghost is hunting because the lights in the house and your flashlight will start flickering. It's time to hide! Run into another room or into a closet and close the door. Sit still and be quiet!

The game has push to talk in both local (people around you), and with a radio, (you can chat remotely). The game has voice recognition system so that you can actually speak the ghost's name and you can usually get a response. Sometimes more negative and aggressive. 

Keep in mind even if you aren't pressing push to talk, the game still picks up your mic and the ghost can hear you.

As you collect your clues, you can put them into your journal and it will help narrow down what type of ghost you have. Select this when you know for sure, and then leave in the truck.

My first few games were very interesting. First game was with a girl who was leading us who heavily emphasized we don't spread out, and instead stay together. Eventually the ghost got agitated and started hunting us. So naturally we follow the person leading us into another room, in which the ghost followed and killed her. She raged over the mic at us for doing so. I pointed out that I followed her direction. To which she responded with some pretty angry choice of words.

Next game was with two jolly Germans. We got spooked, laughed, and had a grand old time.

10/10. Would ghost hunt with Germans again.

So I've been playing this game for 21 hours now and here's what I can say about it. It's not often I get genuinely scared by a horror game, and upon launching Phasmophobia for the first time I wasn't expecting much when I saw the Unity logo pop up on the screen. Oh boy was I wrong.

Upon first glance at Phasmophobia it comes across as a cheap, taped together survival/horror game, but after a few hours playing I learned that there's so much more than meets the eye.

The rules are simple, in a team of up to four players, you assume the role of paranormal investigators. Initially only being equipped with basic tools you enter a haunted house, as your player level progresses you can unlock access to other spooky locations such as an abandoned high-school and a derelict mental asylum.
Each location has been inhabited by a paranormal entity, it's your team's job to locate which room this being inhabits, and then endure the ensuing horror as you desperately try to figure out which of the nine types of ghosts it is.

Each ghost has unique abilities and tell-tale signs, such as freezing temperatures, fingerprints that can only be found with a UV light, ghost orbs which are only found with the remote video camera etc.

Phasmophobia promotes and rewards teamwork, mostly requiring one player to stay behind in the 'command centre' overseeing each player's sanity as well as recording sound data, player location, paranormal activity (There, I said it) and watching live video footage through either security cameras, remote video cameras or mounted 'GoPros'

For those who are a sucker for realism and immersion I would highly recommend you use the in-game voice communications instead of a third-party software. The in-game voice quality is second to none and the radio communications really do their part to immerse you into the horrors that is Phasmophobia.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who thinks they can stomach it. With only a few locations to choose from for now, it doesn't affect the game's replay value at all, and with so many different scenarios you can expect a different experience every time.

This is such a great horror game, with a lot of genuinely scary moments! It has a very suspenseful atmosphere, and a building sense of urgency as you work your way through identifying the ghost and completing other objectives, especially as the ghost gets more and more pissed off. 

The game perfectly encapsulates the vibe from those ghost hunting shows, with the radio communication between the team, and the ability to communicate with the ghosts using voice recognition. [i]I highly recommend using in-game voice comms as opposed to Discord, for the full experience.[/i]

It's great playing with your friends, and in my experience it's also worth mixing things up by playing with randoms, as with different teams comes an element of unpredictability resulting in a different playstyle/experience. So far I've met some cool people and it's been a good laugh!

I look forward to continue playing while following the development, and I highly recommend the game to anyone interested in the co-op horror genre.

[b]** For anyone interested in following the game's roadmap, you can find it [url=https://trello.com/b/9QrnqQ1j/phasmophobia]here.[/url] **[/b]

Phasmophobia is a 4 player online co-op psychological horror where you and your team members of paranormal investigators will enter haunted locations filled with paranormal activity and gather as much evidence of the paranormal as you can. You will use your ghost hunting equipment to search for and record evidence of whatever ghost is haunting the location to sell onto a ghost removal team.

You can choose to support your team by monitoring the location with CCTV cameras and motion sensors from the safety of the truck or head inside and get your hands dirty with the ghostly activity that will get increasingly hostile as time goes on.

Immersive Experience: Realistic graphics and sounds as well as having minimal user interfaces will ensure a totally immersive experience that will keep you on your toes.
Cross platform: Phasmophobia supports all players whether they have VR or not so can enjoy the game with your VR and non VR friends.
Co-op multiplayer: Play alongside your friends with up to 4 players in this co-op horror where teamwork is key to your success.
Unique Ghosts: Over 10 different types of Ghosts all with unique traits meaning each investigation will be different.
Investigate: Use well known ghost hunting equipment such as EMF Readers, Spirit Boxes, Thermometers and Night Vision Cameras to find clues and gather as much paranormal evidence as you can.
Full Voice Recognition: The Ghosts are listening! Use your actual voice to interact with the Ghosts through Ouija Boards and EVP Sessions using a Spirit Box.

So, what can I say about Phasmophobia?  The game is in early alpha and, but already has all the makings of a great game.  The dev is actively working on bug fixes and there is a very active and friendly community, so as of now, all of that is good.

So now, the gameplay.  The game has its spooky moments, but a lot of how scary it is has to do with who you play with.  Playing by yourself, especially on a level like the high school or asylum can be very nerve wracking and provide some genuine moments of dread as you cower behind a desk by yourself while the ghost stomps around looking for you.  On the other end of the spectrum, if you play with a group of skilled goofballs, you'll end up with some really funny and memorable shenanigans.

Example 1:
-We needed a ghost to act up in order to get evidence, but it was only skirting around us and hissing on occasion.  We knew the ghost acted up around people who were alone, so we sent in one guy to go flirt with the ghost as the rest of us stayed in the van and watched on the cameras we set up.  Through his valiant efforts, the ghost started to reciprocate his passion and started to show up more.  We all got out alive, but sadly, our partner didn't get the ghost's number.

Example 2:
-We wanted to get a ghost to act up so we could fulfill an extra objective and were feeling somewhat daring, so we all piled into the same bedroom, jumped around on the bed, and the other three team members chanted out the ghost's name as I serenaded everyone with my Mongolian throat singing.  To my surprise, the ghost didn't enjoy this display and even told me to go die over the spirit box.  We all survived this encounter as well.

All in all, this game has a solid foundation and I am excited to see what it becomes as the developer puts more levels, items, and ghosts into the game (still hoping they add a fishing trawler level as a small map).  Ultimately, the game is what you make it though, as you can have more fun with an outgoing group or a spooky time with a more serious group.  Hopefully this helps and happy hunting to everyone whose out there!

I am not normally a fan of horror games, as most use the same recycled tactics to 'scare' you. This game is a bit different, however. After stumbling across a few streams, it looked alright, decided to give it a try. What I was witnessing was people streaming the game exhibiting genuine fear/nervousness. Seeing it in Early Access had me slightly concerned, as I've been burned many times before by a crappy unfinished game. I am here to tell you that yes, it may be technically unfinished, but sweet mother it delivers. Instead of focusing on scripted jumpscares, or disturbing imagery, or obscene amounts of gore, this game manages to deliver 100% genuine fear and the adrenaline rush that goes with it. This is a proper horror game entry; psychological terror extraordinaire. The visuals I would rate a solid 6.5/10. It's nothing to write home about, but they're not cardboard cutouts either. What sells the terror to me more than anything else is the sound design. Floorboards creak, items move about the room, stairs crunch, whispers hit your ear (and legitimately sound spatially close/correct). Anyone with a decent set of headphones is in for a bad time, and I mean that in a good way. The doors flinging open/closed in front of you are spooky, but not scary. What makes them scary (to me) is hearing them open/close outside your field of vision, or hearing ghastly footsteps near you when you are the only one present, or hearing a ghost materialize behind you... So again, for me, 75% of the spoop-factor is in the sound design.

Numerous times I've soiled my drawers, sat in corners and cried, or simply Alt+F4'd. The effect is duly exaggerated in VR. I play both non-VR and VR (Rift S) with friends (you can technically play solo, but I am too big a baby to do so. If you "don't have friends," head over to the Phasmophobia Discord and hook up with the fine folks there. I have had many a good time with total strangers looking to get spooked). I have not had A) This much fun and B) This much anxiety/stress over a game in years. For the EA price of $13.99, you will absolutely get your moneys' worth, and more. Also worth noting, I have personally experienced a handful of small, inconvenient bugs from time to time, but am perfectly okay with them (remember, game is still Early Access), as the developer is actively patching most of them out, and is very involved with the community.

TLDR;
Game may be technically unfinished, but is absolutely guaranteed to give you a real scare. Amazing horror game. Does not focus on jumpscare tactics or violent gore. Instead, keeps you awake at night with psychological torture.
Visually = 6.5/10
Gameplay concept = 8/10
Sound engineering = "Soiled-Pants"/10.

First off, I'd like to mention that this game is really, really fun. It nails the atmosphere of being a paranormal investigator, using all the tools to figure out what type of ghost it is that you're actually hunting, and the game can be legitimately terrifying at times. However, I just cannot recommend it in the state that it is currently in. The movement speed is painfully slow. I don't know if the devs did this to make the game more scary, but it's just ultimately frustrating. The game would be just as spooky if you didn't move at the pace of a snail going through molasses. The game is also extremely buggy. I do understand that it's a small indie team making the game, but that doesn't excuse the fact that whenever I complete a mission there's like a 50% chance that my screen is pitch black and I have to close and relaunch the game. I really hope that these issues are resolved in the future, because the concept is amazing, but I really cannot recommend when I actually don't know if something is a bug in the game or evidence of a ghost.

For $14, you get a lot of entertainment for you and your friends. For this game being in early access, I am impressed. One lead developer has taken this game so far already. Thank you Kinetic games for making such a enjoyable, scary experience for me and my friends. I plan on playing this a lot more, and I can't wait for new features to be  implemented later on.

This is an exceptional horror game that does not depend on jump-scares to frighten the audience. Instead it utilises people's fear of the dark and the unknown by using great sound design to heighten the already tense atmosphere. 
At the beginning of playing the game, I did not want to go in alone -- the change of ambient noise from being outside to being in the location was scary. The darkness and the random creaks, opening and closing of doors, moving objects and hearing footsteps and voices really spooked me. I hated every time we had to go to the generator to be able to turn the lights back on.
Its helpful that the game offers a Journal which allows players to fully understand the type of ghost they are dealing with and what it's unique strengths and weaknesses are, as well as information about the different types of evidence and equipment. 
However, after player for more than 2 hours over the course of many days, I realised that I was less scared of the game as I knew what to expect... but i still enjoy it and playing it with other people makes it a much better experience. 
Even though this game is still in development, I still have high hopes for future developments!
spookingly addicting to be scared

Honestly I can't say how much I've enjoyed this game so far.

For a person like me who's a huge horror fan/nerd, I don't get scared easily. Let's just say the game managed to break further beyond that barrier, which I think is saying something...

Example: I was playing with a friend of mine atm. We collected and set up the gear in the places we thought would fit best for getting good footage of the entity, but little did we know that we were going up against an Oni. After setting up a couple things downstairs, we then began to hear things that were seemingly happening on the floor above us, so we obviously went up to investigate. We found a bedroom and began to joke about how the entity was a "gamer" because of the tall desktop pc and the two displays that were on a table in the room. I than forgot that after five minutes the entity will begin going on hunts every now and then and I began to slightly panic, thinking that we had no where to hide. I noticed that there was a closet behind me and pointed it out and said how I was going to leave one of the closet doors open just in case if it were to start hunting us. GOD AM I THANKFUL I SAW THAT DAMN CLOSET! Just barely a minute later, the lights began to flicker violently and the EMF reader that I laid on the bed began to spike up higher and higher on the lights. I looked at my friend and screamed that we needed to get in the closet right now. After entering the closet, we remained silent in the closet as the EMF was blaring outside at a level 5 and proceeded to hear footsteps that got louder and louder. Never have I felt so god damn scared in my life since I was 7 years old, when I accidentally watched a rated R horror film for the first time. After the EMF went quiet we assumed it was gone, but we were very well aware it was on the same floor we were on. We were forced to stay in the closet four more times afterwards because it kept coming back into our room over and over... damn that thing was active as hell! Knowing that it was going to find us eventually and that we can't sit in there for long, I counted to three to my friend and proceeded to open the closet door and we fucking booked it out of there. My friend ironically got a head start before me and darted down the stairs and as I was slowly trailing behind him I hear him panic for a split second and then go quiet. I then come to realize that the ghost got to him and locked the damn front door. I ended up grabbing a pair of keys placed within a bowl in the living room which was next to the front door, opened the door, and in mere seconds I hear fast paced footsteps occur behind me as I exited the building. Through all that shit, I got $10, but my unfortunate friend got half of that...

Never in my life have I feared for my safety so much until now!
You should too if you ever play this game!

10/10 tbh
The first game that has managed to break my "not being scared barrier" and manged to go beyond that!

Advice for those who may be new to the game:
- Try to reduce the amount of times you say the entity's name, it may be your last words. However, if there is absolutely no activity occurring, feel comfortable to state it's name once or more out loud with a simple question like for example, "how old are you" or "how did you die."
- Turn on the lights in areas you may not be active in, it just might possibly hint the location of the spirit if the lights shut off in that specific area (not saying this works all the time, but it's helped me out a bunch of times when playing).
- If the unfortunate event happens where any lights begin to flicker violently, get to place that will conceal yourself from the entity such as a locker, bedroom closet, basically any tight space that you can squeeze yourself into that may give you a chance at surviving the attack.
- If the entity locks the entrance door to the building, each map is different, but there should be keys lying around that are colored differently. I yet still have to discover what the colors stand for, but all I know is that you should grab it and head for the entry door, it should unlock it.

This game is phenomenal in so many different ways and I'll be looking forward to future updates as they come by! Keep up the great work and good luck to those who are new and experienced on your future hunts!  :)

If you've seen a ghost-hunting show on television, you'll know exactly what you'll be doing in Phasmophobia. Ideally played in a co-op setting, Phasmo pits you and your ghost-hunting team against one of a variety of different types of malevolent spirits haunting locales. Your goal is to primarily identify which ghost type you're dealing with by observing its characteristics and entering data into a notebook that you have. This is done by utilizing your ghostbuster tools. Things like UV lights, which allow you to see phantom handprints or thermometers, which allow you to register cold spikes when supernatural presences are nearby. Upon successfully identifying the ghost, your team leaves the site and earns money and XP based on how much evidence is acquired and whether or not you're accurate in your assessment.

Sound technical? Only slightly. The real fun of the game is in how this is all done. Talk about an atmospheric experience, Phasmo delivers on the chills. One of the most unique features to the game is that the game listens to everything you actually say over your mic. It's open mic and the spirits are listening. This means that you can ask the spirits questions, encourage them to appear, or even anger them.. all based on what you chatter over the mic. Want to hear something scary? Ask a spirit if it can show you a sign of its presence. Few games incorporate a mechanic like this into gameplay and the result is absolutely terrifying.

"Ghost sign" begins sometimes as slight as listening for a small creak or knock in another room. Sometimes things will move or you'll even hear a faint whisper or breath. The audio is mind-numbingly chilling in every way and almost requires a headset. Want the full experience? Turn off the lights. As many ghosts only appear when you're alone and in the dark, you can see how this primes the experience for terror.

There is depth to this game. It is a highly novel concept and great fun with friends. I highly recommend Phasmophobia and it retails for a very affordable price. Get it!

I never write reviews for games, but this one is a glaring exception.

Do you like horror?  Check.
Do you like GOOD horror that uses suspense, immersion, and tension and not cheap jumpscares?  Check.
Do you like solving mysteries/puzzles?  Check.
Do you like gameplay that's unique?  Check.
Do you like co-op?  Check.
Do you like games that require, encourage, and facilitate being social?  Check.
Do you like singleplayer?  Check.
Do you like emergent gameplay where every session feels different with endless replayability?  Check.
Do you like a friendly, helpful, non-toxic community?  Check.
Do you like early-access games with weekly updates and a dynamic and transparent roadmap?  Check.
Do you have VR but want to use it in a game with your non-VR friends?  Check.
Do you like feeling your hands get sweaty, heart beating in your throat, and funny smells coming from your draws?  Check.

The only cons i can think of right now are that there's quite a few bugs, however none are really game-breaking or frustrating, and they're being patched up almost daily.

That and it runs on Unity engine.  Why?

Regardless, this game is incredible, i've been playing it all day every day for the last week and I rarely get hooked this hard by games.  There's so much potential for development in the future, like new ghosts/evidence, types of hauntings, and maps (literally endless potential there).  I thought come November 19th i'll only be playing Cyberpunk 2077 (might still be the case ^^) and despite anticipating that title for 7+ years, I can still see myself playing Phasmophobia with friends.

Just get this game already.

I absolutely love this game. sure it has some issues in connections at times. but it's really great for an indie game in early acces.

the main tip I would give the dev: double down a bit more on the horror. right now, it ramps up from 0 to 100 real quick. it's scary, but I would like to see some more & different/new random events to scare players while still at level 0, while keeping the 0 to 100 very fast. and on bigger map, some more activity in general would be nice as well. and just in general some more randomization regarding map lay-out and ghost(-activities) would be great.

also because of activity going from 0 to 100 so quickly, death is too often no preventable. maybe give the player a bigger window to 'escape' the ghost attack?

other than that, I think the game is amazing and it's worth the price FOR SURE. great atmosphere, scary moments, pretty solid controlls, good gameplay and very fun.

I'd give it a 7.5/10 in it's current state.

As someone that HATES horror games, Phasmophobia is surprisingly fun. I've had a few scares from scurrying footsteps and what I can only assume is my heart jumping out of my chest, but there's also some fun in angering a ghost and hiding for dear life, or baiting a ghost to scare a friend.

It's early access, so there are a few bugs here and there but nothing game breaking. I still think it's worth the money and I can't wait to try it in VR.

A superb example of what VR horror games have been needing, a complete immersion into a terrifying and dark area.  Creeping around every corner with the utmost of caution as not to disturb the ever-present and dooming threat that is the ghost.  Every single ghost interaction I have had in this game, inside of VR and on desktop, has been truly heart dropping.  If you want a genuinely high quality and terror fuelled game that has very fun and repeatable missions, I would highly highly recommend this game.  This game has given me something fresh and exciting with it's varied locations and in depth ghost hunting strategies and I cannot recommend it enough.  

Even if you absolutely hate horror games and you could never imagine yourself playing it, I recommend that you do.  Being full of absolute dread in a situation like that in Virtual Reality gives you such a rush that is so difficult to explain.  

This game can be played completely solo, but I personally wouldn't recommend it.  The game becomes much more technical based and team oriented when you can play with friends or even randoms that you find in public lobbies.  

Awesome graphics, absolutely stellar sound design that perfectly encircles you in mysterious and anxiety inducing creaks and bangs around the house. It truly makes you feel like you're being watched, or even the feeling of being in the same room as the entity is super immersive.  You will KNOW when you're near the ghost, or when IT is near YOU... 

Highly Recommend!!!  Please expose yourself to this awesome game and contribute to the developers making it even better!!!

I've put in quite a few hours into this game and it's more than worth the price.  I do suggest for new players reading this, once you learn the game, play as a team and don't just sit outside.  This can be very annoying and it makes it harder for the team to come to a conclusion especially on the higher difficulties.  This game feels like an original that hasn't been played out and I look forward to the full release.  Graphics are not the greatest but it doesn't really matter because the game play is exciting.  The mechanics are simple and easy to learn.  The items have a learning curve but there seems to be more consistency as updates come out.  I highly recommend this game.

As somebody who generally dislikes horror games and movies, I was convinced that I would refund the game asap.... However, I am utterly surprised how much I like this game and had no urge to actually refund it after playing.

The premise of this game is quite simple, you are a 1-4 man team and your goal is gather evidence about the ghost that inhabits the premises. The type of ghost varies and sometimes only 1 person can be with the ghost at once (very scary). I can't go into much more detail without giving anything away, but the experience this game provides is absolutely amazing.

I have played this in both VR (index) and desktop; it's safe to say the game is no where near as scary in desktop mode once you have been in VR. If you're using an Index, I suggest that you use a custom mapping for the game as it will make you feel incredibly nauseous otherwise.

This game offers a truly unique experience that you will not find elsewhere and has the key component for a game, it's very fun!

Considering how this game was made by just one guy, I would say he really nailed it in terms of mechanics and scare factor (atmosphere, ghost interaction). I like how there's scaling difficulty with the professional modes and bigger maps, which certainly makes ghost hunting effectively a bit more challenging. But once you've nailed down the process, everyone goes on auto pilot. 

The co-op factor of this game is what makes it more anxiety-inducing yet more more fun as well. I would say some objectives or clues still require more polishing though - e.g. preventing a hunt using a crucifix, how the ghost chooses their targets during a hunt (sometimes it goes for the person nearest it, sometimes it goes for the person with lowest sanity, etc., which is a little hard to tell). 

Other than those small stuffs, the game is pretty much seamless. Kudos to the developer! I hope he introduces more modes, maps and ghost interactivity/types into the game as it continues developing :D I definitely see this game getting bigger in time to come (and just time for Spooktober too)

[h1] Phasmophobia [/h1]

[i] Phasmophobia - The fear of ghosts is sometimes referred to as phasmophobia and erroneously spectrophobia, the latter being an established term for fear of mirrors and one's own body. [/i]

[b] Plot [/b]

You or up-to three investigators try their hand at solving several paranormal mysteries. Using various equipment to discover the spirit before them. Can they keep their Sanity during their investigation? Will they survive? 

[b] In Depth Look [/b]

You're an investigator investigating several locations to gather intel about the Spirit that roams that area. Gather the correct evidence for the Spirit Removal Team. Start off with Amateur difficulty and Small locations (Farmhouse, Resident Homes) and make your way to Medium sized locations (High School, Asylum). Level your character to unlock better gadgets (Head-mounted Cameras, Mobile Microphones etc.). You use your journal to figure out which Spirit you are encountering based on different clues you can get. You have five minutes to search the location and find the Spirits' location (Randomly Selected) and setup your equipment. Use DSLR Camera's with Infrared and other gadgets. Use your journal to mark down the found clues to narrow down your Spirit. Use the Spirits bio to determine your next clue assessment.  Be careful because the Spirits can hear you. Careful not to say their name as it will only anger them. Sometimes this is required to gather specific intel on them. Just know they are always listening and will react at any moment. You need to stay on your toes and always move as a team unless the Spirit prefers otherwise, but keep a close eye on their Sanity. 

[i] Sanity [/i]

A very important piece of your characters mental stability and overall survival chance. Keep an eye on this as it can affect how your character can last during a high activity run for the Spirit. 

[i] Spirit Activity [/i]

Notated in the base truck is the current and 60 second limit Spirit Activity. Ranging from 1-10 will show the severity of the Spirits activity. 10 means the Spirit is in hunt mode and you should be on your toes and should hide or leave the place immediately. 

[i] Sensor Activity [/i]

Similar to Spirit activity this relates to your motion/sound sensor gadgets. Directly linked to your home base for remote readings. Place sound and motion sensors throughout the location to see where they are lighting up and what the strength is. This helps mainly for larger missions. 

[h1] Pros & Cons [/h1]

[b] Pros [/b]

[list]

    [*] Ghost Hunting
    [*] Multiplayer/COOP
    [*] Upgrades
    [*] Horror Element
    [*] Puzzle Element
    [*] VR Ready
    [*] Good Pricing
    [*] Early Access
    [*] Graphics are OK
    [*] In-Game Voice works for teamwork & Spirits
    [*] Level Layout is well done
    [*] Game mechanics are good
    [*] Replay rating is high 
    [*] Randomly generated missions
    [*] Perma Death-ish idea (When the player dies you can get an insurance photo taken that gives a large sum of money back; if 
         not then you're in trouble)
    [*] Tremendous potential
    [*] Active & Updated Roadmap
    [*] Spirits looks terrifying

[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]

[list]

    [*] Player animations are poorly done
    [*] Player models are terrible
    [*] Spirits/Player models can glitch through walls/doors/objects (Unpolished)
    [*] Some gadgets are just iffy & seem useless (Needs tweaking)
    [*] Overall polishing of actions needed (Turning on/off gadgets)
    [*] Walking & Running Speed is beyond slow (Crouching is [i] slightly [/i] faster than regular walking )
    [*] (Currently) Dead Players are Spirits but can't do anything to help; it's just an ethereal realm
    
[/list]



[h1] Overall [/h1]

This game is fantastic with friends. This game is absolutely terrifying. It's perfectly priced for where it's at. It has a tremendous amount of potential. I streamed this game for 5.75 hours straight and experienced a lot of gameplay mechanics that I love. The replay rate is high. I can't wait to see what these developers come up with moving forward and how it will be polished in the future.

Very spooky ghost game. Very fun spooky ghost game. An absolutely terrifyingly funny spooky ghost game. If there's anything about co-op games that I know of, this would have slid under my radar at a glance. Once all my friends got it, it's very fun to be absolutely terrified of the ghosts just creeping behind us no matter where we were. The concept for this game is great.

Of course, though, it isn't without its flaws, which I see why it's in Early Access, and I'm sure they're being addressed, but here is what I noted, and what I'm criticizing:
- With how often I play with my friends, they [u]constantly run into long loading times[u] or the game just ends up [u]freezing/crashing[u]. It seems that only more high-end PCs can run the game, and that's kind of dumb considering some of my friends have managed to run and play GTA V without many issues (that isn't internet related, anyway)
- [u]The "sprint" doesn't [i]feel[i] like a sprint at all[u], if I had to be honest. I'm not gonna entirely diss this out, but I wish it was a little faster. I just don't like how slow it is, considering how there's medium and large maps, and traversing these maps at the speed the sprint is just doesn't cut it.
- [u]Make whoever starts the game lobby [b]always[b] be the game session leader[u]. It kinda appears to be random whoever gets it, and I believe that what happens is whoever manages to join the lobby back the fastest gets leader, which is a little annoying having to pick the levels through "turns". 

I personally think these kind of Quality of Life changes and optimizations will make this game much better to play, particularly with friends. This game is great, and I especially didn't think I was gonna play this more than once with my friends. It's perfect for October.

A REALLY well made indie game!

This isn't your regular half-baked indie horror game! This game goes far above and beyond what you'd expect of an indie horror game! There's no major story plot to speak of... and that's perfectly fine. In fact, I'd say that plays to the games strength.

The players are basically ghost hunters who go out and investigate haunted locations. The primary objective of every game is to identify what kind of ghost you're dealing with and they're not all the same. There are multiple different types of ghosts and they all have varying behaviours and require varying methods to identify them, which is where the challenge comes from in this game. You CANNOT go blindly guessing what kind of ghost you're dealing with, you will more often than not have to risk your mortal neck to figure out who and what you're dealing with.

There are multiple maps in this game, you start out with small houses before moving on to the larger, good ol' fashioned abandoned schools and asylums. Don't think for a second that experiencing each location once allows you to know what to expect either as there are even different variations of each map, meaning you're unlikely to get the exact same map, or ghost, twice. At least not in a row. This also plays into the games strength greatly as never knowing what you're gonna get keeps you on your toes and just adds to the scare factor.

The level of interaction between the players and the ghosts also plays greatly into the scare factor. Like I said before, in order to identify the ghost type, you'll need to risk your mortal neck. You'll have to set up camera's, look for hand prints, pay close attention to it's behaviour and even communicate with it! There's no easy way to do it either as the game was deliberately designed to be difficult. If you accidentally drop your equipment and don't know where you lost it, it's as good as gone. Your equipment is precious, especially your starting gear as you'll need it to identify the ghost type, so for the love of god don't drop them!

This game does have some minor downsides however, some to be expected from an Early-Access game (at least as I'm writing this) and some that are just poor design. For instance, the in-game VOIP is a little buggy. Sometimes when you enter a game, you might not be able to hear a player when other players can hear that player fine. Another bug with the VOIP is the Ghost Box which is basically the tool that allows you to speak with ghosts. However, sometimes it doesn't quite read your voice correctly, which is strange since in post-release patch 1, it was working perfectly fine and could read my voice almost perfectly, but after post-release patch 2, it started failing to even realise I was talking into it half the time, let alone correctly interpreting what I'm trying to say.

There is also an issue where the game will give you a red-herring and I'm at least 90% sure that this isn't intended to be a feature. Sometimes the game will give you a completely wrong piece of evidence for a ghost. For example, in one game I was playing with my friends we got the evidences: Ghost Box, Freezing Temperature and Handprint. These 3 evidences together mean't that it was a Wraith type. But when we left in the truck after putting the ghost type in our journals, the game SUDDENLY FUCKING DECIDED that the ghost was actually a Yurei which is a ghost that's supposed to produce Ghost Orbs on camera feeds and write in the Ghost Book, to which we didn't get either. Needless to say, this was pretty frustrating.

Despite it's issues and shortcomings (which will hopefully be iron'd out long before the game comes out of Early Access) the game is still a very atmospheric and damn well made experience and I ABSOLUTELY recommend getting it while it's still cheap!

Although I don't have a lot of time on this game it's well deserving of a review. For a spooky game Phasmophobia nails it. Not only is it scary but it's very engaging and certainly not a brain dead game. If you want something entertaining and at the same time cogitative than look no further.

This game has huge potential, but it won't last for as long as it deserves to unless the devs patch the handful of bugs, expand the content, and make the tutorial easier to understand.

If you have friends who can show you the ropes and you learn by doing, this is a no-hesitation cop. If you're the type to learn well from an interactive slideshow where you can't refer back to the next slide and there's very little context when that info is critical to understanding what you're doing, then you should also be able to pick this up on your own (though I can't imagine there are many of you). If neither of those appeal to you, give it a shot or don't.

"These are not fun times for you, Scooby. These are darktimes!"

Phasmophobia is an immersive VR game where you play as a ghost hunter along with 3 other friends or randoms. The game consists in finding clues and evidence of the existence of supernatural beings: taking photos, witnessing the creature strangling another poor fellow and piecing information together to find what type of creature it is. All of this while trying to stay alive from the murdering ghost.

It has some bugs in the setup such as crashing and voice chat not working but apart from that I've had a smooth experience.
extremely fun with friends
pretty killer game lul!!!!!!!!!

I only reserve my game recommendations for certain games and Phasmophobia definitely takes one of the top spots on my list of favourite games. Been waiting for a coop horror game like this to be released since forever and it really lived up to every expectation I had. 

First hour in, I have been spooked multiple times. Ten hours in, I've learned the mechanics because of its balance in simplicity and complexity. 15 hours in, I am still not bored with the different interactions that the ghost has to offer. Every game feels like I'm replaying the first hour as there is just so many things that can happen, complimented with the scare factor. 

Can't believe that this game is in early access and I cannot wait to see its potential once it is fully released.

It seems like a lot of the reviews seem to applaud the game for its atmosphere. Which, to give it credit, does a good job of creating. However, once you have the game down into 2 phases: find where the ghost generally is/its room, and constantly test the ghost to narrow evidence down. It becomes painfully obvious how inconsistent the ghost appears given the hints the game tells you. 

Saying its name pisses it off?
I can stand alone in a dark room with a friend in the van repeating the name and not get a ghost appearance for a solid minute. Does ghost hunting reflect this? Probably, don't get a reaction 90 percent of the time in "real" ghost hunting. However in this game,you get ghosts that don't bother appearing, or appear once every 5 minutes due to being shy.

Additionally, one of the main ways to consistently find the room the ghost resides in, the thermometer, seems to be particularly inconsistent. Despite the book saying all spirits make rooms at least somewhat cold, that is false. You can easily explore the house having the same temperature throughout. Only time it seems to work is only under the condition of "freezing temps" and nothing else. Which, at a low level, makes narrowing the ghost's room down very tedious and is only worsened by the inconsistent ghost responses.

TL;DR
Pros: Good atmosphere, VR and voice chat only is very scary.
Cons: Tedious and monotonous gameplay combined with inconsistent mechanics make the game easily boring after getting used to said atmosphere.
The only emotion I got from this horror game is Anger from losing all my Stuff to a Btch as Ghost name Charle Smith.

For a game that's come out basically two weeks ago at the point of writing this review, I'm amazed by how well it plays already. I've currently only played mouse and keyboard, but when I play in VR I'll update this with my opinion on that as well. If you want to see my quick opinion, scroll down and I'll list them as pros and cons with a TL;DR at the very end. If you want more of an opinion, read on :D 

----

[b]Pros:[/b]
 -Very immersive, especially with a decent headset
 -Good at scares without relying on cheap jumpscares for everything
 -Figuring things out is really satisfying! You feel like you actually accomplished something at the end of a successful mission
 -Level design doesn't feel boring. You get used to most of them quickly, but it doesn't detract from the game much if all
 -Good amount of content for how long it's been out.
 -Some levels can be played solo easily, but you also don't feel pressured to play with a full team of four in order to do anything. (Though if you choose not to team up on the larger levels then good luck)

[b]Cons:[/b]
 -Object interactions are a bit iffy at times. Be it placing them or picking them up.
 -Voice servers aren't perfect but are at least being worked on
 -The tutorial gives the barest information and doesn't explain certain mechanics necessary for actual play.
 -The game occasionally crashes upon loading into a hunt for no reason. 
 -Your mic sensitivity skyrockets (as intended for the game I assume) but if you have extra mics attached and enabled but not in use as your primary, it seems to pick those up as well instead of just your primary. Which has actually gotten me killed before I figured out it was doing that and disabled the other mics.
 -It leaves you to figure a lot of things out on your own, which isn't a bad thing, but there's some things that you may not pick up on at all without looking at other people's experiences. 


---


And now for more elaboration......

First off, this is a very immersive game. Headphones are your friend...and your worst enemy. The ambiance on it's own is great but the fact that you *have* to pay attention to the various sounds of the house to pick up hints and clues as to what is going on means that you find yourself startled by the sound of your friends simply walking up the stairs.  And then you get scared out of your wits by the ghost breathing in your ear a moment after. And when the action picks up and you're crammed in a closet...oh does it make everything even more terrifying. The spacial audio is perfect, and later larger levels actually add in an echo to your local voice chat which makes things even spookier.

At the moment voice servers are a bit sketchy but most of the bugs I've experienced have already been reported and the developer is actively working on solution and putting out fixes, or partial fixes, so that's a lovely thing to see. And most of the time you can fix it by leaving and rejoining the game. Annoying, yes, but you don't have to mess with anything in the program files or anything like other games I've played in this early of development so I'm counting that as a win.

The variety of locations is fairly good as well- I'm not extremely high level yet so I only have I believe...6 or 7 areas unlocked at the moment and I don't know if there's more I just haven't gotten to, but each one is varied enough that it takes you a few tries to start learning them and what rooms are where. Not that you have to memorize every location, but it certainly helps. The larger maps I have access to are quite a spike in size and are overwhelming at first, for sure. But they aren't terrible either and actually feel and look like the locations they say they are supposed to be instead of just large areas with random furniture.

The ghost variety is nice too! There's already several 'types' of ghosts you have to identify, each with their own little behaviors and clues but not completely so different that you can immediately look at something and know what ghost you're dealing with. That being said, sometimes despite collecting all the clues and figuring out the ghost type, the ghost doesn't behave like it should. Some of that I imagine is part of the charm, to keep people from figuring it out from behavior only, but sometimes it feels completely random how the ghost is going to behave and I'm not sure it's fully intended on that aspect. But, then again I could be wrong.

My major gripes are all basically quality of life things that I imagine are planned on being worked on in the future, but i'll list them anyways.

It feels like the journal needs more explanation for the tools you'll be using, and you need to be able to check it when not on an actual hunt. Being able to check your journal in a lobby would be great. A lot of things need more explanation that the tutorial just doesn't fully cover, but it's not impossible to figure out on your own.

The options menu is a bit confusing, not too bad but I personally like having tooltips that say what certain options do for those who might not be fully tech savvy when it comes to certain settings.

A 'test this item' option would be nice to try items in the lobby before buying them to use in game. If you die you don't get to keep your items so if you picked up an expensive parabolic microphone and then went to pester a ghost then died....well. There goes your expensive equipment. 

And explanation of a hunting phase!! Though, admittedly, it was fun to figure out what it was. But at least a mention of what might happen in one!

---

[b]TLDR;[/b] The game is incredibly impressive for how long it's been out. It's great if you like figuring things out and possibly getting scared at the same time and I could go on for longer about the mechanics and such, but it's more fun to discover yourself. Yes, there are bugs. Yes it's still in development. But honestly I've played fully released $40 games that were far less fun than the 13 hours I've already put into this game after having it for less than a week.

Awesome game to play with friends. The atmosphere is very good. It really makes you feel the tension. The gameplay loop is fun. There are 10 types of ghosts. You must find evidence to deduce which ghost is haunting the location. It's random every time so even though you may play through the same location multiple times you'll never have the same experience. This game is a must have if you can convince a friend to buy it. I've never had so much fun in a coop game before. It's got some bugs but that's to be expected from an early access game. Sometimes the doors can rotate 360 degrees and end up stuck in the wall. Also, ghosts may not appear in a photograph even if you capture them. Hopefully small bugs like these will get patched in time. I haven't experienced any game-breaking bug so far. I'm really enjoying this game and I can see myself coming back to it for an investigation or two every once in awhile for the foreseeable future.

TLDR: Phasmophobia good

It's early access but honestly has more content that many full release games with loads of gadgets, a good handful of maps to start with which will be expanded I'm sure in the future and a large variety of ghost types.

No playthrough is exactly the same and even with a group of 4, it doesn't lose any of the tension since once the 5, 2 or 0 minute grace period is over, you could be attacked at any time.
