Phasmophobia is an incredibly unique and enjoyable coop experience, that I would whole recommend to anyone looking at purchasing this game. As a solo-horror experience it is a reasonably scary game, one that will absolutely get a spook out of you or two. But the game shines brighter in its coop elements, and not in singleplayer. Anywhere from 2-4 extra players makes solving the haunts much easier, and more enjoyable, as they make bringing along extra equipment, and extra hands to handle all the equipment to minimize trips back to the van to restock. Each haunt lasts about 15-30 minutes, depending on difficulty and location of the haunt, all while you're using your equipment to track and record evidence of each different haunt (There are 10 possible ghostly encounters, among 5+ different maps currently). You connect into coop by generating a private room and inviting players through an invite code, and having them connect in-game, and not through Steam which is a hassle.. And you can't change a private room to a public, or vice versa, so if you want a full game of 4-players with you and your friend, you can't make a reserved spot, and just need to make it public, hope it doesn't fill before your friend joins, and if it does fill, you either need to kick players - which feels horrible for the person kicked, just so you can get your friend in for a full party, or else if you have a private room, you can only fill however many you invite.. Which if you have 3 friends to play with, awesome you have no troubles, otherwise you use the previous method... Hopefully this is fixed before leaving Early Access.. Other than connecting, the game feels a bit like a proof of concept to play, a few of the haunts will start to feel repetitive after a while, with minimal differences between certain ghosts, but as it's early access you can support it, and hope they enhance the game more, so haunts feel more different, and with more locations. Also - You are only given minimal amount of equipment going into missions, anything more you must buy with money you earn from completed haunts. Adding equipment to a mission takes it out of your inventory for the mission, completing the mission lets you get your equipment back, no hassle, no conditions, no needing to bring it back to the truck. But dying in a mission means you lose that equipment for the game, and its investment.. Plus you get less money at the end of the mission, just a note! But in conclusion, game is great fun to play with friends, and with decent spooks! Absolutely worth your money and time.

TLDR -
Pros:
Fun Cooperative gameplay! 1-4 players!
You can talk/taunt the ghosts over mic!
Spooky as heck!
Playing ghost detective is actually a lot of fun!
Low price tag!
Once you learn controls and equipment use, making ghost hunting efficient is fun!
Daily and bi-mission bonus objectives for more money per haunt! (Some are equipment specific, so make sure to bring one of everything if you can afford it!)

Cons:
A bit sluggish controls (Slow walking/sprinting, and almost mandatory rebinding.. VR or Desktop)
Making a party of half friends half randoms is harder than it needs to be
No steam invites
Some ghosts aren't nearly different enough
Some mechanics aren't explained in the tutorial (Crucifix / Smudging / Sensors)
A lot of trial and error in learning how to complete objectives, and find ghosts efficiently.
Spooks

After my friends left, I decided to play one game on my own. Me vs the spooky boi. And I honestly have to admit that it was one of the scariest experiences I had with a horror game, if not the scariest lol.
Having no story-line and being always randomly generated, combined with kind of realistic aspects of paranormal investigation makes this game truly scary. The fear of the main entrance locking itself, the lights turning out and the spirit haunting you, will terrify the crap out of you. 
Dying is actually not horrible at all, but the build up to that is. You only got maximum 3 items with you and got to head back to the truck to get the other ones. Every time you're out of the house you feel relieved. But you know you have to get back inside to gather evidence in order to find out what creature is haunting the place. 
In every other Horror game you run away from the monsters. But in this game your mission is to search, awake and trigger them. I think that is what makes it so much worse than other games.
I also love the grind that's going on. You get more money for getting much evidence. You need the money for better equipment. But once you die, you lose everything you brought. Which makes every decision really hard.

Well if you decided to play the game, play it with others. Unless you got balls/ovaries of steel to play it alone. But I promise: It'll scare the living hell out of you either ways.

Amazing, easily one of the best horror co-op games I've ever played. It's smart, fun, well optimized (for both VR and non-VR), great replay value, and smoothly creates tension without being over the top or predictable. 

If this game continues to be updated and active, we could have something really special on our hands. BUY THIS GAME if you are looking for a unique horror co-op experience or just a fun co-op experience in general. The sky is the limit and I can't wait to see what comes next.

Probably one of the best games I have played in 10 years. Honestly. Not only is the game good in its current state... but it has soo much potential. And the devs have set them up for success so much, because this is one of those games it could be very easy to set up new progression points and add skins/patterns/animations for ghosts - to make sure that even veterans gets thrown a curve ball now and then, so they can't figure out instantly what ghost it is - by just looking at one (if they are lucky to see a ghost visually, early on).

Wonderful game, scary as hell. Insanely immersive. Highly recommend this one.

I'm a grown man that was literally screaming in fear as I was chased down a hallway, down the stairs, and in circles around the kitchen until the ghost ultimately caught me and snapped my neck like a pencil.

Even worse: Turns out, nobody could hear my screams for help - because the ghost shut off my radio. It wasn't until I got atop the stairs once more when I got caught - right as my friend came around the corner. The scream he let out when he saw that ghost get me was absolutely priceless.

Truly torn between buying a new copy for a fourth friend, or another pair of underwear after that experience. :D 

Heads up, though: The game is super buggy at the moment, but still absolutely worth it. Some of the most fun we've had in a while. Make sure your windows default microphone/audio is set correctly, and then ensure the same in-game. Once it's set in-game, even if it says it hears you - close and restart the game again just to be sure. This is one game you DON'T want to start a session on and realize that your mic isn't functional! :)

Phasmophobia is a really cool take on paranormal horror. It's not perfect by any means but I can guarantee this game will terrify you. Fun solo, best with friends that are just as scared as you.

Pros
Atmosphere is always tense, keeps you guessing what's round every corner.
Random ghosts each time you play to keep things fresh.
Wide array of tools at your disposal.
Progression that allows you to buy better tools for more efficient ghostbusting.
Great, diverse ghost design, there will be at least one that spooks you the most.
Horrifying death animation that WILL get you every time.
Great sound design, spooky ambience and ghost noises.
Voice recognition that actually work properly. Using a ouija board and getting an accurate response for the first time filled me with a kind of dread I've never felt before. It felt like it was actually all real for a moment.

Cons (most of these are just nitpicks and don't detract from the game enough to stop you buying it)
Sometimes certain things like lamps or curtains will pop in, which is kind of immersion-breaking and can sometimes give you a fright when you're on edge.
Occasionally you'll be stuck with no evidence as the ghost isn't active at all, then suddenly hits level 10 and kills you. This can be pretty frustrating when you've been circling a location for 15 minutes trying different tools, only to die for nothing.
Ghosts pop in and out when appearing in a room. Maybe have them fade in and out, or some kind of animation?
Running (press and hold shift) is laughably slow, almost feels totally pointless.
You drop your items before the death animation plays which can take away from the scare since you'll be able to see it coming if you're paying attention to your tool.

Overall, Phasmophobia stands out as one the most interesting, entertaining and downright spine-chilling horror games I've ever played. Big recommend for horror fans, mystery fans, and everyone looking to have a laugh with their friends. Definitely pick this one up.

Hands down the best horror game on Steam. VR compatable, but also incredible on PC, Phasmophobia is a terrifying game that's all about feeling helpless, spooked, and well...dead. You work as a team of four to hunt down a very creepy ghost, and will be tasked with finding out what kind it is, (there are plenty, as you'll find out) and gathering information about it. The ghost will also be hunting you, however, and that's when things get chaotic, yet absolutely hilarious.

Make sure you find a group of 2-3 to play this game with, as it's not very fun alone, but there is also a great discord community to find lobbies of your skill level.

Phasmophobia is a game with incredible potential. Despite how early in the Early Access period it is, it has great atmosphere and feel. It's a game with moments that you talk to your friends about.

"Hey, remember when you asked the ghost one question, and it murdered you?"
"Hey, remember when you were chased upstairs in the farmhouse?"
"Hey, remember when the ghost was named Thomas Thomas, and we summoned him using sing-song?"

But I don't want to focus on Phasmophobia as an experience because I'm happy with what I've gotten so far. I want to focus on playing the game.

First, I don't play in VR, but VR has a huge effect on us screen peasants. We move excruciatingly slow. My assumption is the characters move this slow not because this is a horror game but to prevent motion sickness for VR players. I honestly don't know how the developer is going to adjust this, but I wish them luck.

Every mission requires tools which are either for hunting, gathering, or protection.

Because speed is the most important thing on professional difficulty, the viability of hunting tools is all over the place. The king of detection is the thermometer. It does that job too well, even compared to the EMF reader which comes in a distant second. It's the difference between active sonar and a metal detector.

On the other hand, you have all of the sensors (sound, motion, infrared light). They need to be far more useful than farming secondary objectives. After all, why would slap down a sound sensor and motion sensor when a thermometer or EMF reader can focus in on the haunted room? Then you have parabolic mic which I honestly cannot see a use for at all, even on Asylum.

The gathering tools are all useful because they're all required to properly identify the ghost, but there are some inconsistencies. The spirit box in particular has issues. I don't know if it's because of its short range, the volatility of the voice servers, or something else. It's a shame too because that is my favorite gathering tool because MOOD.

There are only two protection tools: smudge sticks and crucifixes. I honestly can't say I know what smudge sticks do. I know what the game tells me they do, but the experience of using them makes me uncertain. Crucifixes are incredibly important on higher difficulties, but they have a very small protection radius. If the ghost is haunting a larger room, your results may vary. Take my friend, for instance, whose neck was unceremoniously snapped with a crucifix just outside of range.

Of course, depending on the ghost you face, some tools have additional uses. For the most part though, there are adjustments that need to be made. I imagine this will be fixed as more evidence types and ghosts are implemented.

The last big problem with this game is the learning process. I understand that keeping players in the dark is important for a horror game, but as a puzzle game, there is too much obfuscating. The journal needs a rework because flipping through every page is tedious right now. Imagine what it'll be like when there are more ghosts and tools. Give my index finger a rest!

So is Phasmophobia worth it despite these problems? Absolutely, and with it's recent success, I think we're going to see great things in its future. Luckily for you, you won't have to wait because the game is great now.

I'll be honest here... I hate horror games. I can't even watch Paranormal Activity without having to watch puppy videos for a good 30 minutes to an hour after a few minutes. But let me tell you - this game has made me into a man. I feel that this game can be a very metamorphic experience for people like me who can't stand horror-themed media. 

For starters, being able to bring your friends into the game to help face your fears is a great kind of crutch to help normally squeamish people through their fears. If you are too afraid to enter the game's various scare houses, there is always the option of staying in the van and helping by monitoring the ghost's activity and relaying information back to your team over the in-game radio. There's always a way to help your team and contribute to the main objective - finding out what kind of ghost you're dealing with.

In my opinion, the process of finding out what kind of ghost is haunting the house you've arrived at is the most enjoyable part of taking ghost hunting contracts in this game. You almost feel like a detective when you are flipping through the pages of your ghost hunter's journal, reading the descriptions of each kind of ghost.

You have to piece together all of the evidence and connect it with the different kinds of ghosts that exist in the game, and even though there is a concrete way of finding out which ghost there is through entering 3 types of evidence in a certain combination, the evidence is not always crystal-clear. Sometimes you have to think back on what the ghost did around your party members, how it reacted to certain items that you earn by playing the game and gathering money to afford more functional items that make more clear the full range of powers a ghost possesses. 

Eventually I found myself emboldened to make more brave decisions. I left the van and entered the house, whispering "Mary Jackson, show us a sign..." as I nervously tried to help my team find further evidence to pin down what kind of ghost was in each house. And yes, sometimes I did die screaming in horror after thinking I was safe in a closet or bedroom after having turned off my flashlight, but I eventually realized that is part of the fun. Even though I lost all the items I bought and only got a small amount of insurance money back from dying, I realized that this was part of the risk/reward system inherent in this game. There was a lot of time and effort put into the systems in this game, and I know that the developer will continue to work on the game and fix the various bugs (in my experience, there weren't nearly as many bugs present as in some other early access games) and improve the formula even further. I can strongly recommend this game to anyone, even if they are usually scared like I once was (and admittedly still kind of am).

This game, (only being out for a few weeks at this time) is pretty solid. I personally skipped the training and dove in which provided for a much more exhilarating experience. The starter equipment provided helps with getting a grasp of the game and its mechanics. The objectives are clear and the evidence is easy to understand with only a few exceptions. As of now i am Level 12. With levels you can unlock different items but also maps. The maps you unlock come with greater difficulty and size. 

One thing i have trouble understanding is the Spirit Box for evidence. This item is probably one of the most difficult items about the game as its use is sometimes difficult to notice. Different events are supposed to ensue but on different occasions the results do not reflect the use of the Spirit Box whatsoever. Every-time the ghost has said something back it has worked, but other times it spawns a ghost event or flickers lights, you could argue that this is coincidental which is what i think aswell, but if this is the case it makes a round go for a lot longer than it has to if you cant decide to take Spirit Box for evidence or possibly die while continuing to look for the 3rd piece of evidence. 

Another issue is "hunt mode". Hunt mode is when a ghost will try to hunt and kill a player, (activity levels reach 10). I read somewhere you can hide in bathrooms and closets/lockers in order to avoid being killed. This may not be reliable but I've been killed through walls, doors and lockers/closets multiple times and am unsure if this is intended. The Crucifix is also a difficult item to understand because sometimes i get attacked through it but im not 100% it will block attacks every time. 

I do not recommend playing larger maps until you have a lot of money and/or items. (sanity pills are a must)

The game is new and at first its fun and exciting but the difficulty and activity of ghosts is rather low at Amateur and by that point you are hoping for something more after you've mastered the basics but the different difficulties to not apply to all maps unfortunately.

All in all a pretty stable game with minor inconveniences with great and refreshingly original content. : )

Spooky ghost game.
It reminds me of the TV shows I watched growing up: Ghost Hunters, Ghost Adventures, and such. This game is faster paced than I'd like. You want to get in and out ASAP, otherwise you risk getting hunted. An "elusive" difficulty/gamemode that has players trying to find out as much about the ghost would be great. Something like: your objective is to identify the ghost and gain as much info about it as possible. Is the ghost male or female? How old? When did they die? What/who killed them?
The kinds of questions you currently can ask in the game are simply to get activity, but the answers are meaningless and unused.
Once you put on your big boy/girl pants and go in there to get things done, this game is an enjoyable thriller. My two pet peeves are the weirdness with the shadows (your body does not cast shadows, but your hands do and the shadows are finnicky) and how the ghost can enter a hunt with no forewarning.

To clarify on the last point: the lights and flashlights do flicker for five seconds before the ghost starts moving, however, more buildup would be great. I was playing with friends and we were heading back to the ghost room when the ghost appeared in the doorway and a hunt immediately started. We had no indication that the ghost was going to be that active beforehand. That moment really broke the tension by releasing what little was built up all at once.

The best horror coop game I've ever played, scarier than a lot of single-player horror titles despite having other people playing alongside with you. Absolutely recommended for horror fans and/or anyone looking to be both spooked and have a laugh with your friends.

Phasmophobia is a fantastic game centered around a cooperative ghost hunt.  Players are tasked with entering a haunted location, setting up equipment, and discovering the nature of the haunt while avoiding it when it hunts.  What this game gets right is the sheer terror that builds over the course of the game.  It's rare for a multiplayer game to achieve high levels of horror, but Phasmophobia accomplishes it in strides.  One criticism I have is that the game could use a few more maps and ghost types to increase variety.  However, for an Early Access title, the core mechanics and base game loop are incredibly fun.  It's easily worth the asking price if you or your friends are looking for a good scare.

Let it all be known that this game is the best thing to come out of 2020. Phasmophobia the gamer where 90% of it's fanbase doesn't know how to spell or say it's name, but let's get into the gameplay.

Backstory -  This game is being developed by one guy @DKighter and let's just say it is stunning to see a game that is developed by one guy be this popular. If you don't fully know what Phasmophobia is then let me explain it to you.

What is it? -  Phasmophobia is a VR and Non-VR 4 person co-op game where your goal is to provide evidence that there is supernatural activity in the location you chose. Whether or not you choose to go in the house or stay in the van the game is great none the less.

Why you should get it - You should get this game because it just starting out and there is already hours upon hours of content and the dev plans on adding a lot more as time goes on. Another reason is the price $13.99 is an amazing price for a game like this. At first I thought the game was kind of dumb, but then I actually started playing and started making lots of money on professional jobs and realized OMG I've needed his game my whole life.

Overall I would give the game a 9/10 because of the fact there is still a lot of bugs, but not many that are game breaking, but if you want to give this game a try I highly recommend it!

[h1]Review From a Coward[/h1]

I don't like scary games. I don't like scary movies. I don't particularly enjoy scary books. 
I do, however, love [i]this[/i] game. 
It has the appropriate flavor of scary, in my opinion. [spoiler]I spend most of my time in this game running inside to plant a good video camera (or three) and then sitting in the van.[/spoiler] But honestly, it's the most fun I've had in a long time. I've also learned I am 100% ready and willing to leave all of my friends behind while they're screaming [spoiler]and dying[/spoiler] in a haunted house.
I appreciate the time that was put into this game to create the difference experiences that the player can have. Although the game isn't without some bugs and wonky controls, with proper funding and attention from the dev team, I can already see immense potential in this game. It's already such a unique experience, and I genuinely cannot wait to see what else they improve on.

Absolutely fantastic game made even better by VR. I'm not much of a horror fan, especially when it comes to jumpscares - however, I have NOT been able to put this game down because all of the horror comes from the atmosphere. You can *feel* that the ghost does NOT want you there. I do wish the optimization were a little better, it hogs up 100% of my GPU in flatscreen and VR both, even when I'm not streaming. However, issues aside, the dev has been fantastic with the patches and adding a few little things here and there to keep the game fresh.

To summarize the gameplay loop, you show up at a house/school/asylum and you're trying to determine which one of the 10 different Ghost types is haunting it and GET OUT. Each time, the room in the building that the ghost "haunts" is randomized, so while the map selection is limited (I think about six or seven maps right now?) the game stays fresh because you never know exactly where it will be,, and each Ghost has distinct behavior patterns, strengths, and weaknesses. Think you're dealing with a Jinn? Cut the breaker. Maybe a Wraith? Line your surroundings with salt to keep it at bay. Banshee? Better keep that cross close. Demon? Just forget everything and get out.

All in all, at this price, the game is a steal. I've gotten more than my money's worth out of it and I already can't wait for my next ghost hunting session with my friends.

It's not bad, definitely worth the price. My gripes are
1. It seems like more of a novelty at the moment, not something I can really get into
2. The controls on the index are...bordering shit. The hands are oriented in a way that feels less like they're your hands and more like they're those plastic hand sticks you'd find in a first grade classroom. Also rotation and movement have 2 separate bindings, the joysticks and the touchpads. If you try to rest your thumbs on the touchpads which is the natural resting place for them, you'll move/spin yourself around. Very disorienting at first until I figured out what was going on. Don't think there's any reason for it.
3. The graphics remind me a lot of some really clunky games like house flipper and thief simulator, and I'm not a fan of the art direction of either of those games. Could definitely use either another art pass or completely different direction because what's currently there isn't doing it for me at the moment. Also the leg IK on characters is really bad.

As for the gameplay itself, honestly I was impressed. I thought it would be pretty buggy, but during our whole first game it was stable and to be honest pretty terrifying. It's a scary game.

Overall, like 6/10. I do see a lot of potential and may come back to this game later. Graphics and controls take a lot away from the experience, but it's an early access game so expect it to be polished more as it get updates. I'd pick it up now if you're on the fence just because they say they'll raise the price on release and what's there is pretty good just unpolished.

It's been a very long time since I've found a co-op horror game that I am absolutely obsessed with. I was skeptical with the font image for the game title and the cheesy character graphics. I will say it adds charm to the game and comic relief from the horrifying adventures you are about to embark. As you prep for the game, buying  equipment, and shooting hoops with your friends. You will roll up in your surveillance van to the location of your ghost hunt. You see your objectives to figure out what type of spooky you have to find. You bring your journal and gear with your buddies to the front door. You have 5 minutes to laugh, talk smack to the ghost before you find yourself cowering in the restroom. Being locked in a room, seeing your breath, as your flashlight flickers, hoping that the ghost doesn't snap your neck or back in half. You try to get out but you have the ghost whispering in your headset that it know wants to get to know you. You find yourself screaming, "NO! NO! NO!" as you are trying to get out of the house again, guess what? The ghost is hunting, they locked the front door, and you missed your chance to hide in the closet because you kept asking dumb questions on the Ouija board. This ghost on the objective says it's responds to people who are alone. Then you have your buddy yelling at you from the van that they see the ghost and it's coming for you. 

Phasmophobia, re-playable, addicting, and I look forward to everything that's the come with this game. The cost of it is affordable and their discord response is on point for development. Highly recommend playing with a group of people who enjoy ghost hunting and spooky. Such an awesome game. Last co-op horror that I enjoyed was Left for Dead.

You are a ghost hunter. You aren't sure how you got here, you don't even particularly believe in ghosts, but you have always been skeptical and a couple of friends thought it would be fun to check out this "haunted" house. All you know is that you were told to bring a thermometer, and you have some cameras, a radio, an emf meter, and some flashlights. You also know the ghosts name is Michael Williams. Your team enters the dark log cabin, and spreads out scanning the house with various instruments, some people brave enough to speak "Michael Williams, are you here?", although maybe they aren't brave and just want to not hear every ambient sound. You enter a room and see your breath in front of you. It's cold. You crackle on your walkie talkie "I need a thermometer on the first bedroom on the left upstairs!" Your teammate arrives and tells you it is 2 degrees C. In a f*****g bedroom. It is ~20 C everywhere else. This is the place. Your team sets up in here, turning on EMF meters, radios, and a video recorder, and dropping them off in the room. People begin yelling "Michael Williams! Are you here? Is there a spirit here?" and suddenly the lights go off. You wish you had a flashlight, but there was only one regular flashlight and a dim purple UV light, and you were not one of the people that got one, and you didn't have the cash to buy one yourself. It's dark and for the first time there is pure fear. All you have is your teammates flashlights, and you can hear strange noises; heartbeats, footsteps,...was that a bang? You don't know what is teammates and what was a ghost. No one is yelling the name anymore. Suddenly, in the dim purple flashlight of your ally you can see a glowing purple hand when he flashes it at the window. Freezing temperatures and fingerprints. Someone checks the journal and finds it could be a wraith or a banshee, but you need to either get an EMF 5 signal or a spirit box response in order to narrow it down. Suddenly you hear some doors slam and the flashlights start flickering. The ghost is mad. The team starts to panic and run, and you hear the faint screams in proximity chat "IT'S HERE! I SEE IT! AHHhhhhhhhhh...!" You use your memory to fumble through the darkness back to the front door, but it is locked. You cower in the corner, powerless. After what feels like ages, a flashlight appears from a corner in steady light, and someone opens the door. You run back to the trailer acting as your home base and realized you have never felt more alive. You see a graph showing paranormal activity and you guys just reached a 10. Another graph shows you one of your team is dead. Unfortunately, you still have not narrowed down the ghost specifically, and you have to go back in and either get EMF or spirit box readings to have a chance at succeeding with any objectives. You could also take a camera and try to get a shot of it. You grab the camera and head back in. You go back to the room it all went down in and start yelling the name again, "Michael Williams, Why are you mad?" Suddenly, the EMF crackles to life, and you see fill bars. Banshee. You panic and decide that is enough, the picture isn't worth it, and start to leave. Suddenly the lights start flickering again and as you are leaving and look down a hallway, you see the banshee coming towards you and in a panic flash a picture, and begin screaming at the top of your lungs as you run towards the nearest exit. Locked again. The team is in panic, but the banshee targets one person, and you are it. You try to run, but you can't see, and you don't know where you are. You see an open closet, and hide in it. You want to ask what is happening, but your voice might give you away. You cower. Eventually, your team tells you it is over and the front door is open. You bolt, and make it to the HQ. You did not achieve all of the objective, and someone f*****g died, but you know what the ghost is, and better yet, you got a picture of it coming at you. You lock in your evidence of the ghost and decide to get the hell out of dodge. Mission successful, and for all that effort you got a measly $60. But you have never felt more alive. 

This game has more ambiance and adrenaline in its pinkie finger than any other game in the last 20 years. It harkens back to the horror of fatal frame and silent hill, but with the team of Left 4 Dead, and a bit of puzzle of a Sherlock Holmes game. But one of the coolest features is the use of sound. The game records you, and you WILL have to speak and be interactive with the game to succeed. It recognizes you saying the name of the ghost, and that will be apparent. The proximity and walkie talkie chat are phenomenal as well. There are I believe 13 types of ghosts you can find, which leads to an incredible amount of replayability as even if you did the same map over and over it is unlikely you would get the same ghost more than once. I have only played a few hours, and I am a little afraid to play more, but I have never had such an emotional experience in a game since my childhood. If you are even remotely interested in feeling your heart beat, this game is worth the $14 price tag. That is the price of a movie, and playing this game for an hour even without VR (which it supports) will get your heart beating faster than any scary movie you have ever seen. I don't really recommend games. You can check my history and see that. [b]I recommend this game.[b]

This is one of those games that has the potential to be much better than its current state.  It's got REALLY good ideas that could be executed way better.

- VR controls were made specifically with the Vive controller in mind.  Not only can VR controls NOT be remapped, but also using controllers for the Index or other peripherals results in jankiness.

- Teleport movement in VR feels janky as well; you're practically forced to use smooth motion for a playable experience.  This is the only VR game I've played where I started feeling motion sickness.  Not sure what the difference is between this title and, say, Rec Room or HL: Alyx, but the difference is there.

- You can't jump into a game with others until you've completed Training mode, which wouldn't be a bad thing if the training mode did a better job of explaining what needs to be done and how to do it.  The slideshow tutorial helps, but it needs to be improved.

- On the topic of the Training mode, the game doesn't seem entirely certain on whether it even wants to allow you to complete it.  Half the time I was in Training, It felt like a toss-up as to whether three pieces of ghost-hunting equipment were actually going to work.  In the end, only two of the tools actually gave me some results and I quit out of frustration.  When I started the game again, it somehow decided that not only had I completed the Training mode, but also successfully guessed which type of ghost was in the house (I hadn't guessed at all).

- The "Five minute time limit" feels more like a gentle suggestion than anything else; I only realized that time had finished counting down when the ghost had started getting ornery after TWICE that amount of time had passed.

I can't recommend this game to people in its current state.  I hope the devs give this title the time, polish and improvement that it dearly needs, because it's still based on some great ideas and I'm interested in seeing what they do with it.

Gone Home but this time, there's a ghost! One of the most original co-op games, atmospheric, investigative. Pour yourself a good drink, sit down with your friends at night and investigate a location together in an interactive version of haunted house.

(+) Can be played in a single player
(+) Private and public lobbies
(+) VR not necessary
(+) Many original mechanics, focused on investigating, fitting mechanic of door-opening
(+) Engaging progression: you make money to buy more equipment for bigger cases
(+) So much potential to expand this game
(+) Price

(-) Awkward manipulation with some tools (rotating a dslr camera, for example)
(-) Probably all buttons on keyboard and mouse can be mapped. Some have weird names (extra buttons on a mosue) but work, some have correct label but don't work properly (flashlight on mouse middle button was not working to turn on flashlight)
(-) Tutorial is very basic, generally a short guide for each investigation tool would be great to have on a press of a button (F1 to explain what I'm holding and how to use it correctly)
(-) I wish I could interact with more objects in the rooms themselves
(-) The designer has really hard time distinguishing between terms "its" and "it's".

Genuinely one of the scariest horror games I've ever played. This is such a well made game that takes horror to a new level. The environment is stunning, thematic and atmospheric that helps enhance the gameplay by instilling a genuine feel of terror and horror in your heart. Every game you play is unique, as there are multiple ghosts, multiple maps and multiple rooms in which ghosts can reside in.

   This game keeps you on your toes with fantastic audio and sound design that only helps in improving the experience as you can tell where the footsteps are, object movements, whispers, doors closing and many small things that the game developers spent time on making to deliver an astonishing experience. The map design is perfect and well constructed as it perfectly mimics places where ghosts are found, such as houses, farms, schools and asylums. It perfectly captures the experience of ghost hunting as there're no cheap jumpscares, or scares in general, that cheapens the experience, while making everything feels like a legitimate ghost hunting experience.

it's a 10/10 for me, despite not having the best graphics nor the best physics. Give credit when credit is do, I can hardly find any glitches for an early access game. That is a job well-done.

I recommend this game to be played in VR.  It can be a little clunky and sometimes you get some FPS drops here and there but nothing too bad.  The atmosphere is great, I don't believe in the paranormal and think all the shows are a complete hoax, but its October and Halloween is coming up and its nice to see a VR horror game that actually gives me chills and a long feeling of dread, of course its in early access and needs cleaning up, there are a few things to bug me.

  Please remove or replace the level system and just have money, this has caused people to become very elitist to the point that they will kick anyone under a certain level, this penalizes anyone trying to get better at the game (This game works great with 2-3 People), forcing them to solo play which is extremely tedious and mostly pointless if your goal is to progress (unless you continuously farm the same level over and over).  I understand not having a lot of room for items because Co-op, but if you are stuck in a situation where solo play is the only way to go, 2 items on belt and 2 in hand, isn't very effective (For flat screeners, for VR you can turn on things and leave them on your belt).  

Overall, the level system has created a prejudice and people are kicked for it and not given a chance at either learning about the game through mechanics/gameplay or being able to progress.

If you are coming to this game, please bring friends along, you will have a fantastic experience because good luck trying to get into a server without getting kicked. Good fucking luck.

While its cool to go in and figure out what the big bad is, I think that having to go back in and exorcise it would add another level to the gameplay, and encourage people to have to guess correctly if they want to preform a proper exorcism. Maybe it could be another optional objective too, but I feel like the missions would feel a bit more "complete" with it.

I absolutely love this game, the atmosphere relies on itself and the ghost you're attempting to hunt solely. I would say there's no jumpscares in this game as every sound and noise in the game is result of audio ques before something truly happens. In VR the immersion is entirely there especially when you play with other friends who are in VR, it controls much better in VR than desktop and is overall better quality of life. Equipment on your belt stays on and active such as EMF and Ghost box electronics. 

As far as what I want to see in this game, I would enjoy a consistent working voice chat, stable servers, desktop players being capable of placing stuff down rather than throwing stuff by looking down and pressing G (candles and other equipment can't be precisely placed at the moment), preferably a Peer to Peer option or just overall stronger dedicated server rooms. Past technical options, gameplay wise I would love to see harder ways to interact with the ghost. On higher difficulties the name of the ghost should be concealed and you should be encouraged to use Ouija boards to get its name at the cost of sanity to get activity from it. I would also like to see larger maps include multiple ghost types active at once but far separate from each other. More unique optional objectives and evidence would be great too!

This game for an early access and unity has been the greatest horror experience I've truly enjoyed. I hope the developer continues to add amazing content such as new ghost types and maps down the line as long as harder to achieve evidence and objective goals while also improving Ai and models. Please do yourself a favor and try this game as I haven't been disappointed yet!

Phasmophobia is like Dead by Daylight with a twist on the gameplay concept.

The core mechanics of the game is great and fun to play. Up to 4 players not only need to find 3 pieces of evidence that determine the identity of the ghost haunting the location, but are also given 3 other different objectives to accomplish while investigating. Each ghost has a unique combination of evidence that satisfies this objective. Once completed, players leave the location and receive payment for their accomplishments.

It's still in Early Access, so there are still a lot of bugs to work out. The tools used to accomplish evidence-gathering can sometimes be bugged (such as the ghost writing book or spirit box refusing to operate, or the ghost orb floating outside of the map), which can lead to frustration. The game isn't going to win any awards for graphics in its current state, but that's understandable (hence Early Access).

I hope this game develops into something more full-fledged and detailed, as it feels primitive in its current state. It's loads of fun to play with friends.

Ever watch a ton of Ghost Adventures and think "I think it would be AWESOME to do what they do!" so you went out of your way to try this game out? Well, Phasmophobia is a pretty unique game that gives you a damn close perspective of what it's like to be a ghost hunter. Without all of the excruciating possessions, deaths, and real life shattering experiences caused by Demons and the like, of course.
 
Try it out a bit more. You'll learn to get into the mood of your job. Want to be the guy that watches after the team and makes sure they're aware of all events gone unnoticed? Stay at the truck and play as the Nerve Center tech. 
Want to piss off an apparition? Taunt it all you want through local voice chat and have your fun as a 3 man hunter team.
Don't care about Nerve Center? Fine, make it a 4 man hunter team and grab all your gear. 
Want to troll your friends while no one is watching and just start slamming all the doors only to blame it on the ghost? Your call. 
Forewarning: I found out today that Shades can move equipment. The sly dead man shut off 2 of my video cams and moved a 3rd one downstairs in Log Cabin. I can vouch that all of my team was with me in Nerve Center when it occured.
Fun for everyone.
Mind you the game is still VERY MUCH in its infancy so it's bound to be buggy. 
If you ever have a voice chat issue with the game on a fresh install, be sure to verify the game's file integrity and it should fix it. 
All in all so far it's a 10/10.

It's not often that I leave reviews for games, but I have to make an exception for this one. I've never been someone who gets scared by watching horror films and playing horror games. While that still applies here, I must say that the suspense in some of the moments in this game seems like it was done by the Master of Suspense himself, Alfred Hitchcock. Along with that, some of the people you'll meet in this game are downright funny as shit. I was laughing my tits off the entire time playing this.
     There are certainly some bugs, but I'm sure that'll get better as time goes on. It can get a little repetitive, but not too bad compared to other games. Each match is unique, which is made better by the players. My first match, I had a user making fun of the ghost's (Donna Thompson) house to provoke it, saying lines such as "Did these plates come from a thrift store, Donna?".  Definitely worth your $15, and I'm sure it's only going to get better from here.

Overall it's a great horror game and it does an amazing job at spicing up the niche horror genre. Controls are good and adjustable. The ghosts are spooky and it really makes you fill like you're there. The ghost can interact with the environment and even speak to you through the game. The game features voice recognition so you can ask the ghosts things like: "Where are you?" or "How old are you?". Sometimes the ghosts respond with nice or sometimes malicious comments. One time I got the response: "Death!" which let me tell you, that made my heart drop like a rock. On the negative side of things (these are probably because of my below-average internet speed and computer) the game crashed several times. At one point my graphics driver failed completely. The voice chat works nice, although if you don't have a decent quality mic you will probably be kicked from most servers.

If you have a decent computer, try the game. If you don't like it get a refund, simple as that.

Are you hunting ghosts, or are they hunting you?

Unlike a great deal many indie horror games, Phasmophobia is not only terrifying but also a deep game with high replayability. You can play in regular desktop mode, or, if you're looking to really get spooked, it works pretty well in VR too. For an early access game, Phasmophobia is quite a bit solid already. The dev team seem to have their finger on the pulse as far as bugfixes and whatnot are concerned as well.

There are a good amount of videos on Youtube you can watch to kind of get a feel for the ins and outs of the game, but its main thrust is this: you are a team of paranormal investigators who go and gather evidence of malevolent spirits. You can use several tools at your disposal to gather clues and to narrow down the ghost you are dealing with, including an EMF detector, a thermometer to measure cold spots, a book for the ghost to write in, a device that allows ghosts to speak through it when you ask it questions, and many more. You can speak the ghost's name to get a reaction out of it, but the results are not for the faint of heart.

At present there are 12 kinds of ghosts you can encounter, and no one haunting is the same. You also have access to all kinds of venues like your run-of-the-mill suburban house, a farmhouse, a high school, and even an asylum. 

Be careful when traversing the locations in the dark, as your sanity meter can drop and thus leave you open to attacks from the spirit. If you notice your flashlight starts blinking, or you hear your heart beating, find a room or closet, hide, and don't make a fucking sound.

My only complaint is the proximity and global chat. Under normal circumstances, it works great, and lends to some great gameplay moments, but sometimes it bugs out and you can't hear your teammates talking. Other than that, Phasmophobia is a rock-solid, pants-wetting experience and perfect for celebrating October.

For game that's reportedly created by one person, it's very well polished...  when i first got the game i only knew one other person in my contact lists that also had the game and now i have about over 10 in about a week worth of playing the game (some of them i meet in the game).

put Simply, you are a paranormal Investigator with upto 3 other players trying to collect evidence in 'dangerously' Haunted houses trying to figure what 'type' of ghost is within the location.
At the moment there are about 10 different ghosts each with their own personalities, one will relentless hunt one person, one will only attack someone who is alone, others attack more frequently while the lights are off.

one of the more interesting aspects of the game interacts with your microphone as well, not only is it used to communicate with other players but also with the game itself, the Ghost can hear you, and if it does it may just respond for better or worse... helping you with clues... or will listen out for anything you may say while you hide in a closet, this can also be used to fight it though as any players outside the house could continue to taunt it to draw it away from those in danger.

To complicate matters further, you have to deal with the map... which can have it's own series of challenges in trying to collect credible evidence and not getting lost.
at the moment there are about 7 maps (3 street houses, 2 cabin in the woods, 1 abandoned high school and 1 asylum) 
It's reported there are more maps on the way.

The other players you work with also add random element as they can be to your benefit or to your bane...
for the most part you get players who are helpful good team players who you need to rely on to get the job done but the player community is not without: new players who don't know what they are doing or who are too scared to enter the house, or taunt needlessly (both the ghost and players), and then there are players who can take it to a whole new level of trolling while you are feeling at your most vulnerable.
This isn't strictly speaking the fault of the game, but one can't help in wondering it wasn't encouraged on some level on it's development where you can take the remote for the TV or the Car and activate it as a player wanders past it.

The game has its share of glitches which the developer has shown to be working on fixing. for the most part they are few and far between, but can happen.

You also have a level progression system but you do pretty much unlock everything by level 10, I feel like it needs something for the later levels or possibly more difficulty levels where you get a place with two ghosts or something...

Speaking as a player who'd like to reach out to the developer, I'd like to see a more broader range of Difficulty options, perhaps a 'random' difficulty setting where players don't know what the setup time is or even a possibility the house isn't haunted at all... this does happen alot in real life ghost hunting after all, and will constantly leave the players guessing... to expand on that further you could have a 'fake ghost' to which the owner had planted a series of bugs and sound devices to trick players into thinking there is a ghost when there really isn't. and finally i think it would be good if at least one of the ghosts were able to step outside the confines of the house and possibly visit them in the truck (you may want to put a cabinet in there for them to hide in if you do that though)
 but that's just my two cents worth of ideas.


Overall if you like the paranormal investigations and like figuring out mysteries plus enjoy the thrill of the scare then this is the game for you.

10/10 would get scared and scream my ass off again.

This game will remain with a negative review from me, until they fix a few things that makes the game feel better than it currently is now.

My reasons:
- You lose your stuff no matter what. (Even if your friends take your equipment you bought to the truck, you lose it. Period). Making it impossible for you to progress because the game will ask you to bring key things in order to complete a certain mission, but, it costs money and sometimes too much money.
- The VR part of the game is quite clunky and probably the worst thing I've ever seen. Hopefully they'll fix it, which I'm sure they will.
- In Non VR the game is still clunky with how it still feels like you are playing in VR. You have to hold onto doors in order to open them. But the controls are fine, once you get used to them.

Super scary, exactly what I've wanted from a coop horror experience for years! Now let me explain why my review is negative.

Not only does the voice recognition not work on Windows 7 at all, it has MAJOR problems working on Windows 10 as well. There's no way to properly play the game with this feature not working. My friend with a Valve Index also couldn't get VR working. He was able to play the tutorial once and said it was so terribly implemented that he was switching to non-VR mode.

Seems like a good concept, but the game is unplayable if you can't get the voice recognition to work. The developer has stated in comments that they're working on getting some sort of patch for Windows 7 users, but even their ideas to work around this problem are crippling the way the game is meant to be played. I personally use Windows 7 and refuse to "upgrade", and this game just doesn't work without the voice recognition feature.
This game gives you the heebies, & sometimes even, the jeebies.

I play the PC, not VR version. Yes, this game is early access, but it's already leagues better than many fully released games. I would love to give this game a big thumbs up.  It has huge potential to be an excellent shared horror game.  However, the 'ghost hunting' itself needs a major overhaul.  Collection of evidence seems to be arbitrary at best as you simply guess your way through each map on which ghost it is you're dealing with.  Twice in a row the game claimed we had a poltergeist with the evidence collected pointing elsewhere and none of its trademark 'throwing' of items.  The 'ghost room' also seems arbitrary as activity will occur anywhere, at any time, with any number of people around.  In the end, this game still has huge potential, but it has a very long road ahead to reach it.  Until that time, I can't in good conscience recommend a game that forces you to put in so much effort in collecting evidence that doesn't seem to matter while forcing you to simply guess the correct answer, with your experience and money earned dependent on garnering the right answer.

This is one of those gems that people wait for. 
A 4 player co-op game? Check.
VR capable? Check. (I haven't played it on my Quest yet because I'm too much of a scaredy cat)
A ghost hunting game that actually feels like a ghost hunting game? Check. 

Walk around the location finding evidence of the paranormal using your tools, all the while trying not to die. 

I love that it clearly took some inspiration from games like Left 4 Dead and Payday. 
The ghosts you are tracking are randomised, making your tools all the more important. 
The location of the power box is also randomised, it's important to know where this is because the ghost will mess with it. 
Jobs appear on a map which are also randomised, as well as details about the jobs such as objectives, the name of the ghost and how it will interact with people. 
Making this game a unique experience each time you play it. It's always a question of how many objectives you can complete in time, or will I die a horrible death?

And yes, you can die. It's terrifying and something you can only experience yourself, so buy this game if it interests you. 

Highly recommended. I can't wait to see what the Devs come up with over time.

Phasmophobia is a 4 player online co-op psychological horror where you and your team members of paranormal investigators will enter haunted locations filled with paranormal activity and gather as much evidence of the paranormal as you can. You will use your ghost hunting equipment to search for and record evidence of whatever ghost is haunting the location to sell onto a ghost removal team.

You can choose to support your team by monitoring the location with CCTV cameras and motion sensors from the safety of the truck or head inside and get your hands dirty with the ghostly activity that will get increasingly hostile as time goes on.

This is my first review on Steam. I've only played this game for 8 hours, but I'm completely enthralled by this game. I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys an investigative oriented game with the intensity of having to survive. Also, the community is amazing. I've joined a few random lobbies, but each one I've joined, every person was both friendly and objective-oriented. My only complaint is that mission difficulties seem to be based off of level, which limits me to Amateur missions when I've tried hosting. These missions allow you to be a ghost sleuth, but lack the intensity of having to hide and survive. All in all, for $14 dollars, this game is a 10/10.

Okay, so i would have to say this is the most... SCARIEST game ever made that makes my heart just wanna stop lol. Great game/love how you have to solve what kind of ghost it is/The paranormal Events that happen..

Game has been a great time with both friends and PUGS. I would highly recommend this to anyone who is a fan of horror, or someone who tends to shy away from them such as myself. Frankly, the game does not use jump scares, albeit on accident. Rather everything is simply terrifying because of how it looks and sounds. You'll find yourself listening to every small thing that happens in the house. As you progress through a mission and slowly learn what kind of ghost your dealing with, you'll begin to start feeling like you are a ghost expert, and you can handle the immense fear of walking throughout the house surrounded by your other ghost expert friends. But in the next moment, all the lights in the house die, your flashlight is flickering out, and doors cracking open. At this moment, your no longer surrounded by "Ghost Experts" but rather terrified people asking themselves why the hell they allowed themselves to buy this co-op "experience".

Phasmophobia is a rare instance of a cooperative horror game working wonders and not turning into a joke.

It is more than capable of suckerpunching you with a scare or even death even if you are popping jokes with friends. The chances of which increasing in likeliness the further into the haunt that you go, don't hesitate to leave with what you've got if you can.  

Preparation is Key, even the timing of when you do things is key. Your sanity is incredibly fragile, in which ghosts will prey on from actual encounters to just being in the dark.  If you've got solid teamwork going, you can nail what kind of ghost it is before anything too insane happens. If you're too late on the draw, you won't even be able to enter the house without the risk of imminent death.

I'll leave the actual mechanics for you to figure out as that's the fun of the game. 
Just get in there and remember you don't have to go in alone at least.

The gameplay experience consists of searching the house for evidence of what type of ghost is haunting the area. Things such as paranormal events, using salt to find footprints, etc. There is some pretty good variety in the levels so far. A school, old farmhouse, some nice suburban homes. 

As it is in early access, game is a bit shallow in certain areas like not a large amount of objectives, and you could use some more ghost hunting equipment. But I easily see myself getting my bang for my buck at this stage in the game given the low price. The general mechanics and loop is in an excellent place, it just needs some more content - as with any decent early access game.

This is some of the most fun I've had in a long time. I've always wanted to know how it felt to be a ghost hunter, and while the game isn't as realistic as one might hope for, it definitely does enough to make for a fun experience.

There are a few cons, which are to be expected with the beta version:

The lobby rooms keep the same name as the creator of the lobby, even if that person leaves, making it difficult for potential friends to join up to those rooms.

There aren't a lot of location varieties at this point. While the game diversifies the ghosts locations/types/personalities enough to make it not FEEL repetitive, it would be nice to not know the full layout of each house every time after a few play-thrus. The larger locations are also quite overwhelming and since there is no reward-incentive to encourage players to play these locations, they are not played through often enough.

Despite these cons, the game is superb and quite addictive. I would very much so recommend this to anyone wanting a good scare and a good time!

Phasmophobia gives you the control. You aren't stuck in a house with a ghost, solving puzzles and trying to escape like many other horror games. No, what makes Phasmophobia so scary is that your main objective is finding the ghost and gathering evidence and information. You enter the house on your own terms and choose how far you'll go to collect evidence about the ghost. You also have to cooperate with others to coordinate and plan how you'll approach the objectives. Will you stand in a dark bathroom talking to it? Will you stay back in the car watching a camera you placed? Will you yell its name and piss it off? 

Phasmophobia doesn't rely on jumpscares and catching you off guard as much as it relies on suspense and sheer terror. It is the most terrifying game I've played because you're forced to trade control for information.

Excellent game with good spooks! Turns into a puzzle game later on as you get more equipment and used to the scares, but it never really stops being creepy (and I still like the puzzle elements to it). Far better with friends, but you can play it alone if you're brave and patient enough.

[b]Some tips:[/b]

Press T (when you have a flashlight) to use your flashlight while holding a different item. You can use the UV light and the flashlight at the same time.

Press F to do an alternative action (like placing the camera). It's sad, but that one took me a minute.

The first thing you'll probably want to invest in as a group is more flashlights. Can't be hunting what you can't see!

You can use spraycans for the hoop in the lobby. Nothing happens at 100 hoops (sadly).

Hide in closets, bathrooms or lockers when your heart beats loudly and the lights flicker (when the ghost is hunting / activity level 10). During 10, the radio will not work and the people inside the truck can't hear you. The doors will also lock.

When hiding, keep quiet even outside of push to talk. If it hears you, it might still kill you. (They can open doors, remember?)

If you can't hide (some locations don't really have an option) you can kite most ghosts around obstacles. Not all, but most.

Always keep a general idea of where the power box is in case you need to flip the switch.

The lower your sanity = the greater chance a ghost will attack you. You can use this to lure the ghost into giving you evidence by using someone as bait.

The ghost can hear you whether or not you use push to talk. It is always listening. Be wise.

Don't name drop the ghost (taunting it) unless you are ready to deal with the consequences. It's natural to want to go in screaming it's name (and I've done this), but you're better off finding out where it is and have a game plan before you go into caveman mode. 

The flakiest evidence in my experience are ghost orbs (because they are hard to catch) and freezing temperatures (I've had ghosts that were supposed to freeze and never did). You'll get annoyed sometimes, it happens. Hopefully they work on this.

General working strategy I've found (when you have 4 friends) is to go in with the EMF, Spirit Box, UV Light, and Temp working in various hands to narrow down where the ghost is inside the house. EMF and Temp are the ones that generally work the fastest. Once you find one evidence, you'll probably find more in that location. Listen for cues like phones, pianos, footsteps, ect. The ghost will make noise even when the activity is low.

Once you isolate it, go back to the truck and get the book and video camera and place them in the haunted area on the floor or table. Have the book in view of the video camera so you can know if the ghost decides to write you poetry. If you have salt, lay it in doorways and walkways. Use the UV near the salt to track footprints. Have someone watch the vid camera in the truck for ghost orbs. Drop the spirit box in that area to keep it going in case the ghost is feeling chatty. Keep an ear for the spirit box at all times. Walk around with the EMF, Temp, and UV Light to narrow down the ghost's exact position, track it's movements, or narrow down evidence.

Once you collect two confirmed evidence, you can usually narrow down the ghost to 2 options inside your journal. Use process of elimination in regards to the evidence--it will be your friend, and help you solve the puzzle as quickly as possible. You don't need to memorize, just keep track of your journal.


That's all for now! Happy Spookums Month!

Now, obviously I know and respect that its still very new and in Early Access and so its definitely not perfected yet. I hear its all just one person developing it as well and its really good so far so I'm definitely impressed!

However here is sum feedback/ideas on the game so far:
- It's iffy with items occasionally missing from in game like even after adding them in, also with sum items not always showing up on the list for everyone in the lobby correctly.
- It's iffy where you use a crucifix or photo camera to defend against the ghost but it doesn't always actually affect it and so people end up dying anyways even if you did the right things.
- Sum times it changes host for like no reason after a match. 
- I think it'd be a good idea to have all lower levels/smaller maps still available to the higher levels as I'm sure there are people who might play this with only 2-3 people (maybe even alone.. Them crazy hoes!) or in general not want to do the bigger maps.
- I think it'd be a good idea to have it so that when you first start playing the game and are low level you at least won't lose any or all of your items when you die till you reach a higher level.
- Also I could be wrong but the insurance seems a bit buggy because there have been quite a few times where I lost all my items after dying and I didn't get any money back at all yet other times I have, so I was kinda screwed over by that which admittedly frustrated me a lil bit.
- I also think that the ghosts and their "behaviours" or "personalities" need to be more polished, for example I had a wraith earlier and wraiths don't show footsteps yet it did with the salt (I could be misunderstanding this tho and I will double check and correct my mistake if I am wrong, but I am pretty certain I'm not wrong).

This game was obviously made for VR and thats not a bad thing however it would be a bad thing if VR users get a leg up on the rest of us as they might be able to hold more stuffs at the same time, I think this is a tad bit unfair (but its not too bad tho like I get it). However I could also be wrong as this is just what I've heard from others so I will happily correct this if I am wrong.

The Devs seem to update it quite frequently which is nice!
I'm incredibly excited to see whats in store for this game in the future and I believe in the potential of this game :D

Most fun I've had in a horror game in quite some time.  The atmosphere and environments are cool.  The map layouts are neat as well.

Suggestions:

I like the idea of making small changes to ghost behavior on a regular basis and not letting anyone know.  I think this would help keep people on their toes as the game ages/the player base gets more experienced.

Multiple ghosts on the bigger maps would be sweet as well. (maybe even on the smaller maps from time to time?)

Bigger maps need more sounds.  When you go in a house, there are always creaks and squeaks.  The larger maps sound less lively by comparison.

More varied death animations and intensity based off of ghost type.  Maybe animations that match the ghost.  (axe ghost axe-murders you, demon babies eat you from the feet up, fast ghosts quickly brutalize you, etc....)

 Overall, just keep giving me more and I'll be happy.

Really great game. The only downside is the tutorial (at least for VR) didn't explain as much as I'd like it to. 

Important Tips for Newcomers (Especially in VR)

-Find the ghost room first (It may not even be a bedroom, but rather a basement, attic, or living room). Thermometers, EMF Detectors, Spirit Boxes, and strange activity like books falling over are all indicators of the ghost room.

-Your journal is on your right shoulder. Articles say it is behind your right shoulder, but in my experience it is always on the front surface of your right shoulder adjacent to your nipple. 

-Thermometers are extremely helpful, EMF readers don't always give an indication of where the ghost room is. If you enter a room that is drastically colder (It doesn't have to be freezing and usually never is) then you found the ghost room.

-Your Walkie Talkie is on your left shoulder, everybody on the map can hear you while you hold it down.

-Don't call out the ghost's name until you want it to become aggressive, stick to more general questions until then.

-Don't be afraid to ask a high level, "What does this do?" half of what I've learned has come from more experienced players.

-Lastly, and most importantly, VR Players can lock other players inside of rooms by grabbing the door handle and holding it shut.

TL;DR this game has more replayability and less bugs in early access than any AAA game I've ever played at release.  If you don't have friends/you don't like randoms/you are brave, a singleplayer mode not requiring internet connection is in the works--so grab it while the price is still an absolute steal.

I honestly don't remember how I came across this game on Steam but I'd been looking for a good co-op horror game that I wouldn't get distracted just building in, as I usually cross it with the survival genre.  I looked up some videos of it on YouTube and knew immediately that I would shit bricks if I played it.

But... after a day or two of ultimately circling back to watch videos of it... I decided to put on my adult pants and try it with one of my co-op buddies.  I have zero regrets, other than the random nightmares and escalating power bill from keeping the entire floor's lights on at night.

A lot of reviews already phrase this game's appeal well: it's the fill for the niche that has been hollow for too long.  The game doesn't bank on GPU-breaking graphics to hide watered-down gameplay or intense cinematic cutscenes for flashy jumpscares--the horror is through the atmosphere and the tension, with just the right build-up to any form of jumpscare.  You jumpscare yourself just from basic interactions because of the immersion you find yourself lost in, that by the time the ghost you are hunting DOES appear, it's the anticipation YOU have created in your own mind that makes it a jumpscare more than anything.

I keep coming back to this, I watch streams in my downtime--simply because every round is unique.  The appeal is in watching what others do when the flight instinct kicks in, which makes it very humorous to watch.  Despite not having some vast double-digit number of maps or supplies, each round will always be different.  You can learn the maps all you want, you're still going to get fucked as the difficulty levels are unlocked.  Being too aggressive or even too slow is punishing but not unforgiving, and seeing how fast the few devs that run it have put out bug fixes, you're rarely going to die due to a glitch--only your own mistakes.

The devs have been extremely open-book with the booming community, the transparency as to what they want to add, what they're working on, listening to feedback and asking for suggestions from those who love the game to help form the future of it.  And the community is hyped to help, as well as being one of the nicest gaming communities I've ever had the pleasure of perusing on Discord.  Even the memes are lit.

Phasmophobia is genuinely a gem that was muchly needed in this genre.  I actively look forward to its future.
This game is so fun! Little glitches here and there but so worth it!

I saw streamers were playing this game on Twitch and I didn't even know what this game was, well I didn't watch them play it cause I didn't want any spoilers so I stayed away.   A couple weeks later I decided to go onto steam and check this game out for myself and see what it was all about.  I saw the screen shots and didn't really watch the trailer cause, again, spoilers.   I wanted to play this game in VR cause I'm getting a new VR headset soon, but I said screw it and bought the game.   At first a couple times I didn't even know how this game played, but soon I got to know it better.   This game isn't like any other indie horror you'd find with cheap jump scares that just pop out at you and try to make you jump.  This game literally has a computer AI that knows where you are at all times and if angered will attack you.  This game has Voice Recognition so, the game knows you're talking to it and will respond accordingly to what your'e saying.   It's very creepy cause the Ghost knows who you are.  Not a lot of horror games do this and they just focus on making you jump constantly without any real suspension, and build up to the fear aspect.  This game does a real good job of making you feel afraid and want to get out.  With the Spirit box, you can ask the Ghost where they are, how old are they, basically anything and they will respond some of the times.   Not every ghost will respond to you.  It seems like everything is random for events.  The Developer is only 1 man working on this game with constant updates to make his game a lot better for his community, unlike most Developers who could care less about their people and just give up on their game and leave it to die off.  I 100% recommend to those who want a real horror game with actual fear aspect to it, and not some BS pop in your face multiple times garbage.  For the price it's at, it's definitely worth your money. It is Early Access, so expect bugs and weird things that shouldn't be there. But again, the Dev is constantly working on updates for a much better experience.  I kid you not, you will find this game scary, even to the gamer's that know what is and is not scary will get scared.

Here are a list of things you should do before playing
1. Check your keybinds! 
2. Set up the voice recognition (you need to make sure your mic works in game in order to talk to ghosts)
3. Do the tutorial, learn how to play from others, etc. because this game is somewhat difficult to play without doing any of those
4. Git gud

Pros:
* Good core gameplay loop
* Progression, the game gets harder as you get more experienced and you can afford better tools to help you on your endevors
* Easily able to develop future maps and ghosts as the game feels very modular in the sense that all of the game play revolves around 1 map + 1 ghost that can be interchanged.

Cons. nit picking:
* The proximity and radio chat is good addition to the game, however it needs some more development as mic quality drops significantly compared to using something like discord and it's clear that data packets get lost on transmission.
* Animations, probably the most rough looking part of the game is the animations of characters and their models, this is something that's secondary to the core gameplay and can be improved at a later date.

All in all, I'd be willing to pay double the amount this game has been listed and look forward to future updates

This game is really fun, but it depends on the group you are with. Finding those groups is the issue. There is no automatic matchmaking, so it is best played with friends. When playing with random people, you may have to spend some time looking for a full lobby with people actually using their microphones. That in itself is hard. Also, if you are just starting out, finding lobbies with lower level hosts can be difficult too. 

Animations could use some work too. While they are comedic with their Chinese contortionist shet, it takes away from the immersive atmosphere. Also, pressing shift to run is more like pressing shift to slightly walk faster. While I can understand the horror aspect of having an unstoppable force chase you in either a small or a gigantic map, I am pretty sure that the majority of people find it inconvenient or frustrating how slow the pace is. It is funny though.

It would also be helpful to have name tags or something, not like the ones that float above your head but maybe a sticker on each character's shirt or something instead to make communication easier. 

When hiding or just opening doors in general, I think it would be best to have it just one click to open and close because many people struggle at first with dragging it open and still do especially when panicking and frantically trying to open the door lol. 

When it comes to equipment slots, I think that there should be a display. With the microphones, an optional display for how loud your voice is in game would be helpful too. Pricing wise for tools, I think it should be reworked because it looks heavily inflated. $15 for a candle. It better be from Bath & Bodyworks, haha. Perhaps dowsing rods could be added too. Just a few minor notes. 

The graphics in this game are pretty good. There are many options for shadows and reflections. The props and objects are very detailed. The mirrors however, do not reflect. In the base, I think it could use a little more trees and houses to make it feel more like a neighborhood. Slightly clipping through the truck and the plywood walls, you can see how it induces kenophobia. Perhaps having a physical store neaby so you can leave the base would be more immersive. There could be more physics with character models too. Clothes moving, shading, blinking, visual representation of losing sanity, etc. Changeable and or seasonal attire would be a great way to add more character to the game as well as receive more support and funding for development.

Overall, I love the direction this game is going because it is very unique, but needs quite some more polishing. I hope the developers read and consider what I have to say, and I cannot wait for the next installment. Good luck.

Review: [spoiler] I've played the game for almost a good solid 24 hours and the game play is amazing. I personally recommend you get the game! [/spoiler]

Decided to try out Asylum map because yay bigger maps right?! WRONG! Hubby and I spent entirely too long trying to locate this stupid ghost. By the time we figure out it is literally encompassing the entirety of the hallways as they all connect, we are already at 0 sanity. We continue to try and pin point the exact spot in the hall it seems to be staying in, all while hiding for our lives when it comes for us every 30 seconds. We find the spot, but my husband decides he has too much to live for, so he dips out and is sitting safe in the truck. He gets to comfortably watch as I scramble to keep the power on, move all the equipment and figure out what it is all while still hiding every 20 seconds. Ghost finally kills me and we make a guess. We guessed wrong. Oni was too strong that day haha

10/10 though and would not trade that experience for anything. It was so stressful and tense that I want to go back to Asylum just to relive that experience again.
