TL;DR - Great game, pretty simple at this point but should still provide hours of fun with a semi-randomized location and ghost each round. A good experience for folks (like me) who love horror, but are easily spooked. Provides a unique balance of investigative mechanics with moments of intense peril. While there are definitely some issues with the game, it's in early access and many of the flaws add to the charm. Give this one a shot and support the devs!

Having written only 1 other review (for a community badge) after a decade of buying games on Steam, believe me when I say this one is worth every penny of its $13.99 price tag. It's an absolute to blast and an extremely innovative take on the survival(?) horror genre. If you're like me and spook easy, but love to be scared, this is the game for you. While there is definitely a survival component, your goal is to observe, record, and identify various types of dangerous spirits that haunt a variety of classic found footage and ghost hunt locales.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
- Dislike spending the whole game running for your life, but love horror/the occult/found footage? Spend your time running tests and deducing what is haunting that house! You have variety of tools and items at your disposal such as EMF readers, night vision cameras, thermometers, spirit boxes, etc.
- Get spooked? Head back to your trusty ghost hunting van and take a breather. Check the cameras for ghost orbs, monitor the ghost activity readings, guide your friends around with the digital map. It's great to have a safe zone to cool off after you've seen a bloody infant charging out of the master bedroom at you. 
- The atmosphere of this game is incredible. While there are still jump scares, 90% of the horror is the incredible tension building: lights flicker, doors close on their own, objects are thrown across the room, spirits will talk and interact with your group. 
- Speaking of talking... the voice recognition component may sound super cheesy, but it's an awesome part of the experience. Getting a response to certain phrases is super unnerving and you can pretend like you totally aren't ******** yourself while howling "Doooooorooothy Joohnsoon, wheeerree are youuuu?!". Everyone will think you're super macho and Dorothy will appreciate your concern.
- This game has barely been out for 2 weeks, it's still in early access. While I've always been wary of the whole "buy before it's ready" concept, this the first time I've genuinely felt that the cost of the game will definitely be put right back into it. If it's this fun already, I can't imagine how great it will be with even more polish and QoL improvements.

[h1]The Neutral[/h1]
- On the topic of polish, the character models for your ghost hunting crew are laughably bad. Any time you bend over or look upwards you're basically bending 180 degrees at the waist and rushing head or pelvis first into whichever direction you're heading. While some will probably say it's "immersion breaking", it adds to the charm at this point and the comedic relief is often appreciated after a particularly stressful ghost event. 
- Currently, the only game type is to "identify" the ghost. You go in, figure out where the ghost is, what it responds to, capture some evidence, and get the heck out. It's fairly straightforward, but with a random ghost type spawning each round you'll definitely be kept on your toes for awhile. Additionally, the locations seem fairly limited at this point, but again the random ghost and randomized "haunt" room make each round feel unique and just as terrifying as previous rounds.
- This game can be played both in VR and on a regular desktop. However, it seems like VR players definitely get an edge by being able to turn on certain tools, like EMF readers, and clip them to their belts to operate them hands free. While this an obvious disadvantage for desktop players, it's great that the game is adding cool details for VR (though I'm a desktop player and not certain I could handle VR).

[h1]The Not so Good[/h1]
- I hate to say bad, the game is in early access and the devs are clearly working to improve things. The tutorial for the game isn't great. While you're given an introduction to a few of the basic tools, it doesn't cover many of them and often times the correct way to use a tool isn't super obvious (looking at you smudge sticks). You'll probably want to read some guides after completely the tutorial, without going to far as to spoil the experience of learning the ghost hunting mechanics. It's a difficult balance that I hope the devs will be able to sort out soon.
- On the same note, many of the mechanics are pretty unclear at this point, but the devs have been very open and helpful in figuring out how things work and explaining how they plan to improve on things in the future. 
- I'm not sure this game would be great alone. While I'm certain some out there will enjoy the high intensity of being alone in the dark with a murderous ghost, the vast majority of my fun has coming from being in group and working together to solve the mystery of the unidentified ghost. 

An easy 10/10, especially heading into October. Turn off the lights, slap on your headphones, call up your pals, and hop in the van, there's a ghost that needs photographing!

Definitely scuffed and has some issues (should give us the option to invite via steam friend list) and suffers from some very obvious amateur visuals like ghosts and human models looking like they were originally SecondLife assets but it's a VERY unique premise. If you play with 3 other people it's a helluva time figuring out the game mechanics, having one person stay in the van and share intel while the other 3 goad the ghost to come out, often cracking jokes and trying to upset it before the ghost shows itself and everyone gets genuinely scared. Really great balanced.

I could see this being improved with character customization, higher-quality models (the environments are fine but the ghosts and humans need work as mentioned) but I'm looking forward to seeing what new content this guy comes up with.

Absolutely goddamn in love with this game. I'm slightly (very) biased, I love ghost lore and have hunted them back in college.

So you're hunting ghosts, not removing them. Some unlucky bastards get to actually banish the thing you riled up, and possibly fed, afterwards. There is a selection of different maps that your team can investigate, several houses of varying sizes, and larger facilities like a high school and, best of all, an abandoned insane asylum.

You outfit your guys with equipment like flashlights, video and still cameras, thermometers, and eventually motion sensors or head-mounted Go-Pro style cameras. Those are the best for creating found footage movie action at somebody's expense. There's a short window wherein the ghost cannot harm you and you need to find its location and evidence to identity it.

Welcome to hell, people.

The game doesn't rely on jump scares, the ghost isn't regularly jumping out in your face and screaming. It's all tension in the dark. Wandering around, trying to coordinate with your team and watching for signs of the haunting; taps being run, doors slamming, car alarms and radios going off. Once you've found the central hotspot you need to figure out what you're dealing with; in the houses this can be fairly easy. Enjoy the multiple floors and many, many rooms in the larger sites.

Voice communications are required. There is no in-game typed chat and one piece of equipment requires you to speak to the ghost; ask it questions like "are you here" or "can you turn on the lights" to help gather proof you need, or call its name to goad it to action.

One player has the option of remaining within the truck where they're safe and armed with tools to help the party; a video display to spot ghost orbs or watch the others' progress, a meter for how active the ghost is, the map of the building. Having the right gear to search effectively is going to be key, because you can leave a notebook for the ghost to write in anywhere, but it's not going to help you find it in the first place. A thermometer isn't necessary if the ghost lowers the temperature to freezing with its presence, you can see your breath, but it can help narrow down the search area.

Your primary objective is to identity the ghost but the real money is in the secondary ones: finding other occult objects like ouija boards or voodoo dolls, getting photos of the ghost, or having specific instrument recordings. Good photos are a money maker.

Of course the ghost is hostile. Knowing what you're up against can save your live; some fear the crucifix, others don't produce footsteps, one will actually keep the lights on because it draws power from the electrical grid. Identifying the ghost can be very difficult and there is a learning curve for the devices and what might be false readings, completely ineffective, or proper proof. But the sooner you do it, the safer you'll be for collecting secondaries.

And yeah, it's scary as hell for the thing to suddenly whisper in your ear. To hear it stomping down the hall in pursuit. To catch glimpses of it as you're snapping pictures and backpedaling. How about asking if it's nearby and just having an invisible voice reply "YES"? Or finding that it locked the exit, trapping you with it?

It's in early access and I'm hoping they don't drop the ball and call development quits after a few weeks of popularity. There's a number of quality of life issues they can address and a lot they can expand upon with the premise; more ghosts, equipment, or maps. Horrible new death animations. Maybe even a mode where you play the suckers trying to get the yurei who ate the interns out of the abandoned high school.

You ever pooped your pants hiding in a closet while a faceless child is chasing you because you said its name too many times? If not, then BOY HOWDY is this in interesting experience. On desktop, it's scary (and I don't scare easily), but in VR, it's a test of your bladder's ability to avoid evacuating.

Group up with friends and work together (with crossplay between VR and desktop) to identify the ghost, gather evidence of the haunting for the paranormal community, and barely make gas money for your time! Learn the Lord's Prayer, say your Hail Marys and wield that Crucifix like it's a massive sword, because these ghosts won't go without a fight.

The VR models are a little wonky (it IS Early Access, after all), and the physics can be a little strange, but with random map creation, new objectives, and a randomly selected spirits (from a list of 10 at time of writing this), you'll have to learn quickly or die trying. Don't stand in the dark. Group up, and make sure you keep an eye on your sanity and the ghost's strength. Maybe all those viewings of Ghostbusters is gonna pay off?

A bit of context first;

I'm a total chicken pansy when it comes to just about anything spooky and I generally avoid early access horror games like the plague, both for their inherent spook factor and their notorious track record of generally being quite ass.

With that being said, this game is fantastic. There's so much love and care put into this product to make it an overwhelmingly enjoyable and tense experience. From things like switching between local and global voice chat to communicate effectively (and your radio being cut off when the ghostie's comin' for ya) to the multitude of gadgets and gizmos that you use to track down all different manners of supernatural entities from your basic spirit or poltergeist to something as aggressive as an oni.

One of my favourite things about this game is how it manufactures and constitutes so many organic scary moments that you can share with your friends and endure together. Speaking of "friends", definitely find some people to play this with. (not just because it's really scary on your own, but it's just a blast with a full team)

Another thing I really like about this game is the inclusion of voice recognition. Even when you're not on either of the voice chat channels, the ghost can still hear you and will actually respond to things you say, like if you tell them to "close a door" they might actually close a door and send your heart into orbit.

I just highly recommend this title. It's a lot of fun, endlessly replayable, and dirt cheap.

If you're made of sterner stuff or know people who are, you definitely gave to give it a try.

I can say I was a little hesitant at first, but the game has won me over. Friends leaving me behind, shrieking down the hall as a small child with a lamprey face tries to murder us, I've had it more often enough where everyone goes "we'll protect you" and watch the ghost B-line straight for me. 10/10 would recommend co-op spirit murder game.

Though some minor technical difficulties with sound and optimization, this game is incredibly fun to play with friends. Tension tends to build up nice and slow as you explore each location and when the hunt is on, run.

The only scary VR game I've played honestly. Even though I know how to not die, the randomness really makes you question yourself. Very rewarding to get the ghost type correct. One big con is that the voice recognition does not feel reliable at all and I need to repeat the ghost's name countless times before I can confirm the ghost type.

While there exists a few bugs that would need to be patched out, as a whole the game is very enjoyable. The use of your mic in game for communications is brilliant in how it can be used for and against you. The game is still in development but don't let that scare you as it is still much more enjoyable than some finished and released games. I very much look forward to seeing it completed

Only review I've ever made. This is the greatest horror game to play with your friends. The ghost are genuinely scary and the randomization means you will almost never get the same ghost hunt. The random scenarios also add to the thrilling aspects of the game because you never know what to expect from each ghost. Co-op works well even with as low as two players and bringing in more only makes the game more fun. Local proximity chat combined with a separate global chat (that is disguised as a walkie talkie) make it really easy to be immersed in, and even lost in, this amazing game. The biggest downside is that the ghosts don't often follow their journal entries making the entries almost pointless. If you like spooky games you can play with your friends, this is an amazing game and fills a gap we have needed in the horror genre for a long time.

The game has a steep learning curve due to the lackluster tutorial, but the non-violent ghost will help you learn the capabilities of each item with effort. It has great replayability and I feel like there is something new to learn in every haunting. For a short review the game is great for the price: especially considering this game was made by one man. 

The pros: 
This game, especially in the beginning, makes the player figure out a lot of things for themselves. Giving major satisfaction when the player figures out a new tool or way of communicating with the ghost. 
Another great aspect is the voice recognition! There is a whole list of phrases and words that the ghost can interact with you can look up the entire list but it’s better to figure them out for yourself! For example saying “I’m scared” actually triggers the ghost in game to do scary stuff. S P O O K Y
Another great thing this game provides is the major satisfaction of investigating correctly every single time we get the right ghost it gives you a sense of pride! Go on try it for yourself!
I also love the local and global voice chat that is offered. 
Now like I said all in all the game is great and there are way more good stuff I could go over but I have to be honest about the negative side of things as well

Cons
The game can get repetitive. Especially after completing a good amount of missions. By the time you are lvl 15-20 you are (in most games with a competent team) can get in and out before things get spooky. 
Another thing that is super frustrating and at times game breaking is an audio bug that seems to happen pretty regularly. I would say 30% of all games has a chance for either you or a teammate or in some cases multiple teammates to not be able to hear one another. It is super frustrating and makes the game unplayable for that round. Hopefully this is fixed soon. 
Another small thing is that some items are useless to non-VR players. For example you cannot light a candle unless you are in vr or unless you hold the candle and another desktop user lights it for you. As you will find out in the game VR players have a major advantage.
One major reason after about level 20 you start to feel the game getting repetitive is because the ghost is locked to a single room, yes they can hunt and kill you in another room but when they are not hunting they are pretty much stuck in that room which is why it makes it so easy to find that room get all the info and leave before the hunt can even begin. The game would feel much more immersive if clues were spread out throughout the entire house rather than just one room. 
Some objectives are unclearable, for instance if the ghost isn’t “confined in a bathroom” then there will never be a dirty sink to take a picture of so no bonus money. 
It does seem like there are more common ghost and so you see those ghost way more often while about half of the ghost are never seen. (This could just be my experience)
When you are dead you are only an observer if they could make it to where you could either A. Watch as the ghost hunts your teammates or B. Somehow communicate through the spirit box or a oiujia board to communicate with your teammates would add a level of immersion that would be amazing rather than just being an observer. 

With all this being said it is in early development, and hopefully the creator is willing to hire others to make this game become something truly amazing with updates! I would say at the state the game is still playable and super fun! Especially for only $15 dollars so give it a try!

Definitely not recommended. I was waiting for this game to be scary or atleast atmospheric but in fact it was just absolutely boring. Tons of walking around in the houses with a dimly lit flashlight while absolutely nothing is happening. When I finally did reach the ghost, I used the methods given to me in a tutorial and left the area. I got my "victory" and went on to the next one and to the next one... I was only wishing for this game to get better once the difficulty gets more challenging, but in 4 hours I was still stuck at amateur level even though I did most of the tasks perfectly. I refuse to believe that I am the only one that is not scared of completely normal empty houses. 

But I can recommend this game to people who think that slenderman and zombie movies are absolutely horrifying. This type of "horror" is just not doing anything for me. I gave this game too big of an opportunity 
and now I can't even refund this. 

PS. It was completely my own fault that I bought this game, I didn't read any reviews or watch any videos, I should've.
PPS. I just now noticed that this is an early access game. But that's not really an excuse for a poor idea of a horror game.
Playing this game with your boys is a pure blast. Hope for a lot more content in the near future!

Considering the game is still "Early Access" the only con's for me is the run speed and the body flashlight. This game is scary, not the jumpscares and loud noises so it spooks you kind of scary, but like the atmospheric, walking straight in the dark, feel like there is something constantly around you kind of scary.
You are not a fighter in this game, there is no way you can do to beat the ghost, you can slow them down, you can run, you can hide, or even escape, but there is no way you can say that you are absolutely safe once you step in the house. 

I have to say, though I don't play horror games a lot, I can really tell that this is once of the best co-op horror ever existed, from the game playstyle, to the audio, they all send chills down your spine. The ghost is in the house, you know it, but you have to walk in, cross your fingers you can walk out, alive, that is.

The game certainly has its flaw, it is early access after all. The game is pretty linear, I'll say, meaning you'll start to get used to it after a few matches. And because there isn't really like some very delicately designed "spook-spot", some people may not even find this game scary (though personally I have to ready an extra pair of pants playing each match). 

At the end of the day, I'm not a professional game reviewer, and I've only played like 7 hours when writing this. I personally do absolutely enjoy and recommend this game, I am excited to  see what the developer plan to do with the game in the future.

Glad it's still in Early Access, this game has the foundations to be the best horror out there, with the main innovation being voice recognition. 

Plays a bit like the "Big Oil (day 2)" Heist from Payday 2, except with the shooting replaced with the eeriness of a Slenderman-like ghost lurking around.

This game shines in pressure scenarios. During a Ghosts hunting period, a "survive or die" encounter in late game, the intensity builds up as the Ghost becomes more active. Your teammate calls out "The lights are flashing upstairs" or "the motion sensors gone off", and you desperately try into pre-empt the Hunt and evade death. 

So under pressure you quickly check to see if there are closets you can hide in, there's none, so since you know your ghost hunts isolated players you desperately attempt to group up with your teammates. 

It's in these intense moments where I've had the most fun, though there was a learning curve to get there.

IMPORTANT: Before you even think of buying the game. You NEED a mic to play properly. Solo or in group it doesn't matter. You must be willing to let the game hear your screams and attempts at communication with the ghost and while you play with others communication is A MUST HAVE. Either that or you must have friends who are willing to work around your lack of communication and can fill in the talking role, but definitely wouldn't recommend trying that with randoms.

While the game does a great job of staying scary and engaging even after you start understanding the mechanics I probably had more laughs out of it (while in multiplayer) instead as this game takes the "best" out of everyone.

I have never before experienced having a need to shout insults at the ghosts into the entrance of the house along with the gang just to run away crying as soon as the ghost appears. Or witnessing all those attempts at pulling out people out of the truck just for them to walk along the walls while staring at a floor only and too scared to look anywhere else. Or to see those brave souls scream and sob their way out of the building just few seconds after putting a brave face on.

If you can VR this 100% do it although some of my friends reported getting sick easily in it without fiddling around in the locomotion settings first. I encountered no problems.

Very sturdy for fresh Early Access release and devs seem to do a good job so far as well.

TIP: Covering your face with hands while standing in a corner and pretending you are not aware of the existence of now chasing you ghost, surprisingly does not keep you safe. Yet almost everyone seems to do it... including myself.

I'm very hopeful for the future of this game, but again there are plenty of bugs and I can't in good faith recommend a game with this many bugs right now. I like the idea of the game and it looks fun, however, it is extremely difficult to actually play the game and it was very frustrating trying to figure out the basic functions of the game without having to look up tutorials for the tutorial. 

The tutorial is terrible and doesn't properly explain or show you how to play the game at all. It would be beneficial to have a set room with the ghost in it and maybe an outline of where to out the camera and book etc so the player can get a general idea of what they're supposed to do. It took me 20 minutes to figure out just how to put an item down without throwing it, and the tutorial controls mention nothing about what left mouse button is for despite it having many functions in the game, such as opening doors and interacting with placed items. 

The mechanics are clunky and don't seem to work well at all. Voice chat did not work at all for myself or some friends I was playing with and we could not hear our teammates. Its not well explained how to use the voice feature for the radio or anything, does the static mean something? Are those voices on the radio, the glitched VC or is it the ambient ghost? Who knows! I certainly don't! 

I also find it frustrating that you can't play the game with less than 4 people in a private lobby, which makes it difficult to play the game as well, since we spent so much time trying to find a lobby we could all be in. We couldn't start our own as people kept leaving instantly. I also noticed that the part where you add things to your inventory doesn't actually display how many of the items you have in the list, which was strange. 

I also think it would also be good if there was some icon/UI feature that displayed what you have in your inventory/how many things you have in your inventory so you know how much you can carry. The torch was also weird- it worked through 'T' without one in my inventory, but later 'T' stopped working until I had the item in my inventory. Not really sure what was going on there. 

The sound effects are very good and the spooky ambiance is very nice and the footsteps have made me jump a few times, but at the moment that's about the only good thing I can say for the game. Maybe I will rebuy this game at a later date when issues are fixed and how to play the game is much more clear and the controls/game mechanics are explained properly.

You're tasked with investigating a house that has been reported with paranormal events, you and 3 other friends go inside and using your tools you find a spot with a freezing temperature, you setup the spot with cameras, writing book, spirit box and EMF Reader. The ghost seems to only show up to people who are alone, so you're by yourself in a basement. You use the spirit box to ask if there is anyone there. The lights flicker and die out, the EMF Reader spikes, you look down...it wrote something on the book "Leave or Die" you scurry back upstairs as you're nearly out the door it closes and a shadowy figure appears before you, it slowly walks toward, your friends on the outside trying to get the main door open, the other watches your body collapse on the floor, the lights come back, and the main door is unlocked, and there standing in the hallway is you collapsed.

TLDR: I recommend this game, my first playthroughs was a blast, finding how each tool worked and finding different type of ghosts and how they react differently, it has been a fun experience with friends. I hope the devs continue with updates, giving us new houses and buildings and new ghosts. Keep up the good work!

In short, fun and surprisingly creepy/terrifying/unnerving. Already feels like a complete game even though it was just brought to early access not that long ago. The game does have a few crashing after completing a game and a voice bugs when sometimes joining rooms, but other then being annoying these bugs don't cause a loss of rewards or equipment.

A brief overview of a round's experience is below. Note: On difficulties above Amateur, you lose all equipment you brought with you on a mission if you get killed. This can be costly and requires numerous rounds to build up the cash to buy it all again, but isn't so bad that it would cause rage quitting. It just adds spice to the game.

Me and three of my friends, being the professionals that we are, decided to tackle a ghost at an Asylum. This not being our first rodeo, we came fully stocked with all the gear a ghost hunter could ever need, most of the equipment being purchased by me. We broke up as individuals to quickly locate the ghost and after a few minutes we determined that the haunting was originating from the kitchen.

We quickly converged on the location and setup all our instruments to determine what we were dealing with. I retreated to the safety of the truck to coordinate the investigation and give directions to a member of ours that was lost in the basement. After some quick research we knew what we were dealing with and everyone met back at the truck. At this point, we had burned through our sanity pills and everyone's sanity was dangerously low, except mine, since I'd been in the truck safe and sound. 

We had one mission left, get a picture of the ghost. We had every precaution in place and my sanity was the only one high enough to safely go back in. So I decided to go anger the ghost to show itself and snap a pic so we could get out of there. What's the worst that could happen...

I go into the kitchen, with my three companions, bravely hiding in the truck and watching me through multiple cameras. In the kitchen with my camera ready, I proceed to call out the ghosts name and insult it's entire family back several generations. After all, I'm safe, it won't hunt me, no danger here. Right as soon as a call it a b**** and demand it give me a photo op, my radio goes dead and my flashlight starts flickering, which means the ghost is on the hunt and is going after the only person in the asylum, me.

I do the manly thing and immediately panic, being in it's room, quite possibly the worst room to be in on the planet at the moment. I don't see the ghost, so I start running towards the dinning room, a few steps that way, I think, wait, what if it is coming from the dinning room. The kitchen is near the front door, I can just run that way and get out. I spin around and sprint across the kitchen to head out the other exit. It is at this point I remember that the front doors will have slammed shut and be locked while the ghost is hunting. It is also at this point that I hear loud footsteps behind me getting closer.

Running out into the hall I dive into the first room I see, which happens to be a small bathroom. I slam the door and proceed to huddle behind my new porcelain friend and praying the ghost doesn't find me. The footsteps continue to get louder until I hear them stop just outside the door I'm cowering behind. I then hear what sounds like claws running across the wood of the door very slowly. After about another 20 seconds of this, the hunt stops and I promptly flee from the building and dive into the truck.

We all decide as a group that we don't need the extra money for a picture of the ghost and leave. It was totally worth it.

My name is Zak Bagans. I've never believed in ghosts until I came face to face with one. So I set out on a quest to capture what I once saw onto video....With no big camera crews following us around, I am joined only by my fellow investigator Nick Groff and our equipment tech Aaron Goodwin. The three of us will travel to the some of most highly active paranormal locations, where we will spend an entire night, being locked down from dusk until dawn....Raw...Extreme...These are our Ghost Adventures.
So much fun.

Finally a horror game in this day and age that is good and a lot of fun.
It doesn't revolve around jumpscares or huge amounts of gore.
The specters are based on lore from real encounters from different cultures over time.
The equipment is what paranormal investigators really use when they ghost hunt.
Each experience is a new one and can have lots of laughs and lots of scares.

I only recommend a few things to spark this up to make this a Classic for times to come:
- Different deaths for players from the many specters. 
- The kills can be seen by other players.
- The ghosts can be seen through reflections, maybe have a randomly generated body/face each lobby, and can pop up outside in the van sometimes
- hallucinations from panic
- FRIENDLY SPIRITS (but very rare, and can do fun/funny stuff) 
- Actual dispersion of the specters (like exorcisms and cleansing)
- P O S E S S I O N and to be able to hunt down others.
- More missions than just getting objectives to make it more difficult
- Players can be a specter in a game mode
- Outside maps (woods, playgrounds, city streets)

I know it's a lot to ask for but this is just chock full of potential and it's already a blast.

These aren't criticisms but things that can be added on. THE WORLD IS YOUR OYSTER. You're giving us a damn good game I've wanted since forever.

WHY IS THIS GAME SO FUN?!

I seriously have no idea. The idea is simple. You and up to three of your friends (or random people via a matchmaking function) are paranormal investigators. You're at a location to discover what type of ghost is haunting the location. You use devices such as an EMF, a ghost writing book, temperature gauge, and so on to determine what type of ghost it is. You try to take pictures of it, and other things, to get money to buy new equipment.

Oh yeah, and you try not to die.

If the ghost gets angry enough, it'll try to murder you. It will also throw things around, leave behind fingerprints, turn off the lights, cut out your radio, and in general just mess with you. 

It's such a simple concept, but it works. It works well. There's some spoopiness in it, and some jump scares, but it's more atmospheric than jump-scarey. I've screamed like a little girl many times, even when I know the ghost is hunting me.

WHY IS THIS GAME SO FUN? I don't know, but it is.

It was first terrifying but became a sweet relief to the hell i just went through. I watched from the front door as my friend scurried away like a rat and zoomed out of there. 10/10 would poop my pants again.

It is scary game, but with your friends it makes playing fun and exciting. I didn't even get through the tutorial alone that how scared I was. But when your with friends it's like exploring graveyards (irl) as kids with flash lights trying to ghost hunt.

The game is 4 player coop, the object is to figure out what type of ghost is haunting the place. You buy equipment to help you narrow down the list of signs that ghost give off, like cold breath, finger prints, white noise chatter, and such.

There are lots of ghosts in the game like demons, wraiths, phantoms, jins, banshee, poltergeist and so forth. The places you go are chosen at start of mission, but the ghost is random every time and so is the room or location inside the place is haunted. Like you can play same map, but get a different ghost haunting in a different room. Because there is a wide variety of ghost and some ghost share similar signs, but every ghost has a particular thing they do.

The game uses your mic to talk to the spirit. The game knows a variety of phrases, like saying the ghost name, or a phrase "hello" "who are you" "show your self" "say something" just say what comes to mind as if you are talking to a spirit and want that spirit to interact with you.

Lots of replay value here. Great game to play with friends. I suggest mics in game. Make sure you know which key is push to talk. There are 2 push to talk keys. Once is proxy chat, and other is Walkie-Talkie global.

This game works with VR and NON-VR. Don't matter if VR or not, you can still play together.

As time dragged on higher and higher paranormal levels were being detected, My friend, inside the house, was speaking to the ghost as a level 10 spike occurred. I immediately called to him and told him to get out. He grabbed the camera and started running down the stairs as his light began to flicker. Then, the camera drops. Bout shit myself.

My review to this game: 

This game, developed by only two people, is a really really great VR Horror and Non VR Horror game. Of course, because it's "only" two developers at this game, this game feels on some parts unpolished. Like the animations are kinda weird or the Multiplayer models in Desktop Mode look kinda janky. But this will improve with time. 
This game got good attention from youtubers and I think it deserves it. 

This game feels crazy good in VR. Playing this in VR is way more scarier because of the graphics this game has and the sound design. With VR you dont have the janky animations and you feel like you are the youtubers you watch for Abandon Horror investigating or investigating houses because people told you that their house is haunted - And hell, it is. 
The voice detecting in this game is great. You have to talk to the ghost to make it aggressive or to get answeres on the Spirit Box. 
The buildings are interesting and with increasing level you get bigger places, I dare to walk into. 
And the best of all: You can play it in Co-Op and using the ingame voice function and the walkie Talkie it's just freaking amazing. 

Defintily a must have for VR users, and definitly a must have for people that are into this stuff. 

People who dislike such kind of stuff will not be pleased in this game. When you search something like an Outlast Horror Game or something with great story, this isnt your game, but maybe it will. 
They have a Discord and a Roadmap, and from what I see on their discord, the developer are quite talkative with the Community. hence I think this game will get a story at some point. 

Overall - Phasmophobia a game developed by just two people - feels like there is a small team behind it. Yes, animations are janky, yes the player models look kinda weird, but the gameplay, graphics and sound design feels so polished that this makes up for it. 
This game for me is just plain amazing.
I'm scaredy boi. Now I can be scaredy boi with my other bois.

At first, I thought that this would be a game that either my friends and I wouldn't play more than once, or it would be a game we would be too scared to play but I was wrong. 

Positive:
The game has this good game play loop that feels rewarding once you actually complete the contract and guess the right ghost and keeps you interested the whole match with the ghosts AI kind of teasing you along and giving you clues. I also appreciate the scary level of the game because it doesn't have jump scares or really any cheap thrills it's more wanting you to fear the unknown because everything is unknown when you start the match, I mean the maps are the same but you never know what is going to be there each time and you never know what could be lurking around the corner or hunting you. I think if the game added jump scares and cheap thrills it would really ruin the gameplay because then you would be going into the maps just to have something spook you for 20 mins plus but for right now (I will update my review if it changes) the ghost will really mainly play with you until you piss it off and really make you fear it to the point when you see it there is a good chance you will freeze up out of just terror.

Negative: 
I honestly don’t have many issues with the AI but the difference between an amateur mission and a professional mission is a little staggering and what I mean by that is in professional if you are not in and out and a little lucky you will most likely lose at least two players, but granted my group and I could become better with more practice hopefully. This isn’t that big of grip yet but I do hope the add more medium to small sized maps semi quickly, I know it’s a small dev team but the large maps are a bit too much sometimes so my group and most Randoms agree the smaller maps are more fun. 

Community:
(I will update this category if my opinion changes) I am very pleased with the community so far I have not run into anyone that is overly critical and mean really about anything and in a game that can get fairly scary I think it is important. Multiple times I have been very scared and it’s was hard for me to want to get out of locker or something and every time I admitted that I needed someone to come and help me get out of the house they always say yes and come to help. Most higher-level players I have seen are helpful to newer players and make sure that they don’t get roasted by the ghost.

For real this game is probably the only horror game that actually scares me even the slightest in recent memory. It has the fear of the unknown when you start playing, the perfect ambiance to set up some scary moments involving the ghosts, subtle build up with small things that get you afraid (ie. the spirit box, flashing lights, sounds, emf readings), all leading to the hunts which lets you, most likely, see the ghost your dealing with in its physical form for the first time. Its all so well blended that after buying this game about a week a go, I've been playing everyday with friends and haven't really gotten tired of it.

Oh yeah and its actually scary the more people you have, having someone monitoring the cameras while 3 of you are walking through the area to finally have someone notice something off is pretty spoopy if I do say so myself. Its one of the few horror games that does multiplayer right.

The bugs are pretty prevalent right now but the developer has been actively putting out updates to fix them are coming about every day or so, which is pretty amazing. The discord is very helpful in finding out problems and getting them to the developer. Most of the bugs that are fairly game breaking have gotten patched from what I've seen but there is still plenty since its in early access and actively being developed so expect somethings to get broken every once in a while.

The game is a bit jank with the DREADFULLY slow movement speed, and the non-vr being somewhat on the limited side in terms of positioning of cameras and such. Also I do recommend VR if you have it because well, it just makes the game creepier and more off putting (plus you can hold 4 items instead of 3 with the two hands you are blessed with).

All that said the game's really fun, has a great community from what I've seen, is even better with friends, and provides some good scares. Plus its cheap!

NOT THIS IS OBVIOUSLY A PREMATURE REVIEW

This game can be super ambitious if the creators stick to it. 
Pro: Its scary as ever, the creaking floors, the atmosphere, the feeling that something is watching you. This what makes the game.

Con: Nothing major, personally its an easy fix. Me and my friends like to goof so making alot of things interactible would be funny for the soul. Then get insta-terrified when our guards are down.

Hope To See: 
100% GHOST SCARES (The book gives us a rough idea of what different ghost we deal with. Which is good, but I hope to see these ghost become so terrifying after the 1st scare players cant complete the level cause they dont want to go back.)

SANITY WATCH*a literal wrist watch* (So our sanity is important therefore we should have a watch to keep an eye out)

HEALTHBAR*can be in the watch too* (I think it'll be nice not to insta-die in most cases rather the ghost becomes violent and the house becomes a death trap like in movies. From locked doors which we need keys to escape or floating objects thrown at the player)

GHOST VARIETY (appearance is important so it's always nice to have ghost look scary as possible, granted the effects they do will do all the work.)

MORE LOCATION VARIETY (Most important by far, location location. House are fine but why limit it there. Motels, Forest, Mansion, Graveyard, Schools, Factories to which plays into the ghost's strength and weakness without having to grind to buy the tool that we might accidently lose)

DLCS NOVELTIES (Im pretty sure you have the tools down but that doesn't mean a person can buy a novelty proton pack from ghostbusters that just does 3 things at once rather than one tool at a time)

DLCS GHOST (This game can be a powerhouse for putting the most feared ghost and entities in it. Slenderman why not, The twins from the shining why not. Pennywise automatic horror why not. Obivious copyright reasons doesnt mean they cant make a renegade version with the same premise)

All and all I love the game and look definitely forward to what's coming

Love love love this game! I end up having nightmares after every time I play but its so worth it. I'm awful with horror games but only way to really progress is to create more activity to anger the ghost by going room to room. So if you just sit in a corner (like I did), while everyone else is doing the work, you're not going to finish the mission as fast. Once I got over the creepiness and fear, the game is really fun. I love the subtle intensity. I love how theres voice interaction and that certain words on communications can trigger the ghost (don't say scared, run, hide, etc.). Not being able to run adds to the thrill as well. If you're marked and being hunted, calling for your teammates on the walkie talkie will not work so your best bet is to hide and turn off your lights. 

The game has a huge emphasis on teamwork and communication. So it is only really fun with the right people. Those who don't share info or say much can make the game boring. So push each other to talk more (chanting the ghosts name, talk to the spirit box, use the ouija board) and when you join a lobby make sure everyone there has a mic. 

My biggest issue though is how buggy (audio and game glitches) the game can be. Right away after loading into Asylum map, I could only hear 1 of the 3 other people. I could hear the click of the walkietalkie being used, I just couldn't hear what they were saying. I have also heard other people complain of this post lobby so its a global in game issue rather than map related. In the same game during the "hunt", I got stuck hiding in a room, and my game crashed. This then caused the entire game to bug out since the game didn't register me leaving, thus continuing the hunt. In hunt mode, the doors to the exit is locked. They tried throwing the crucifix at the ghost and tried standing in front of it to die so maybe the doors would unlock again, but instead the ghost would walk up harmlessly. So my game crashing prevented my team from completing the game (no reward collection) which we lost about an hour of time for. Still def fun tho! Some things I wish they would add:
*More variety of voice lines: When asking whether the ghost is child or an adult to the voicebox, the voice is always a male. Having the voice match the answers (or gender) of the ghost would be nice, such as if the ghost says "child" it'd be cool to hear it in a child's voice rather than a grown man in his 30's. 

*Speed bar for running: The running right now is more of a fast walk than run. I like that I can't run since it adds to the thrill (plus if I'm slow, the ghost is usually slow as well), but I've heard others complain for a faster option to run. Having a speed bar and having to pay attention to how much stamina I have left would be interesting as well. 

*Match history: I wish I could review the stats of a mission. This would include people I've played with (I want to be able to add them in case I crash again), how fast the mission was completed, how many times we've each encountered the ghost, hotspots of our activity vs ghost activity, and what items were used.

A lot of folks are asking me about this game for some reason, so I'm typing up a formal review:

Is it worth it?

the short answer: yes, probablyThe longer answer:
If you have VR it's especially worth it, it's really good quality and a rare thing to find a co-op game that's also scary, particularly good with friends.It's still got quite a lot of the early access jank and it's pretty buggy at times, and definitely could use some additional features to cut down on what I can already forsee turning into a repetitious experience once you "figure out" how it works. For now though, it's already pretty damn solid and even with minimal extra work by the developers it'll be a great game. Even if you don't have VR then it's still worth it, a lot of the atmosphere is taken away when you're not on a headset though
shidded my pants but worth the money

Definitely not perfect, as it stands however, this is how you do a proper horror game. No bullshit jumpscares, just raw atmosphere, creep factor and paranoia. Grab 3 friends and get scared shitless. Fun idea and game, horrible drawbacks ruin the experience.

Too frequent crashes or disconnections completely ruin the game, as all your experience and money is lost. The 15 minutes you spent hunting clues and getting all the objectives is just lost.

Some ghost signs are completely inconsistent. I did 3 matches. 1 involved EMF5 & Ghost Writing, never saw Ghost Orbs, but that's what we missed. 2nd we got all 3 clues. 3rd match in School came down to EMF5 & Ghost Writing. So we needed to check for Ghost Orbs, Fingerprints, or the Spirit Box.

We had the room and I personally scoured the room and area for fingerprints with the blacklight, couldn't find anything. Even after the ghost haunted us, slammed the door, rang the phone, etc. Nothing on windows either. It even appeared, and chased us down the hallway (at lvl 10). Went back to the room, no fingerprints. We went to the truck, and 3 went back with the Spirit Box to check for that and get the last objective (spirit sticks). They were haunted thrice and chased down the hall. My game crashed of course. They returned to the truck and guessed Oni. Nope, Revenant, but we never found any fingerprints after it attacked us 4 times. So we got it wrong, but even then I got nothing due to the crash. After 3 matches I had only $75 bucks.

Audio mic frequently refuses to work for my friends, and has not worked for me at all, meaning I have to use Discord, which takes away a lot from the experience.

I just have a bad taste in my mouth with this game, losing all of my progress due to disconnects sucks, and missing the clue you specifically scoured for sucks.

This game is not bad because it has bugs, it's not bad because I keep getting disconnect, it's not bad because I couldn't figure out the tutorial. I had none of those issues. When a game hits early access, it's usually because the team has a small part of the game done that is extremely well put together, fun and polished. Those are the early access success stories like Slime Rancher, Factorio, Hades. This game has every tell of a game that's never going to be finished. There's so little to almost no quality in the game. This is a game that will end up like The Forest or Thief Simulator, and it looks and feels just like those games too. The mechanics are there and it's fun to explore them with friends, but it's barebones and most of the time is spent wandering around with nothing happening. Even with different ghost types, even with different objectives, once you've seen one you've seen them all. The game follows the same formula every time. As for the quality, there's so many graphical issues you're always looking at something being wrong, the english is broken, and the design choices reek of putting no effort into a unity asset flop. It's not worth your money. It's not worth being early access. It will not be completed.

10/10 game, would betray again.

I expected Phasmophobia to be an asset flip/gmod-horror-map-type deal. That's actually what I thought it was the first two days I played it.

Tonight I learned that's not even close.

Honestly, I really didn't enjoy myself at first. This game was hard to learn, and the tutorial confused me even more. I was thankful that I streamed my first time with this game because a friend and viewer who is familiar with it helped my team out with some basic mechanics. The community is really chill and the dev is active.

I enjoyed what I thought was a bunch of silly jumpscares and random events ... but then I learned there's an actual roaming ghost on the map that you have to track down. For whatever reason I didn't realize that at first, it dramatically changed the game for me. I sincerely thought it was just a "haha, go in, walk around, spooky things happen, someone dies, you guess a ghost, and leave." You're actually dealing with an AI! This game is quite intense (and insanely fun), and I can't wait to play it in VR someday.

It's hard to find a horror game that does atmosphere well nowadays. Phasmophobia nails it. Being hunted is pretty frightening, especially when you're crouched behind a table hoping those footsteps don't come closer to your hiding spot. Several times while on the way out of the location's front doors, the ghost has slammed and locked in one of my teammates' faces. I never relax until I cross that threshold. Even then, I'm still scared out of my mind because I know I'm going to have to go back in.

There's typical early access bugs (getting stuck in things, objects flying, etc) and the controls are a bit clunky, but what's here is VERY cool and shows a lot of promise. The concept works surprisingly well. It's worth keeping an eye on Phasmophobia if you're not yet convinced, but this is a generous price for a pretty thrilling experience with a high replay value!

I concur with what seems to be the consensus of a lot of reviews: Phasmophobia is even better when enjoyed with friends.

Finally, I highly recommend joining the discord. The dev is very active and focused on the game, and the community is quite friendly.

A very fun and scary game with friends. A few minor bugs tho, but can be easily fixed. Closing the door on your friends and scaring them is the funniest part about this game. The price is worth it. Hoping for more content for this game.

Truly the good kind of horror, no cheap jumpscares, no random loud noises or music to make you jump for no meaningful reason, this game manages to scare you through good atmosphere and sound design despite not having very good graphics or animations. The whole thing about solving the puzzles to discover what kind of entity haunts the place you are investigating, the feeling of never truly knowing what you are dealing with and what kind of danger you are in each game, makes this a game that not only manages to be really scary but also very fun at the same time.
Judging by how good the game already is despite how early in development it is only speaks good things about it's future, sure, right now the game might be buggy, kinda ugly, use some default animations, some stock sounds and text to speech voices for some stuff, which can be quite off putting when you are immersed in the atmosphere, but that's to be expected of a game so early in development, but when the developers finish polishing this rough diamond I can only expect it to be one of the best and most popular horror/puzzle co-op games out there.

What I would personally like to see later on is attention to detail such as more animations and effects, different models for different kinds of ghosts, age of ghosts(of course a child ghost and an old man ghost won't look the same), and genders of ghosts as right now all types of ghosts can have both male and female names, (without of course making them too unique so players can't just tell which kind of ghost it is whenever it makes a random apparition and just win from that.)
And maybe story clues behind each haunting for immersion such as: Finding a diary that might (or might not) have some crucial clues about who used to be it's owner, aka, the ghost, e.g. it's age, which was it's room or favorite room of the house, or if they had many frustrations so you can speculate if it is one of the angry or vengeful kind of ghosts. Or maybe when getting an answer from a spirit box, let's say, in the school map, judging if it's a child's or an adult's voice you can speculate if they were a student or a professor/staff, and then you can maybe ask with your own voice the right question, such as in which classroom they used learn/teach, you MIGHT just get the answer to which room they are haunting. Of course all this could be just generic clues and bits of information that can get randomly swapped, mixed, changed slightly at the start of each round or be completely absent from a game.
I am no game designer, I'm just saying what I think sounds cool, but I think making the whole detective work to find out about the ghost besides the hard proofs would be really fun in this game.

I won't officially rate this since it is early access and it's unfair to put a final judgement on a work in progress, but I will say this: we have a classic in the making here. As long as Kinetic Games sticks to its objectives and stays dedicated to a polished final product, this game WILL go far.

I can't rate this game highly enough at the moment. It's ridiculously immersive, with some of the best voice effects I've heard in a game in a long time, potentially ever. Hearing a friend screaming in another room and having it ACTUALLY sound like they're screaming in the other room? Absolutely amazing. The ghosts are varied, and every encounter feels new, despite the repeated models. Capturing evidence is great as well, and flows naturally into the gameplay loop. 

There are some bugs, however, mostly with the voice chat going silent for a certain player on occasion or tools falling through the ground, but aside from that it's an extremely solid game that has major potential in my eyes. With continued updates and effort put into this game, I fully believe it can grow into a major community game that you can play with friends or even randoms and enjoy it to its fullest.

This is recap of my terrifying encounter in this game.

My friend and I were playing this together exploring an asylum we didn't encounter anything at first. The place after a while started to seem like it went on forever dead ends, long dark hallways, terrifying. So after a while the map started making me feel very uncomfortable and uneasy, I wanted to get back to the van. We started trying to find the exit after being in there for at least 20 mins with no activity finally we get back to the lobby area and see the exit my friend leading ahead about five feet reaches the door first and as soon as he gets out the doors shut and my light starts to flicker. My biggest fear in this game is the door shutting as I'm walking towards it... So I just start loosing it I'm freaking out hyperventilating, shaking, I curl up in a ball by the door as my friend is trying to help all he could do was throw a crucifix through the door past me blocking the hall. After what seemed like forever it stopped I got out of there as fast as possible, and I grabbed a candle before we left and I thew it in the doorway and insulted the ghost. I then decided to go grab it which I ultimately regretted... The I turned around to walk out and the doors slammed shut I broke down worse then before my friend threw the crucifix back though the door and saved my life. Finally after the second encounter we left. I need to breathe after that... I don't know if I'll ever play that map again.

This game is terrifying at times and very thrilling, no game has ever scared me as bad as this game.

I noticed this game had a lot of positive reviews, but to be honest, it took us a bit to get into this. It's a cool idea (4 player ghost hunting game) but it lacked polish necessary to work well. A lot of bugs. 

My friend who was trying to teleport couldn't enter the house on our first try. He kept teleporting back into the van. We had to restart. 

Second time around, we were all able to enter the house, but all our equipment seemed pretty useless. The radio for example didn't seem to do anything. We said the ghost's name many times and it didn't necessarily seem to do much. The same death animation happened for everyone, not really particularly scary. 

I will say that it's a creative idea to have your teammates drop out, but I wish that they could do more once they're dead. 

Go through the training for sure as it helps get the most out of the game.

EDIT: Glad the devs fixed some of the bugs, and we had a more fun time on our second playthrough. Changed this to a positive review :D. Keep it up.

this game is so much fun

Let me say I have put in the time for this game. I am lvl 96, and yes it is scary every game. Even professional mode gets boring eventually once you figure out how to go in, and know what to look for. It's definitely the best horror game out on the market by far. I don't have VR so I can't say from that perspective. Every game is gonna be different which is great! Some will be quick while others will be long due to you being scared to complete the hunt, or bugs in the game preventing you from finishing every objective. It has its bugs yes, but nothing game breaking. Overall the game has so much replayability that I will definitely give it a 10/10 for just being early access. The inventory you have is great, but some items are limited like you can only bring in 2 glow sticks. Helps you see your path once you lay them down to not get lost in bigger maps, but just hide in closets or corners and you are fine 95% of the time for sure during hunts. Amazing game to stream as well for all of you streamers, but I highly recommend playing with friends for more fun and scares! Best way to earn money is the harder modes, completing objectives, and taking photos of bones, writing in books, fingerprints, dirty water, and the ghost. If you want a harder challenge like we are doing, then go on into professional with nothing but the base equipment. Really adds to the horror as you are short on supplies, and really pushes you to be at your best. The bigger maps take longer for sure due to limited equipment. Other than that it brings my review to a close, so I'd definitely say pick it up right now, and enjoy it everyday because it is a BLAST!

I absolutely love this game. I've played numerous haunts and still get the doo doo scared out of me!

One of the most terrifying games I have ever played. The horror is perfect. It's all about atmosphere instead of constant loud noises and jumpscares. The atmosphere is sooo silent that you can hear the really quiet noises from the other side of the house, alerting you to the ghosts location. The variety of equipment and ghosts is also pretty good for a early access game. There is enough ghosts to make it an actual challenge in identifying the ghosts. The maps are all completely different and extremely eerie, especially the farmhouse, (that place is nightmare fuel). The whole gameplay is perfect, having the hunt phase identified by the flashlights, the emf reader in the truck spiking at 10, these moments are terrifying when they happen as you know somethings about to go down. One of my favourite parts of the game is how you communicate to your teammates. You have local talk that's for teammates in close proximity and a radio for teammates at a distance. This is by far one of the coolest systems as it makes the game much more scary as you can't hear you teammates sometimes and you need to use the radio to communicate with them. This game also listens to your microphone to mess around with you more. There are over 150+ Phrases that once said will cause the ghost to react in a certain way. For example, using the ghosts name will cause it to get really annoyed and it might start being aggressive.

Only complaint I have is just with the slight lack of polish with interaction and movement. For example in the hub you can only pick-up 2 objects in the entire room which just seems odd, and within the actual game you can only pick-up equipment and you can't really interact with much else. This isn't a big deal as you have no reason to look around but it just would be nice. Also, there is some bugginess with the movement. There as times when I am trying to hid in a locker and my character keeps jolting around the locker and constantly blacking out my display and turning it back on. This is sometimes really annoying as I don't feel hidden and one of my teammates died when hiding in a locker which I thought couldn't happen. Another slight nitpick is the death animations aren't really scary after you have seen them for the 6th time and just become more frustrating.

But apart from those two little nitpicks, it is definitely the best VR Horror Game currently out now. I highly recommend and the price is completely worth it!                             

                                                                                   (9/10)

My Ghost Experience 
- I went up to the Log Cabin while my three other friends messed around in the van.
As I walked up I started saying "Weeee Woooo, Weeee Woooo" slowly over the walkie talkie. 
I stood in the doorway for a while and then finally stepped in.
The second I stepped in, the door slammed and locked behind me as my light started to flicker.
I immediately started shouting over the walkie talkie "WEE WOO!! WEE WOO!! WEE WOO!!" "HEEELLP!!!".
A shadow showed up on the left of me as something started whispering in my ear.
Then something else appeared at the other end of the room
It suddenly started sprinting towards me with loud thuds (sounding exactly like the IT 2 grandma scene)
As hands came over my screen I screamed my last "WEE WOO!!" as I died. 
They then found my body and left the mission right away.

Have you ever watched Ghost Adventures or Ghost Hunters? This is basically the game of those series. 

Your slow movement only adds to the feeling of dread that wears on you throughout your duration of each location, and the unpredictable behavior of the spirits keep your long hours of play interesting and consistently spooky! 

Playing with friends is both hilariously fun and (obviously) a bit of a safety blanket on your fears. Have already spent many hours playing long sessions, only stopping because... it was close to bed time, haha.

Currently the game is in early access, so the repetitiveness of ghost designs and mannerisms is starting to show due to the limited variety. I'm excited to see more horrifying, possibly less-human designs, faster or creepier animations for the ghosts AND the death cutscene. Would love to see more interaction for those of your team who die (possibly with the spirit board or box). There is room for so much easy growth and potential, I'm excited to see where this game goes!

You arrive at a haunted location.

Step 1: Use your equipment to locate the ghost
Step 2: Use your equipment to find out what kind of ghost you're dealing with
Step 3: Get out (hopefully alive)

The game does a great job with making you feel on edge.
You rarely die and there are barely any jumpscares, but the atmosphere really puts you on edge.
The ghosts usually only make their presence known with subtle details, so when they start becoming more active, you get caught off guard and they scare the hell out of you.

I do wish there was a step between 2 and 3. figuring out the ghost type is usually the last thing you do before you escape, so the knowledge of the ghost type rarely gets used, which is a shame because each ghost tends to act in a different way and it'd be cool if that played more of a role.

Growing up and watching ghost hunting shows, I've always wanted to take a stab at it myself, and this game lets you do just that. Right now, you have many of the tools ghost hunters would use in their line of work, and I'm positive that more will be added in.

The only two things I have to look at as a minus is that:
 
1. When a player dies, [spoiler] They become a ghost, or are in the spirit plane [/spoiler] there's not much to do except for waiting around, watching your teammates. If there was a teammate specific [spoiler] spirit box [/spoiler] that would allow one-word communication from the teammates, that might actually help things. Of course, people could troll, but it would give the players something to do.

2. There is only a small sense of fulfillment for me in [spoiler] discovering what ghost is haunting the area [/spoiler] I'm sure there are probably more things in the works, but I would love for there to be maybe a 3 part sort of thing, which would be:
-Discovery of ghost
-Investigation as to why they're there or what happened to them
-Possible Exorcising of the ghost and removal from the place of residence

I think that there should be more of a challenge like that and that [spoiler] not all the ghosts should be violent. It's a bit ridiculous to me that everyone's pissed off when they die lol I would think that maybe some peoples' death was an accident and they just wanted to stick around to see what was going on in peoples' lives. [/spoiler] 

I think these changes would add more flavour to the game and make it keep my attention for a long time to come. 

But to conclude, Phasmophobia is a brilliant game and I highly recommend it to everyone who loves to be spooked <3 Thank you for your hard work Dknighter!

Sharing a haunting with others can be a uniquely frightening experience. Even if Phasmophobia isn't the sharpest ghost in the shed, basing it around drawing out the danger instead of simply running/hiding from it evokes a new type of dread. It's not unlike the thrill of daring a friend to poke a large snake with a short stick.

Gimmicks such as speech recognition are exciting, but its integration seems very shallow and it's difficult to gauge its accuracy. Still, speaking to the spirit and getting any sort of response is an event that gets the whole crew shaking. People often take this element quite seriously which only adds to the immersion.

The overall polish that's on display often takes away from the atmosphere. The way characters stiffly look around and slowly reverse-moonwalk is hysterical. On the rare occurrence where apparitions do show themself, their appearance is often static, janky, and underwhelming. Giving additional attention to the ghosts’ visuals could go a long way. Dynamic, intelligent movement with dramatic particles could be a start. It'd be a shame to leave early access as without overcoming the Unity creepypasta game taint.

Keeping up ambiguity and maintaining space for discovery is essential for a sense of mystery, but confusion over basic applications has made introductions to the game very rough. A tutorial that makes sure to demonstrate positive readings would be appreciated. Subtle contextual button prompts would assist with the odd control scheme. As for mechanical transparency: defining the 'freezing' threshold, giving notes on the implications of lights/flashlights being on/off, and what phrases ghosts respond to are basic examples of missing feedback.

Launching with VR compatibility is a smart move. That said, the terror of any horror experience is wildly amplified by 3D and 6DoF, so Phasmophobia isn't responsible for the impact that’s inherent to the added immersion. Being in a dark room with the promise of a cube that will suddenly and unexpectedly violate your personal space would be distressing. It’s still a pants-filling way to play and worth trying [i]after[/i] familiarizing yourself with the gameplay.

In its current state, I'm not sure the game lives up to its steam rating, but its shared-scare premise has clearly been effective. Once again, friends tend to improve games and Phasmophobia doesn’t require much commitment which makes it great for randomly bringing others on board. It’s not a bad investment if you have two or more buds at the ready, especially if some of them aren’t used to horror games.

I have owned this game for 2 days, and have already pumped in just over 9 hours, as well as had nightmares for 2 days straight. I intend to pump many, many more hours into it. This is one of the best games I've ever played, and it's only in alpha. I can not wait to see how much further this game can go, especially since it was only released a little over 1 week ago. I am especially amazed at how fast it topped the charts for Top Seller, and it should be true foreshadowing for what this game will become. 

Of course, only being in Alpha, it does need a little polishing, and as such, I have some suggestions for the developer that may want to take into mind. I feel that the following suggestions may make the game feel a little more lively, ironic considering the games premise. The suggestions may already be obvious, or even planned for a future update, but I hope the developer takes them into consideration.

- [spoiler] [b] more death animations: [/b]. This would be good to deviate from the basic "hands grasping player" animation. [/spoiler]

- [b] more entity variety: [/b]. This does not mean to add more entities, but rather make them more distinguished. I truly understand the concept of the game IS to find out what entity the players are dealing with, however, the have been quite a few games where we have found all three pieces of definitive evidence, I.E pointing to a [spoiler] poltergeist [/spoiler] but it ends up being a [spoiler] demon [/spoiler] or a [spoiler] yurei [/spoiler]. Of course, this may be a bug, after all, it is still in alpha, but I hope this is more fleshed out as time goes on. 

- [b] PVP mode: [/b]. This would be an absolutely huge win in my book and would skyrocket the game more than it already has been. A PVP mode would be true insanity. Maybe of course have a minor nerf to the player who controls the entity as it may be way too strong for an actual human to control, rather than an AI. Of course, as the case with the AI, limit the player to [spoiler] certain rooms or portions of the map [/spoiler] or allow them to [spoiler] roam the entire map in larger maps such as asylum [/spoiler]. 

- [b] have entities truer to their descriptions: [/b] this also correlates to the second point in the list. I feel as if many of the entities we have encountered have been very cut and dry, and not as true to their descriptions as they can be. I've had [spoiler] poltergeists [/spoiler] behave like [spoiler] revenants [/spoiler] and i've had [spoiler] wraiths [/spoiler] behave like [spoiler] shades [/spoiler]. For example, I've had [spoiler] Jinn be extremely slow and stalkerlike toward the player, [/spoiler], which doesn't correlate with their descriptions. Of course, this may be a result of the evidence bug. 

- [b] Faster movement speed: [/b] This is fine for the smaller maps, but for maps like [spoiler] Asylum [/spoiler] and [spoiler] Middle School [/spoiler] this can be a real thorn in terms of game pace. I understand the developer does not want to make it easy on the player by any means, but I feel that for the bigger maps, a higher movement speed is in order to make the game more atmospheric, especially if you were running from an entity. You can even balance this by making the entities move faster.

- [spoiler][b] Have the dead players interact with the remaining group: [/b] This would make the game especially interesting and it could always be a help or hinder situation. Allow the dead players to convey messages through the ouija board or ghost radio. This would add a better sense of teamwork within the game. [/spoiler]

- [b] Higher player count: [/b] Although with most games having 4 players as the sweet spot, I feel like 6 players within this game would do it more justice. I have a bunch of friends that love this game and others that haven't bought it yet due to the fact that 9 times out of 10 so far, we have a full group. It would give a greater emphasis on teamwork, especially for the larger maps. This would entice more players and larger social circles to buy and enjoy the game.

All in all, this is an absolutely amazing game, and has fully convinced me to buy a VR headset for my rig in order to truly experience the game. I look forward to the many updates in Phasmophobia's future, and I can not wait to see how far the developer can take it. This truly is an atmospheric horror masterpiece that myself, and i'm sure, many others, have been waiting for. It is a breath of fresh air from the typical, mainstream jumpscare games and this will go down as iconic.

This game is awesome. If you were looking for a Co-Op horror game this is it. Just bought it and cannot stop playing it.

Pros
----------
- Fun (and tense) game-play with friends or alone
- Plenty of different scenarios (and items) in the current build
- Highly replayable value
- Early access (more content is always a pro)

Cons
------------
- VR people can slip through locked/closed doors
- At the moment the voice servers aren't perfect but do the job fine
- Walk speed is a bit slow on the larger maps (makes it more scary imo)


If you got the money to spend I say go for it. The game is really fun and will only get better.

For being early release, this game is fantastic. 

There are some jump-scares but the game relies heavily on ambiance, sound (and sound placement), and anticipation to build suspense, to great effect. 


There is some glitching/clipping through walls that can occur for player and spook alike, but it is a minor detail. I'd also argue about the cost of a $10 lighter.

I am greatly looking forward to seeing how this game expands and grows.

First indie horror game in a long, *long* time where I didn't actively want to anger the ghost in any way I could, and that's something special right there.

Like all early access games, it needs work. But the idea and the basis of the game is amazing. I have had a lot of fun with friends. I would recommend VR but desktop mode works just as well. I can see extra ghosts and maps being added to enhance the gameplay. 
Things to work on: 
Not sure if its just me, but sometimes there will only be  1 or 2 ghost signs and I will need to guess the ghost based on other things experienced. 
More kill animations and jump scares, the game is spooky as is but more things to scare the player would make it far better. 
More ghost evidence, often my group only needs to make 2 trips to the ghost area to figure out which ghost it is. With more evidence or evidence that only shows up later it will extend the game and cause more ghost interactions.

These suggestions added into an already great game will greatly increase the user's experience

Ambient Sounds in the houses need to go. They are often jarring and take away from realism.

More ways to discover what ghost you're dealing with as alot of the time you get no EMF readings/ghostbox/them reading/orbs for a while and often get attacked before hand. Yet having a ghost play with a Ouija board or flicking the lights on and off for half an hour. Giving us no relevent information

I never write reviews for steam but this game deserves one:

Phasmophobia is a game where you take on the role of a paranormal investigator with up to 3 friends.
I've only been brave enough to play with 3 friends and we've had a blast every single time we played. This game doesn't need cheap jump scares to get you but instead uses atmosphere and tension to get you.

Some cons that I noticed tho:
The ghost names were all pretty similar when we played. A few time the ghosts had the same first name or last name as the one we were hunting before that but this might just be coincidence.
Furthermore in VR me and my friends sometimes had trouble loading in if we were in VR.
Overall I'm gonna throw those cons on the fact that this game is early access and also say that it did not take away from the experience as a whole.

I couldn't recommend this game enough if you enjoy paranormal horror or just a good time with friends.
This game is like an analogy for Twitch chat where if you say the right words, some hostile entity will get triggered and attack you.
