This is one of the best horror games to come out this year, with the name meaning the fear of ghosts i was hooked I clicked on this game, had a look at some comments and reviews and after being impressed i brought the game, plugged my VR headset in a jumped right in and after 32 hours of game-play i finally had a review. Keep in mind this is in early access and i will explain some things about in being in early access

Environment
The environment in this game really sets the mood the ambience changes as soon as you walk in the building making easy to hear anything, a clock ticking in a silent room makes you feel uneasy sometimes making you want to go back, i do believe this game holds a solid environment for every map it has so far and more in the future.

Gameplay
The game-play is solid and doesn't let you down giving you all the right equipment to find and figure out what kind of ghost you are looking for, i've had stuff thrown at me or in the room, ive had door open or close in front of me, i've been growled at chased, hunted, this is a great scare, using your microphone to talk to the ghosts is really smart and creepy knowing they can hear you at all time and saying the name which is randomly generated making it angry, this game will never let you down if your looking for a scare.

Early access and bugs
This section is going to be talking about the future of this game, this game is in early access so there are bugs but they aren't game breaking and don't happen often so you might get a few bugs, but this game is constantly getting updated to fix the issues. Now there are currently 2 farm houses, 3 street houses and 2 Large maps a high school and a Asylum, and more are to come as again in is constantly getting updates from the dev.

My personal ideas
I grew up watch ghost adventures and ghost hunters so i was hooked already on this game but there is some equipment they use that aren't in the game so here is some things i believe should be added. number 1 is a thermal cameras you can bring and look through or only on the van monitor. They should also add a sound system to the video cameras so you can hear whats happening in the room, like if the EMF is going of or its talking through the spirit box. Now with maps i feel there should be medium sized maps i have a really cool idea for a mansion to be added or a old castle.

Community
I've meet some great people and people i play with almost daily now and it is fun with friends, this community its built so far is amazing super nice people and funny and its always fun to hear them scream from another side of the map, you will meet some people who might seem weird or annoying but its still the same scary game.  

Conclusion 
This is something you should definitely add this to your cart if you love horror or your interested in ghosts, i love both so this was instantly in my cart. Now it being in early access should not stop you from getting this game it is always fun to come back to so get it try it and if you don't enjoy it refund it. i was going to leave a review sooner but i didn't have much hours. SO in conclusion... get this game what can i say its amazing for a horror lover.

Rating - Sound a bit crazy but for me i give it a... 10/10 and with more updates and bug fixes daily, I expect big things

Absolutely wonderful. Phasmophobia is a horror game like no other. Gearing up with friends or randoms in this game gives the player a unique experience every time you go on a hunt. 
Pros: 
-Definitely spooky for sure
-Ghost variety
-Dynamic situations based upon location, ghost type, difficulty, and team size 
-Practically endlessly replayability
-Even after you clock a few hours and the game becomes not as scary, the investigation aspect is equally as enjoyable
Cons:*
-A few bugs such as thermometer readings going through the floor so you may thing it's upstairs but it's actually in the room underneath, random loading issues where the game crashes upon loading into map (Very rare for myself but I lost my equipment even though I didn't die :/ ), Spirit box can be a bit hit or miss sometimes but you can get a hang of it after a while.
*While there are a couple bugs, the dev team are extremely quick and have literally been putting out hotfixes almost every day (Just make sure to update every day before launching). You can see the bug fix description in the phasmophobia discord in which the devs are very interactive.

Overall One of the best co-op experiences I have had and an absolute steal for the price.

Fantasticly terrifying game.

Only bugs my friends and I have had is the ghost got stuck one time during a hunt and other time one of our players was seeing a different head-mounted camera to the rest of us. 
Aside from that, it's been loads of fun.

From 'easier' ghosts that aren't super aggressive, to ghosts that care only about scaring you shitless and trying to kill you, the reactions and situations you'll find yourself in this game are priceless. 

The game doesn't really hold your hand past the tutorial though, from what we've found. Haven't been able to get a Ouija board to work, and understanding the Parabolic Microphone has been met with mixed results. All the other equipment is pretty straight forward though and easy to use.

I don't know if it's a bug, but whenever returning from a ghost hunt, the host sometimes changes and there isn't currently a way to transfer host. It's not a bad thing if you're playing with friends, obviously, since you can just discuss what jobs to do.

If you can stream this, or play with someone that can, I'd recommend that. Not only so people can also bask in how terrified you get, but also so you can clip awesome, bone-chilling moments to rewatch later.

The devs are extremely active with constant updates. Well worth the asking price and I'm stoked to see what comes next. 

All in all 666/10, would get spooked again.

Flavor:

Well at time of writing I'm almost level 80.

I have mostly overcome my fears, and my skills of master ghost hunting are basically complete.

But there are still moments where I am super spooked. Being alone in a house trying to aggravate the ghost is not my favourite thing to do, but it must be done.

Technical:

An impressive game for 1 dev. Dev is actively bug fixing and communicating with community on Discord. It has ironing out to do for sure, but at the rate the dev is catching issues and providing fixes, it is no concern.

Currently some of the bugs effect gameplay. Some evidence mechanics occasionally don't seem to work properly. This leaves my friends and I having to sometimes troubleshoot our way to guessing the ghost type based on ghost behaviour and the evidence that we can prove we DON'T have. Works 90% of the time. This is more of a notice than a complaint, as I know it will be fixed, and once it is I'll edit this section.

The tutorial doesn't tell you everything. We learned a lot through looking into forum discussions, from other players, and experimentation. Some more official documentation would help new players, but I think some level of trial and error should exist to maintain the feeling of discovery and also added anxiety.

Appeal: 

Visuals aren't mindblowing, but nothing to complain about.
Atmosphere seems very well tuned. A hair raising combination of light, sound, and physical environment. 

I've been having fun playing with friends, guiding noobs, and watching grown men scream.

A fun selection of equipment to use for tracking down ghosts and evidence.

Excited to see where the future will take this game, but it's current state is totally playable and well worth the price tag.
while it has its glitches it is a very fun co-op game.

If you're into board games, Phasmophobia is designed like one - each session can be split into different phases where each player has specific objectives/responsibilities in each phase, depending on the items they hold.

 Even in its early release state, the game is well designed and has a satisfying gameplay loop. 

There's a lot of ambiguity around how certain mechanics work and sometimes can be frustrating due to inconsistencies from bugs (and sometimes gamebreaking), but discovery is also part of the experience. This is one of the better co-op games I've played and for its early access price, it's worth it.

Hands down my favorite game. You get to play as an ghost hunter and have a near infinite combination of encounters/missions to complete while trying to keep your sanity and survive the terrifying torment of whatever is haunting you. I personally enjoy the smaller maps more due to the similarity to movies such as "paranormal activity" and "sinister". If you enjoy those kinds of movies then I completely recommend this game. Have fun!

Amazing game, built from the ground up with VR in mind but with full desktop support so you can turn you and your friend's into the Scooby Squad with a few less ascots. Any fans of the ghost hunting genre could not have asked for a more perfect multiplayer experience. It's not about winning or losing, it's about going in as an investigator and trying to figure out what works and what doesn't, all while trying to not get yourself and your friends killed....Ok, well maybe you might try to get your friends killed, yeah scratch that, you 100% will. Having tons of options for gear, full voice recognition support through Windows and some of the creepiest atmosphere ever and it does not rely on cheap jump scares.  It's genuinely filled with WTF Moments nearly every hunt. Jump in, Try Not To Die, Repeat 10/10!

Shortly after going through Dead Space 3 with a friend, I took to Discord and rambled on about how much I [b]need[/b] more decent cooperative horror experiences. A couple days later, another friend told me about "this new game where you investigate ghosts with up to 3 other people", and before they finished explaining what it was, I bought it. 

[b]Here are the Nifty things I liked, and the Lame things I didn't.[/b]

[h1]The Nifty[/h1]
✪ Playing this game with friends is a blast, especially if at least one of them get spooked easily. Hearing their reactions to ghost encounters, and how their voices can actually be detected by the game, is an absolute treat.

✪ Each level's design is top-notch, with excellent space utilization, lighting and interactivity.

✪ Ghost hunting wouldn't be fun without a decent variety of tools, and this game provides. It also helps that every mission features a different ghost with different strengths and weaknesses, so learning how each tool works is a necessity.

✪ The journal, which helps you find out what ghost you're dealing with and serves as a hub for your clues, is a really nifty progression tool. It's also nice to see how it automatically eliminates the possibility to guess a ghost that doesn't fit with what you've discovered.

✪ No matter how much I'd love to think that I've been desensitized to fear in the vast majority of horror games, almost every round of Phasmophobia makes me feel uncomfortable and anxious. The unpredictability of each ghost, especially once you get out of Amateur difficulty, in intoxicating spookiness at its prime.

✪ Voice Recognition is usually a pretty big miss in most of the game's I've played that support it. There's either no true benefit to using it, it serves as a forgettable gimmick, or it just doesn't work at all. Phasmophobia not only nails the execution of voice commands, but makes it essential to the gameplay loop in a horrifyingly immersive way. I'll never forget the first time I called out to a ghost and it said it was behind me, or how a friend said they were scared, and a ghost threw something at her. 

✪ For a game that looks and feels very VR focused, it runs smoothly in Desktop mode. The keyboard and controller bindings are simple to execute and easy to remember as well, making it enjoyable no matter how you prefer to play.

[h1]The Lame[/h1]
✘ Having a flashlight on your shoulder whilst holding an even better flashlight doesn't make much sense to me, and feels like a wasted equipment slot. Maybe, instead of essentially having two flashlights, we can just replace the flashlight on our shoulder with whatever one we pick up in the truck?

✘ Large maps are way too big to be enjoyable, and I don't think I'd be able to navigate them without having a person in my group who stays in the truck. Perhaps Medium maps could be considered the new Large, and the new Medium could be something between the starter houses and the High School? If that passes, perhaps maps like the Asylum, which is considered a Large map, can be dubbed Extra Large instead.

✘ There are a few little issues that aren't bad enough to be considered serious, like: not being able to access the controls during a mission, muting other players, Options menu adjustments resetting after each round and a few glitches that will likely be ironed out as the game goes.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I usually try to avoid Early Access titles, but after Phasmophobia's convenient release, I couldn't help myself. Fortunately it ended up being worth every single penny, and I'd be willing to dish out more money for it in a heartbeat. With the right amount of dedication, thorough fan feedback and a dedicated base, this could end up being one of the absolute best (multiplayer) horror experiences of all time. Here's hoping it keeps gaining traction!

[h3]NOTE: This is an Early Access review, and I've yet to play in VR, but plan to within the next 30 days.[/h3]

[h2]EDITS:[/h2]
> Sept 26, 2020: Moved NOTE from top to bottom.
> Sept 27, 2020: Removed a Lame after discovering that it wasn't true in later difficulties.

Well worth the price, and a very promising game by Kinetic Games.

The horror in this game is well executed, and is mainly conveyed by the atmosphere and sound environment. 

The lighting compliments the eerie tone of the game, and is one of the best aspects of the whole experience at the moment. It is well crafted and believable, adding to the immersion. The bigger rooms swallowing the feeble light of your candle or flashlight elevates the sense of space and loneliness to a whole another level, making the danger lurk not only behind you or around the corners, but right in front of you.

The gadgets and minigames tied to them are entertaining and don't take from the experience. Most gimmicky of them is the spirit box that you use to talk to the ghost. It is not always clear what you can ask or if it's working properly. It would be a good idea to expand on it, making the questions somehow tied to other phenomena happening around the haunted location. If the ghost breaks stuff, you could ask if they are angry for example. But all in all the gadgets bring purpose to you being in a haunted building, and the tasks force you to move on when you feel scared. And get eaten of course. 

VR in this game works very well, so well in fact that it is the best VR horror experience I have tried. Many objects are interactable and fully modeled and textured. You can light candles that your friends are holding and the gadgets work when stored on your belt as well, so physics are well thought out. The game does not take away your control at any point for a pointless cutscene or animation, and it does not control you in any way when danger approaches. You are in control, yourself, alone, without any safety nets. Hide or die. Excellent understanding of game design and VR as a medium. 

The money system and levels work as a great way to convey progress, and I am excited to see the system expand with more equipment and locations. I wish some kind of an upgrade system was implemented as well, where you could bring more equipment to the locations. I really love the glowsticks but you can only bring two. 

Surprisingly, the ghosts themselves are the worst part of the game right now, and I would work on them asap. The suspense and outright terror of the unknown (or impending doom) carry the experience well, but when you actually see the ghosts they are a letdown. For the player models the goofy Cry Of Fear-esque models are sufficient, but the ghosts really need to be more detailed. More animations, better models and for some of them a more disturbing way of movement. Keep their traits and expand on them, you have a great base already. As for how they are now, a seemingly stock animation of a middle aged dad on a leisure walk stapled on a goofy zombie model is not scary at all. It's too humane. Crawling, floating backwards, twitching, keeping disturbing sounds etc. are more fit for ghosts. Of course, for some better than the others. I like the idea of diverse ghosts, I'm not saying they all should be generic Grudge-girls. Just make their motives unearthly along with how they conduct themselves. The ghost hunters should not understand them, neither should the player. And in my honest opinion, remove the flickering in and out of existence. It's fine if it happens on camera, but not when you are directly looking at the ghost. It really reduces the scare factor and reminds you that it's just a game. Plus, it really doesn't seem to have a purpose at all, unnecessary things are almost never good for a game in the first place. If the intention is to make them harder to see, just make a separate ethereal form for them or make their movements less predictable. 

Some actual problems I noticed while playing the game:
- Grouping up is maybe a bit too powerful of a tactic. I don't know if the A.I. breaks or what, but we have not yet been killed once when sticking together as 4. 
- A small area inside the doors leading out is considered outdoors. This affects communication, but more importantly breaks the ghost. If you hug the door when they are chasing you, they cant path to you. You are always safe near the door, and it takes away form the experience and immersion. I have confirmed this behavior in the large wooden house and the school map, but it might be a problem on all of them.
- The area where you have to point the VR controller to speak through the radio is a bit too small and gets displaced when you crouch. It's a bit too tedious to use at the moment, even though the idea is great. Just make the area larger by a fraction, it should fix it.

Currently I would say this game is a 7/10. Amazing concept, very well implemented so far (with some buggyness), and overall a very fun and creepy time. I like the items and the design of gathering evidence and angering the ghost.

Pros:
Amazing Co-Op.
Creep factor done right.
Good Graphics.
Sound Design is creepy AF!
Proximity and voice chat help the immersion a lot.
Just fun as hell.

Cons:
Bugs. Some ghosts don't really play by the rules assigned to them or straight up refuse to give you the 3rd evidence no matter how long you stay or what you do. The chat also can just not work. Not the worst, but can make gameplay worse.
Walking speed. You walk like an old granny and jesus is it annoying on large maps such as Asylum or High School.
Lack of explanation/understanding for aspects of the game. It can be difficult to understand how to do things or what means what exactly. (Off the top of my head, I have no idea if you can remove a head mounted camera)

Overall this game is extremely promising and is already delivering a pretty damn good experience, but I believe if polished correctly and completed it could become a masterpiece.

Scare easily? fumbling around in this game is terrifying; with the various creepy maps and randomness of the ghost's actions nearly every encounter is diffrent.

Ain't afraid of no ghost? Even if the game isn't really scary to people who have gotten use to the game mechanics or you've seen enough **** already that you're numb to the world, this game has a great "professional ghost hunter" feel. Go in set up your equipment, get the evidence and get out. You're still likely to get a startle now and then or just laugh as you and your friends form a teabag circle around the ghost and place bets on who dies first.

The game can get pretty buggy, to be excepted from a game with a couple of developers, however they obviously care about the game and have been releasing multiple patches a day since it's steam launch.

 Sadly I don't have VR so I can't personally comment on it.

You're on a paranormal investigation team. You are contracted to search a cabin whose new owner believes is haunted, so you grab your friends, grab your ghost hunting tools, and jump in your mystery wagon. 

Unlocking the door, you walk into a dark, empty home and make your way through the rooms, waving your trusty EMF finder. You get some readings in a back washroom, so you put up some cameras, maybe a book and candle, and investigate further. The teammate in the van says he's got some orbs on camera, then suddenly the candle goes out and the lights flicker.

You and your buddy take the initiative to get some more information. Going in with the spirit box, a camera, and a crucifix you try to speak to the ghost. "Daniel Martinez, are you here with us? Please give us a sign." Suddenly, your friend jumps to the wall, the door slams behind you, and you are now face to face with the undead.

Quickly grabbing your crucifix you thrust it at the demon yelling "THE POWER OF CHRIST COMPELS YOU", then watch it turn towards you, the lights flicker off, and it says through the spirit box: "Man door hand hook car door". You fucking shit bricks and your buddy didn't even get a photo of the damn ghost.



That's what this game is like, unless you take too long investigating and you get fisted by some dead lady in a high middle class suburban home..

I play in VR and it was thrilling and I swear I could feel things give me goose bumps, raise hairs on the back of my neck, and nearly fricken touch me.
This game is amazing, if you like horror games you'll love it. No annoying jump scares, all atmosphere. Fun with randoms and even better with friends.

This game is great, but currently it has some issues with the movement in vr going up slight inclines that makes it really annoying. Even smooth inclines like the ramp for the truck can cause people to get stuck and you'll have to move at an angle to continue moving up it, same with the stairs. If they worked that out it would be a solid 10/10 for me. I'm looking forward to the additions they bring to the game, tons of possibilities. 

Also, this game has no level based scaling for which types of spirits you encounter. You would think that weaker/less aggressive ghosts would be more common, and the more dangerous/erratic types would be rarer. But that's not the case, you could be level 1 with other people also level 1 and get a demon, or an oni, back to back jinns. I really think it's just random. As I write this I'm currently level 20 and my experience has been mostly Jinns, Onis, Poltergeists/Banshees pretty much tied, rarely a regular spirit, phantoms somewhat common, shade here and there. Yureis and Mares are extremely rare in my experience. So I figure that which types of ghost you encounter is based on their characteristics alone, and the difficulty of their characteristics is what you see when going into the job.

One other thing, currently there's some sort of desync issue with the ghost orbs. Sometimes people see the same ones at the same times, others though, someone will be able to see them but no one else will, the intervals and positions will be off, making it harder to identify which type of ghost you are dealing with. I considered maybe it was due to a sanity difference or something but it just seems to be a bug. 

Currently there is only one type of voice that can come over the speaker box, not a big deal, but it hurts the immersion a little. 

And you can have a female named ghost but the apparition won't resemble a female at all once it manifests. Sometimes it does, it's just something I personally wished was a little more consistent. Sometimes they appear as children-like manifestations, but the voice is always the same guy. I'm just saying, if it was a child's voice coming over the speaker box I'd s**t myself. 

Good game nonetheless. Keep up the good work guys.

Some ideas I had: Since the game can recognize your microphone and speech. Maybe you could add an attribute to a ghost where it will capture phrases your teammates say (Locations, yes or nos, etc) and play them back at times a teammate will ask a question to lead them astray, perhaps a ghost that targets solos.

Maybe some writing on the wall, cabinets that open and shut suddenly, just some things to consider.
Most of those hours were spent in some corner with crucifix in my hands, flashlight all around me and screaming the power of christ compels you.

I MADE A CONTROLLER MAP FOR AN X-BOX ONE CONTROLLER BELOW MY REVIEW! Seriously, this game is Amazing! Worth every penny spent on it! VR is amazing, desktop is just as fun with full controller support! The game is a bit like a horror game of co-op clue, hear me out; You go in with a group of people, you collect evidence, you try to survive by working together which helps you get more clues as to what the ghost type is, then at the end after collecting enough evidence it points all fingers at only one possible entity. It's fun, great for communicating and socializing and facing the primal fear of what's lurking in the shadows together.
It took me a while to figure out the controller buttons ... so here, this may help until they add a controller map:
Left Analog Stick - walk (Press and hold in "L3" to "run")
Right Analog Stick - looks around (Press in "R3" to crouch)
A - action button (hold rotates items you want to place / tap, looking at a camera to turn it on or off)
B - cancel (or back out button) also drops/gently tosses held objects
Y - cycle through inventory)
X - pick-up button
RB - (hold) speak in your walkie-talkie
RT - Activate held item
LB - (hold) speak out loud (proximity chat)
LT - Place held object (this replaces the "toss" option that the "B" button offers)
D-Pad Up - opens and closes Journal (the "B" button does not work for closing the journal)
D-Pad down - toggles flashlight in your inventory on/off when holding other items
(I haven't found a function for D-Pad left and right buttons)
Menu/pause button it the middle right black button (I don't know its proper name)
I don't know what the middle left little black button (two little boxes on it) does, same for pressing the big "X-Box" button

So there you go everyone. I hope this helps anyone that wants to use the game pad, but it will help most with X-Box One controllers (that's what mine is) and it MAY help with X-Box 360 controllers. Enjoy this fun and addicting game!

An amazing experience through, and through. As someone who plays barely any horror games whatsoever, a genuine recommendation is given, to horror lovers, AND non-horror players alike. This is ESPECIALLY true, if you're looking into an entry-way into the genre. The game itself is not one that crutches on jump-scares whatsoever, but instead purely creepy, chilling, dreadful atmosphere, and design. I've been looking for a horror-game to jump into with friends for awhile now, and this game is the PERFECT scratch for that itch. It being in early access, I am impressed with how well the game runs, absolutely no crashes, on top of a good variety of interesting, in-depth, yet simple game-play concepts. I very eagerly look forward to seeing where this game goes, with potential new ghost-types, models, behaviors, maps, hunting-equipment, and progression.

I feel as though the larger maps, like the high-school, and asylum would benefit from a player-capacity increase to 5, as it can be pretty tiring, and tedious at times looking around countless empty rooms, or having to haul-ass back to the truck, for equipment. if balancing is an issue, you could come up with some sort of equipment to buy, that allows the extra player, or two.

As a personal note to the developers; PLEASE, NEVER-EVER start implementing any major sudden jump-scare designs. That would, in my own tastes, completely ruin ANY drive to play the game.

This game is off to a good start. It can be pretty scary and fun when playing with a group of friends. I like the concept of this game and how you can communicate through the microphone. It gives players more of a "ghost hunting" vibe. 

Although this game is off to s good start, there's a few things that could be improved to make the gameplay even greater. I would like to see the ghost roam around or peek from the corner; I think that would make it scarier, rather than the ghost only popping up to kill me. It would also be nice if the game implemented more evidence to collect during missions. Usually, there's only one bone to collect and I'd like to collect more things in the mission. There's also a few bugs in this game, such as my entire money collection going missing and seeing a friend's level reset to level 1. I understand that this game is still being developed, but I am hoping to see these bugs fixed in the future. Again, this game is off to a great start and I'd still recommend it.
I would recommend this 100%. It was kinda spooky ngl.

Game is really fun even with the dreaded "early access" caveat. I'll list my pros and cons below as well as some recommendations to make the game better.

Pros:

- 4 player co op
- Can get pretty tense/spooky even in multiplayer
- Fun finding out which ghost is there
- When something actually happens it is great
- Graphically, the environment looks good
- Great concept
- VR support

Cons:

- Tutorial doesn't tell you nearly enough which leads to a lot of experimenting/figuring things out which CAN be fun, but is mostly frustrating
- The end of a mission is pretty anticlimactic
- The character and ghost models look bad
- The characters move SUPER slow
- There isn't much of an indication of success
- Sometimes it is way too hard to find the ghost

Recommendations:

- Make the characters move a bit faster
- Get some new character and ghost models
- The game currently feels like it is missing an act. After you find the ghost you just leave. It would be cool to get some sort of post discovery mission to get rid of it or fight back somehow
- Add some sort of mechanism that aids players once a lot of time has passed if they haven't found anything.


Overall I really like this game and concept! I think a few things just need ironed out and it will become an even better experience. Kudos to the devs so far!
As a real paranormal investigator this game is pretty realistic! From equipment to environment and sounds this game is intense! Being early access I can only see it getting better

Remember those corny ghost hunting shows ? Well now it's for real, Chose a location and investigate the area. With a bit more polishing and getting rid of bugs this could be an absolute game changer.
The psychological terror part / early game is fantastic but could have a bit more added too it, the hunt section could be better, here are a few suggestions:

- Fade in and out effects and animations for all Ghost types.
- More animations in general for Ghost movement.
- More death animations and finishers for all Ghosts.
- Visible death animations on the human side
( seeing your teammates getting killed in glorious fashion)
- Getting items thrown at you, furniture pushed etc
( also the poltergeist being able to lift you up )
-  More models for the ghosts

Sanity System Suggestions:
With insanity going up / sanity going down, you start freaking out
 (All of this is Local / Individual player point of view only, nothing server side)

- Seeing smoke or darkness coming from under doors 
- When opening doors bugs crawl from some doors to your hand area
- Hearing voices non related to the current ghost you are gathering evidence for
- Lights seem to go off, pitch black (but its only local so your there screaming "in the dark" while your friends wonder why) for a few seconds
- Getting transported into a "upside down" version of the map where you need to complete a survival mini-game to come back to your senses / reality
- Taping on windows but when you look it's a tree branch
- Seeing the faces of your teammates distort into a "Ghost like" appearance / Morph

I only encountered a few bugs:

-Falling through certain maps in certain areas
- (VR) Item belt not following you around properly

Make sure to share this game, and hopefully with sales the Dev's can get a full team working on it !

(I will be updating my review with the development of the game and adding suggestions)

So as a closing statement, I give this game a very solid "Must Buy" for VR users and heck, even desktop ! it's such a unique take on the horror genre, and from what I gather it has never been done before !

I mean its definitely the best co-op 1-4 player horror game I think I've ever played?!  I dont know if theres much competition for that spot to be sure (L4D and the like being more Action than Horror), but Phasmophobia is a real treat :)  Instead of being another combat-ridden over the top monster-fest: you take all of the tropes from modern ghost hunting tv shows - video cameras, spirit talking boxes, EMF readers, motion/sound sensors etc - then put yourself in a creepy location with a bunch of mates or randoms online and prepare for some crazy times!  

As a team your goal is to try to track down, draw conclusive evidence to identify the type of ghost using the different tools at your disposal, dissuade the ghost from attacking you, and capture photos of spooky phenomenon.  All while the AI tries to wreck your sanity (both in-game and in-reality)!

Microphone is required to communicate with your team, try to use the in-game comms rather than Discord to add to the tension (V for Local chat, B for Global) and don't be shy!  Theres been some genuine creepy moments in my first 10 hours of gameplay - a few hugs in wardrobes while flashlights are flickering - and some great laughs :D

What a game for people who love a scare!

The game is currently in Early Access, but it's a solid release. It runs butter smooth, barely any issues and more or less, the issue's with the game are around motion like characters animations and little bugs. Nothing major!

Graphics: The graphics are actually alright, not amazing like Battlefield but there are decent to look at with some great visual effects and overal a nice 3D rendered aspect game that is nice to play and look at.

Audio: The audio in the game is massively atmosphere based, so you need sound on to listen and proceed. It does have some weird audio effects but they just work and the audio is spot on from stamping to the ghosts running, to floorboards creeking, to pictures falling, it's all really great audio that brings the game to life.

Controls: SUPER easy to pickup and play, but a long time to clean your underwear when you move to far forward and something happens. Easy controls in VR and desktop version.

Gameplay and every else after: So the game supports VR and Desktop so you can play VR, a friend can play in desktop mode, which is amazing and we need more games like this.

Doing so, it's based around ghostly investigating. You spawn in, after your've purchased a whole bunch of items and then set to 5mins before the ghost stuff starts, it's your time to quickly invenstigate and find the cold spots, marks, anything strange before the different type of ghost appears and then really causes spooky stuff.

You can die and when you do it's freaky, but when you do die, you can see the ghost spawn and chase or stalk a friend. Which is helpful but you cannot do anything so yeah. Try to survive!

There is talking in the game, you can communicate with the ghost with a variety of commands found here:  https://gamesgds.com/phasmophobia-all-questions-and-answers-ghosts-ouija-spirit-box/ - Which is a super helpful page.

It has some neat features like saying the ghosts name toooo many times angers them and they come to kill you in the most freaky way. It's all down to get in, get solved, put the information in your journal, not get to freaked out because it does effect your character sanity and then get out, end mission for cash. - That all being said sounds easy but trust me, it's not!

The game does not have any jump scares with anything jumping out to grab you. It's massively atmosphere like paintings falling, items being moved or thrown, doors opening and closing etc.. You do hear and see the spirits and they are freaky but it's how they appear, which is why I do not want to spoil anything but if you want a spooky ghost game to play with friends and something to really scare you, better than anything that has been released recently. This is 100% the game and 100% recommend.

Also, the devs are active to reply and update the game so I massively suggest checking this gem out!

I do have some problems with the game, but that is to be expected with an early access game. It needs some work on in game mechanics like placing things down, or lighting candles if your not in VR. Sometimes when placing down things, it'll clip through objects or the floor and then we cant use the item for the rest of the game which in turn causes us to lose out on finding certain evidence. I totally skipped the tutorial and had no idea how to play this game, so I highly recommend doing the tutorial. 

One last thing to say, running isn't always the best option, and remember to stay calm.

Basically Payday 2 but instead of robbing banks, you're hunting spooky ghosts.
10/10

Completely and utterly pants-wetting. No game has ever gone the same and there is a ton of variety in levels already. The best part is you're not alone in being terrified out of your wits and all other players run away screaming with you at the same time, usually resulting in prematurely ending the round because everyone is far too terrified to continue the round to collect whatever evidence we couldn't find.

Good game. A game of speculation over who is hiding inside the truck looking at the cameras while everyone else suffers to the might of a ghost called Margaret Anderson. An intense game especially when you get towards the larger maps such as the Asylum and the School where you are forced to split up and potentially meet your own death. Overall, good game, good community.

The game isn't scary at all, it's just random and makes you go like "wtf is going on? why isn't sh*t working properly?" most of the time.

This game does not tell you almost anything about how the game works. It's 95% trial and error.

What is considered a "spirit box evidence"? Is it just hearing a voice? Is it seeing/hearing something happen after you told it to "give you a sign"? You will never know, because it's not properly explained.

How exactly does the crucifix and smudges work? You will never know because the game gives you next to no information about it.

You can only hold 3 items at a time, which is incredibly dumb even from a balance point of view. Apparently backpacks or pockets weren't invented yet.

The descriptions of the various ghosts are too vague most of the time to tell the difference between them, especially if you didn't get any evidence for 10 minutes.

Half the times the ghost will spawn inside of you and you will instantly die, without having any chance to hide. And half the time you take a photo of the ghost it doesn't work.

Oh yeah, and if you're talking to your friends on discord, prepare to never get any result from the spirit box, because apparently you need to hold the "local voice chat" button for it to work in multiplayer... And of course, the game doesn't tell you anything about it.

Also you're at a huge disadvantage if playing on desktop, compared to VR, because why not.

This game is a buggy mess, I'd barely give it a 6/10. I recommend it if you can stomach early access problems.
GOod

Absolutely a GEM of a game. This game REALLY shines when you figure everything out IN-GAME. If you keep that mystery and all the smoke and mirrors behind the scenes a secret and just immerse yourself in the game its absolutely amazing man. My name is Zak Bagans. I never believed in ghosts until I came face to face with one. So I set out on a quest to capture what I once saw onto video....With no big camera crews following us around, I am joined only by my fellow investigators Nick Groff and our equipment tech Arron Goodwin. The three of us will travel to some of the most highly active paranormal locations, where we will spend an entire night, being locked down from dusk until dawn....Raw...Extreme...These are our Ghost Adventures.

Good:
- The ghosts react to what you say on your microphone
- Good variety of tools and ghosts

Bad:
- It's not scary
- The flashlight sucks
- You have to buy tools. To buy tools you have to complete mission objectives. The game sends you on missions where you have to use tools you don't have for the mission objectives... 
- KB+M users can only take 3 tools while VR users can take 4 and they also move way slower. Why?
I've soiled my pants 3 times already within 6 hours... 10/10 would soil again.

Camera ... Check
Radio ... Check
Flashlight ... Check
Crucifix ... Check
Diaper ... Check

...and here we go!

What's most interesting about this game is how the design/balance so accurately emulates the experience of ghost hunting. Nothing seems to be working, until the shit hits the fan. So much information is hidden from the player that the mystery stays palpable after hours of replaying similar missions. Especially with a VR set and the excellent diagetic voice chat, the scripting of each match never fails to create memorable moments. 

Also - props to the developer for launching with such (relatively) well-done VR support. Wish I could access my options in the in-game lobby....

It's a cheesy ghost hunting game, using the dubious tools and methods that ghost hunters use. So all in all give it a go and play it. 

Just a side note I've bought 4 copies of this game 1 for myself and 3 as gifts, it's great to play with friends and super enjoyable.

We were talking about the idea of making this game available on the workshop so players can create their own haunted areas, and ghosts to tackle. This game has so much potential, and hopefully it continues getting even better as time goes on. One of my favorite games of this year by far, I can't wait to see what happens with it in the future.

I'll be the first to tell you i am a big puss when its comes to horror games and the genre alike but putting that aside i have to say "What a game" this is without a doubt the most immersive and terrifying game i have ever played the atmosphere each map has just cant be described at how much it will make your spine tingle the hairs on your neck stand up how sweaty your palms will get or the shear pounding of your heart in your ears. I wont try to spoil gameplay wise too much but i will say even with the safety timer still up you never truly feel safe even while its counting down, the biggest part that does me in is situations where the ghost will only communicate when people are alone, like that already isnt the biggest red flag to be thrown up, along with maps that are massive in size. To make a long story short you cant put into words what the situations are like in this game its almost too difficult to give any kind of an explanation with all the variety that can happen with no experience (in my time of playing at least) always being the same. All in all i would say this game will be one to watch for sure the dev, yes you heard it correctly one dev. with how he keeps improving this game. If you are very easily scared or even a big brave dog this game does have something for everyone going back to earlier you will know how i am with the genre of games and even i still had a fun time with friends playing this. My final thoughts is: this game is actually a blast to play, didnt realize me and my friends played for about 5 hours straight, if you are easily scared its better to play with friends rather than alone, the biggest part is to keep an eye on this game because not only is the price of 13 dollars well worth the admission, its also easy to see that the dev put a lot of time into this game to make it what it is so i will say my hat is off you sir nicely done

Do I recommend this?  It's a little hard to when I just almost had a heart attack.

Sitting in the bathroom on the floor, cramped between the bathtub and the sink, this particular ghost doesn't respond to groups.  So I had to be alone.  We needed one more piece of evidence to complete our investigation.  It was either orbs, which we hadn't seen, or a response through the spirit box.  I had the box.  So there I am, in the small cramped bathroom.  My companions has wandered down the hall away from me.  I sat there alone, door open and I could see down the hall.  I was incredibly shaken as I'd just been chased out of that same bathroom by this little girl ghost, Lisa Moore.  I did capture a photo!  Our first.

There I was.  I turned off my flashlight, only able to see the faint light from the outside creeping into the small window.  Okay, time to talk.  "Lisa, are you hear?"  I could see my breath in the freezing air.  This was definitely where she haunted.  "Lisa Moore, can you show yourself?"  Suddenly the lights flicker on and off.  Then the door shuts on me.  Knowing she was close, I started to panic.  I couldn't see her again after the first sighting!  "Please don't be here..." I thought to myself.  Then a growling hiss shot out at me from the darkness!  My heart burst through my chest!  I couldn't stay cramped in that tiny room with her, not again!  I crawled to the door, yanked it open and ran like the dickens out of the house!  I couldn't go back in there, ever again.

I've played all of the "scary" games.  99% are not scary and go with cheap jump scares.  Fatal Frame was a difficult one.  Fatal Frame 2 is the only one I couldn't play, at least alone.  This game, I dare say put the scare on another level.  It was so scary to me that I'm not sure I dare recommend this game!  I swear for a moment my heart hurt after that encounter.  Thinking of having to do it again, I just didn't want to.  But that's why you're hear!  So yes, it does what you're looking for!

There are some issues, and I doubt they'll be changed in Early Access if ever.  We did maybe 5 investigations and they all went the same way.  Go in, set up a couple of things, get some evidence, get killed by a ghost.  Even though they were different types of ghosts, it was the same routine.  It would be neater if each investigation was VERY different, maybe solve a murder mystery, find the lost buried body, help a ghost cross over, maybe do an exorcism.  I doubt this game will become that.  So it will likely get repetitive and loose it's fear luster quickly.

The animations are crappy.  I doubt they'll ever improve.  Sounds are good, but there needs to be more variety...maybe a kid laughing as it runs away (maybe I haven't played enough to hear these).  Controls are a little quirky, having up to 3 MAIN controls for items.  I think they really took VR into consideration with these.  Menu systems are also quirky, probably made for VR.

So, it's early access, it shows, and most early access games really don't improve.  Sadly, I doubt this one will improve much either.  I hope I'm wrong because this game does have a unique flavor that I hope to see realized.  It's great for a handful of hours of terror.  I expect it to get old pretty fast and won't offer anything afterward.

Don't really review games all that much but I am super impressed with this one. I've always watched ghost shows and having the opportunity to play a game that has the equipment that is used was super exciting. I was worried that it could be limited since it is Early Access but the different type of ghosts and different ways to find evidence puts a lot of variety to it so it doesn't get old.

Probably the biggest one of my complaints is investigating big maps. Since you have a sanity bar and the less sanity you have the more the ghost could kill you, and with different ways to lose your sanity (i.e. complete darkness) it takes a while to find the ghost's room and locate your evidence. But honestly, this could be due to me not understanding the game fully right now and maybe my friends and I are approaching it differently. But regardless, it's a small complaint and something that won't ruin the game for me at all. Another small complaint is the spirit box/voice recognition. Again, it could be me not doing it properly but I don't seem to have a lot of success using it which that is one of my favorite equipment to use.

I can't wait to see what kind of updates they give this game cause it is already so much fun. It would be cool if they allowed more players for those bigger maps but honestly, I can't think of anything else they could add (besides new locations and equipment). 9/10 I would give this game.

I bought this game and honestly, I thought I would be bored after a while but I played it for 6.7 hours straight and when I quit I was not even bored. It's a really fun game. You are supposed to figure out what type of ghost is haunting the house without dying. It's a lot harder than I thought and I think that's what makes it so fun. I definitely recommend playing it with a couple of friends, because that makes the game more fun. The only bad thing about it (it's not really that bad) is that you can only play up to 4 players. It would be fun to be able to play with even more friends but it's still a great game.

This review is just gonna be some suggestions i have about the game, granted, after 20 hours of playing, I still love it and its the best use of $10 I have spent in awhile.

1. Holy water would be a great addition to the game
2. Smudge sticks need to be nerfed, you can prevent a hunt for the entirety of a game if you bring 4 and have one person with a lighter and a stick at all times.
3. Add more ghosts and add more REAL lore! i am a huge Supernatural fan, and I would love to put some of that knowledge into the game.
4. Add more distinctive traits to each ghost. The base is a great start, but I feel like there is something missing to just getting into the routine of checking this and that and then running around looking for stuff to take pictures of.
5. The Supernatural fan in me wants to be able to hunt the ghosts, not just figure out what the heck they are. This is your game, although I would love to have a "storyline" to each different hunt. Maybe starting out with a "figure out wth it is" mission, then a setup mission to set up equipment/acquire equipment in order to find the ghost, finally, a hunt mission. Understandably, this would change the entirety of the game, although I thought it was a really cool concept.
6. More items! I hate using the same 5ish core items to figure out what type of ghost i'm looking for.
7. More of a fear factor. Don't get me wrong, for the first 10 hours i was scared shitless lol, but after that my buddies and I kinda just run around, find the room, set up everything, figure out what it is, and leave. VERY LITTLE fear factor considering we have smudge sticks at the ready after the 2 minute timer runs out, not to mention scattering crucifixes to the point where we only get maybe one hunt each game on Professional difficulty.
8. Something more to work towards. This further elaborates on everything said above. The game is find ghost, maybe get scared, get paid, rinse repeat. What am I working for? money? idc, after 5 hours, all my friends had every item in the game and now we very very very rarely die, and even if we do, just a few hundred bucks and we have everything back. I desperately want something to work towards and I want an endgame that allows me to pour hundreds of hours into this game.
9. The visuals of the ghosts need a lot of work. If I'm hunting a wraith, I should not see a mf ghost walking on the ground towards me. Each ghost should have certain characteristics that stay the same with different models(maybe based on how they died in combination with gender/age) 
10. More sound effects! I used to get scared by the little breathing in my ear, but ive become accustommed to it. Obviously this will come with time, but a variety is definitely needed in a horror game.
11. LET ME SEE WHAT MY FRIENDS SEE!!!! In a party of 4, most of the time we will all need to be sitting in front of the monitor watching the same camera in order to see an orb. Most of the time, only one person will see the orb out of all 4 of us! Same thing goes for ghosts. Only 2 of 4 people will see a ghost in the same spot. This ruins some of the immersion for me, for I want to be scared when my friends are. This also applies to sound effects, we'll all be in the same room and one will ask if we heard a footstep or something and nobody else does. Definitely a change i want to see as soon as possible, for it is a big immersion factor when playing with friends.
12. Going off #1, I want to see a lot more items in the game with more organization options for moving things across the map. IDK, this will happen with time and I don't really have a solid idea for it, but I'm curious as to what you guys think.
13. More maps! this will come with time as well, but I want to see more 1-2 player maps for when my buddies aren't on and I dont want to play with randos.

I'm sure I could name a thousand more things I would love to see added to the game, but I love this game and I love the concept. I have so much faith in this dev team to push out more great updates to make the game long-lasting. I understand that this game is early access, but hopefully we will see some changes that allow the game to blow up in a way that people can pour hours into it. To spooky atmosphere, goosebumps, chills, whispers in your ears, and also seeing a quite wide variety of pretty scary looking ghost.

 The game does a really good job of spooking you without any cheesy jump scares or basically telling you that you should be scared. It has that atmosphere that gives you the thought of "I shouldn't be here" or "the ghost is already mad at me" I genuinely thought I wouldn't be playing this game for this long but it keeps on bringing you back for more. 

The in-game chat is so well done and well put together. I would seriously recommend that you mute yourself in discord etc whenever you are playing this game with friends it adds that slight part where you might actually be alone in this one room where your friends are somewhere else it just keeps the game spooky and fresh. With how much the dev has been fixing the game and adding quick little hot fixes, I really think this game is gonna take off and have a really good community.

My friends and I have been playing a few hours now. We've managed to finish out a few jobs with a number of jump scares. Very well developed for the atmosphere. Only complaint I have is the loud annoying ambient background noise while inside the houses. Addition: We've also noticed that the standard Flashlight should probably be a default toggle option instead of 1 of the 3 inventory items. It takes up needed space and if you're holding other items, the flashlight sits on your shoulder anyway and can be toggled on and off with T. The Stronger Flashlight is understandably an inventory item since it is 'larger' in both size and light radius.
I haven't literally screamed out in fear since I was a child. I am 32 now. I am really glad I decided to buy this game after watching IGP. Something we've noticed though. Once you get the hang of how the game works, you can easily knock out most of the optional objectives and the entire job in just a few minutes. Also, we have run into an issue where we will collect 3 pieces of evidence and it will not show us a possible ghost type. We then have to risk increased chances of getting hunted to find a 4th piece of evidence to try and find out what we're dealing with. Along with this, we will gather 3 pieces, get the ghost type, turn in, and it will be the wrong type.
Example: One of the last jobs we did came up with EMF Lv 5, Freezing Temperature, and Ghost Writing. However, it didn't show us a possible ghost match. So, even though we were hunted twice with increasing activity the longer we were there, I risked my life to place a camera in her room. Found a Ghost Orb. Swapped Ghost Writing with Orb and it popped up Phantom. We turned in and the game told us it was in fact a Yurei.
Is there something we are missing or is this one of the downsides of Early Access?
In conclusion, the game is fantastic and we're enjoying the crap out of it. Brown pants and all! 10/10

I recommend this game, it has the potential to be the best Horror experience in gaming, and the "Overwhelmingly Positive" review score would have you believe this is a better game than it actually is. 

This is as rough as a newly released Early Access game can be. If your group is anything like mine, you're going to spend 30 minutes just trying to get everyone in the same lobby and able to hear each other speak. If you're using the Valve Index like me, your experience will take you back to 2017 archaic VR gaming. Let me break down what problems I would like to see Kinetic Games address, and give my own positive experience:

-You must allow the Tutorial to be completed in co-op. 
-In lobby options needs to be expanded. Often friends will have to drop out just to change keybindings or audio settings. See the bit about getting the party to hear eachother above. 
-VR must be improved. Finger tracking needs to be added eventually. There needs to be a clearer indication to the player that they are speaking over the "radio" by bringing their left hand up to their ear.
-The objective/progression systems needs to be improved. Your progression is tied to how many objectives you clear, but I had many cases where I couldn't even accomplish a single objective in an entire mission. An item you'd need for an objective is often behind a level requirement and a cash requirement. It makes the early game extra rough, when you understand it the least. 
-Movement is slow and clunky. 

I still recommend the game for the insane emergent gameplay. My team is trying to get a photo of this ghost, and we hear it stomping up from the basement. Already something that would brown my pants, is also invisible but a shadow cast by my flashlight. My EKG meter is going nuts. Then, everything stops, as... You should play the game, as this is a spoiler. The point is I freaked the F out. It is some of the scariest shit I've seen in a game, and you're denying yourself the same experience. 

Buy this game, get frustrated with the lack of polish as you brute force yourself through the game, crap yourself, put the game down, forget about the game for a few months as it's patched and vastly improved, come back, crap yourself again.

I love horror, and this is the scariest video game horror experience I've ever had, hands down. 10/10 easily

Lets set the scene. Me and a friend had done some work and figured out the ghost was a poltergeist, however we had an objective left "Stop a spirit's hunt by using a crucifix". We were going back in, and we had to anger this thing somehow. We went into the room the ghost was haunting and got everything ready; a spirit box to communicate, a crucifix and a flashlight. If only we'd brought brown underwear.  We went near the lockers and opened them up, ready to hide in. It was time.
We got near the ghost box and my friend said "Show yourself".... Silence... In defeat and disappointment I taunted the spirit. "P***y..."
As soon as I said that, the lights went out. Oh no, footsteps. Out of nowhere this old man with a hatched begins striding towards us from the darkness, evil in his eyes. We both panic and run for the locker, fumbling and dropping our equipment. Squeezing into the same tight space, we slam the door shut and pull out our crucifixes. I'd dropped mine in fear, however luckily my friend still had his. We were safe

Or so I thought...

After the activity had died down we clambered out the locker and picked up our equipment, we were outa there! However, the ghost had other plans. As soon as we headed for the way out, the lights went out again. My friend was certain "Everything was fine!", however I wasn't so convinced. As I fumbled around with the door (pushed not pulled), I heard an unnatural sound, and his footsteps getting closer. A quick glance over my shoulder and there he was, coming right for me. I've never tried to glitch through a door faster in my life. He then disappeared into thin air, almost like he was scaring us out. I ran like there was no tomorrow, I was outa there! We both made it home in one piece, though in reality we were forever scarred.

~~Pros~~
- Both VR and Monitor support.
- Singleplayer and multiplayer support, the game still playing perfectly in both.
- Concept easy to pick up and understand, however new things constantly keep you on your toes (e.g. Mannequin moved between missions of the same map, freaking me out and mixing things up a little)
- Game really knows how to build up tension, like to the next level. Not seen any jumpscares as of yet.
- Voice recognition works and really adds to the immersion. Speaking to the ghosts and waiting for a response puts this game in a league of its own. (Note: mentioning that you're scared/or something is creepy at any part of the game will make the ghost more active, almost like its teasing you.)
- More unique maps like schools and asylums? Haven't touched them yet but damn they look amazing.
- variety of ghosts and spooks, have only experienced a tiny part of the game and I am already over the moon.
- Setting up cameras and watching them from the van is surprisingly cool and fun.

~~Cons~~
- Most of my problems with this game are glitches and minor things, which are to be expected with an early access title. (e.g. Dropping an item on the keyboard in the van or the car in the garage makes it impossible to pick back up.)
- INDEX SUPPORT PRETTY PLEASE (Being able to control my fingers will make everything so much more immersive)
- I can see the same maps over and over again getting repetitive. Maybe a randomly generated house would be a good idea? Keep things fresh. 
- Walking in VR, I keep getting stuck on the floor and other invisible things. Really annoying when trying to run away from something spooki.
- Constantly needing to buy new underwear.

We were sent to investigate a ghost haunting an abandoned high school. 

A strategy is formed: split up, place sound sensors on the east and west side of the ground and first floor. However, our radios turn to static as our flashlights flicker. One man separated, my buddy and I hid in the corner of a class room, huddling behind my crucifix. 

Our lost radio contacts means we can't contact our friend in the truck monitoring our progress. We think it's all clear, we step outside, start walking to the exit; our flashlights start flickering. 

We're being hunted again. We retreat to our corner classroom to huddle behind our crucifix, as footsteps get louder and louder outside the door. We don't dare speak. Finally, a chance occurs to escape by darting out of a fire escape and across the school grounds.

We made it. We're back at the truck, and learn that the one friend who got separated didn't make it. Reunited with our friend in the truck, we decide to keep calm and carry on. 

As we re-enter the school, our plans come to a halt. Our fallen colleague, who got separated earlier, is lying dead a few paces from the door. So close, yet so far.

Our flashlights flicker again. We're being hunted again.

We were not prepared for intermediate high school.

10/10 would get PTSD again.

So this game is in early access which is partially why I'll be giving it a yes as the Devs have a lot of space to expand and improve. The game is a lot of fun, can be shockingly tense and scary despite being multiplayer, and it overall a great time. If the premise interests you I'd say you'll have a great time. However I want to go into depth where I think the game can improve so the devs can see that little piece of feedback.

First, repetition and longevity:
The game begins so strong, and it's a lot of fun. However within a few hours, and once you figure out certain things about certain items, it becomes routine to an almost saddening degree. This is how every hunt will go, regardless of spirit type. Scout location looking for EMF or temp readings, upon locateing the ghosts "room" drop a crusifix inside of the room and run back to trunk, unload as much junk as you want in the room, scanners, cameras, etc. Then proceed to antagonize the ghost either by being in the room or talking to it until you complete objectives and know what it is. That's it. No matter the spirit the core gameplay becomes identicle, the crusifix is your get out of jail free card, when it's down you can't be killed, and with that in mind it makes the gameplay extremely straight forward. However I don't think just weakening that item would fix anything, in fact I'd argue changing only it would make the whole game worse, and that is because...

The spirits. This style of game is going to rely on one thing more than anything else, and that's the enemies. The ghosts are what provide the gameplay and the variety, and right now it's simply not there. I saw the list of spirits and my mind went wild with the possibilities for what they could all be, how they could act, the amazing, weird things I might encounter! I was wrong. The spirits all act extremely similar if not the exact same. If they manifest theres a VERY small number of ways they can look, none unique to themselves as far as I could tell. It's always a bloodied person walking or a shadow person walking. That's really it no matter what mythical spirit you're brushing up against. This lack of variety along with how little the difference is in how they act in gameplay is truely a shame as without the variety in the spirits it makes that core gameplay feel even more drastically samey as you grow accustomed to the things that can and will happen. The only real differences are how often one spirit or another may do something. Otherwise they all do the same things, just some more than others, and the difference can be hard to pin down because of this homogenized style. This needs fixed, badly.

The other half of this equation is something more nuanced that I don't know how to label. Let's call it...

Gameplay focus/rewards and difficulty

So this is also something the game feels direly lost about. My friends and I played for 8 hours all told, in those 8 hours we only had a single person die. It was on our very first hunt. Since then not only has noone died, noone even came close. After a while the spirits begin to feel almost toothless as you understand the mechanics, which thus far don't go too deep, and realize what different signs mean. Now this may not sound like a problem, "Of course I'd die less as I get better!" But that isn't how it felt, we hadn't really gone from clueless to pros after that single first hunt. It's just too easy to survive, the spirits often feeling, as said before, toothless. But I know why this is. You lose all items but the default ones you get given to you that you brought on a mission upon death. So the devs have gone with a system of high punishment, low reward, and lower threat because of it. It's almost how minecraft treats death. Sure you lose everything when you die, but you will basically never die if you're careful.

I don't think this style fits this game. UPon winning a hunt, say a small hunt, you get base 40 dollars, plus an extra 20 if you got a photo of the spirit on still image camera. 60 bucks for hunts that can take some time. That's not enough enough for 2 doses of pills to restore sanity (which are consumables and are spent if you die or not). It buys you one video camera with no tripod. What I'm saying is the payout to missions is almost comically low to the points you can't restock lost goods all that fast should you die and lose a lot. I currently take enough gear into missions with friends that were I to die it would take me literally HOURS of real life work in the game to re-earn what I'd lose for one failure. Now, I understand what the devs hoped would come of this system, they hoped the threat would increase tension and make it feel scarier, making the threat of death a genuine concern. But that's now how it feels in practise. In practise it instead means that I just play it safe, follow the formula mentioned in a prior point, and never really have to worry. The system meant to add tension instead adds none, really.

The solution here I think is to revamp this structure. To begin with a game of this nature having some kind of rogue like/survival reward structure simply makes no sense to me. You're playing because it's fun to hunt ghosts, not to buy one more camera every hour. But I also think revamping this system would be important for one other reason; if the punishment for death is less dramatic, then you can ramp up the spectral aggression which would make the core reason you're ACTUALLY here more fun! There's a few ways they could go about changing this. one is to massively improve payouts for missions so replenishing lost goods isn't hard after a death. Another would be to simply not take things from players upon death, perhaps you only lose items if EVERYONE in the session dies, but not if only you personally do. Whatever form this change would take I think this is extremely important because being able to ramp up the activity of the enemies AI would make for much more exciting gameplay, without feeling pointlessly punishing since, as I said, the current progression system doesn't do anything to make the game feel better to play, it's more of a hinderance and a bother.

Overall though this is a strong foundation. I wish the devs well, but those 3 kind of points are key to making this from "good for a few hours" to "Great, let's play this a ton!".

The enemies are the crown jewel of this kind of game. Make them unique, visually, mechanically, structurally, push what makes each one special.

The core loop is too similar hunt to hunt, add variety, drive decisions that will pull players into different action than simply camping one room of a house.

And restructure or remove the needless progression system since it's presence has knock on effects into the gameplay that can not be ignored.

OH and PS. increase the damned move speed. It makes the game absolutely unplayable on lager maps, takes it from a fun, spooky experience to a torturous slog. The fact there even IS a sprint button is baffleing as it's only a fraction faster than not sprinting. Make the current "sprinting" the default run, and then make an actually quick moving sprint, as it is there is NO reason not to hold down sprint for the ENTIRE game which is wildly uncomfortable  over extended periods, and considering there is absolutely no downside to sprinting that just leaves even more reason to perpetually crawl at the "sprinting" pace. Please improve movespeed. I know VR means you can't full on rocket sprint but the current speed is painful.

Already a promising game in early access.

Even with plans to introduce more content in the future, the current set of equipment, maps, and ghost types allow for near infinite replayability. Earning money and leveling up based on identifying the ghost and completing optional tasks enable the player to be more tactical as they continue to play. A new player will start to recognize the flow of the game, starting with preparation and then evidence gathering, in a way that will force them to take some risks, let their Sanity drop, and, if they're particularly unlucky, get killed by whatever ghost they're trying to find. However, the unpredictable nature of each Contract, as well as the limited visibility and mobility of the players, ensures an experience ranging from spooky to terrifying every single time, both on desktop and in VR. Nothing has ever made my heart race so quickly as rushing out of a farmhouse after seeing a ghost, only to hear my friend scream through his radio as he was killed, listening to him get cut off as his dot on the map vanished and Total Activity dropped from 10 to 0.

There is room for improvement, though. The VR controls are a bit difficult to use at first, and some other issues arise, such as not being able to pick up items from the ground if the player's height isn't finely calibrated. Additionally, the tutorial will require an update at some point. Despite being given the location of the training ghost, a lack of labels on the map display inside the truck leads to confusion if a ghost isn't in an obvious location such as Kitchen or Living Room. Labels may also need to be added for larger maps such as the High School and the Asylum which have many similar looking hallways and rooms, and possibly to all maps in general to help communication between random players, who would be more likely to go off on their own without coordinating.

Overall, Phasmophobia provides an enjoyable ghost hunting experience, which will only become more entertaining and replayable as it progresses through early access, and eventually reaches full release.

Got convinced to play this game in VR with my friend, lets call him Danny.
Danny and I enter a little house, with only one floor.
We figure out that the ghost is in the kitchen.
Danny tells me to wait in the kitchen as he would grab extra supplies.
I wait around the kitchen, but as Danny leaves the house, lights slowly turn off.
I begin screaming Danny's name as I move towards the door.
The door is locked... death.png incoming
I fall to ground as I scream loudly.
A figure comes up to me as I scream even louder. 
It disappears and the door opens behind me.
Still laying down, I make my way outside the house still shaking and nearly crying.
Danny looks at me...
Danny laughs...

If your friends are like Danny, buy the game. It is so much fun.
If your friends aren't like Danny, buy the game anyway!
If you don't have any friends, buy it anyway!!!

In conclusion, buy the game.

Does not work out of the box with Index controllers. Game is currently designed for other controllers and has finicky movement with the thumb touchpad that has to be manually disabled in Steam VR controller settings. Game also doesn't register the Index controllers grip well, and has to be set to an awkward toggle. Game also has no way in game to adjust your height, and currently has me floating about a foot off the floor so if I drop an item, I can't pick it back up. My height is correct in other VR games and there I can properly touch the floor. Game is currently in early access, but states it supports the Index, despite these issues. Will update the review if issues are fixed.

The game is absolutely amazing for the price. There's a lot of variety in ghost types, evidence gathering and determining what type of ghost is hunting you. In terms of jumps scares, it isn't your typical "open an door and jump out" kinda scare, it's much more psychological than that. Say if you start at Intermediate difficulty, a lot of the time, the ghost will give signs like EMF readings, temperatures, very subtle to begin with. However depending on how you play, i.e. calling the name out a lot, or using a ouija board a lot, it can change very quickly.

The game is absolutely worth it for the £9 I bought it for and it keeps me entertained for hours with my pals. It's amazing with the voice detection feature too, to the point the ghost actually listens to practically everything you say. No level is the same either, it's always a different ghost, different spawn, it moves, it flies, it groans at you, it hunts you...

My best moment so far is definitely when we were searching a house for a ghost, and a buddy of mine came along saying "he's in that room", to which I replied stubbornly "no he's not in there lmao", buuuut the moment I opened the door and walked in, I heard a groan in my left ear so I quickly turned to see where it was from, next thing you know, my mouse flew across my desk and my heart was racing. Makes a grown man scared, frfr.

I would recommend this game, but it does need more interactive from the ghost though, sometimes it can be a little bit dry or boring. It would be cool if the ghost can move chairs or toys or at least something, so it can us the spook. It's good game, but please please let the ghost be more active and do something to not make it so boring. Also should add like ghost voices or crying too. Overall, good game, need more things from the ghost to make it more fun.

Pros: 
- Relive your favorite 90s Paranormal investigators TV shows through their eyes in a world where ghosts are definitively real.
- Co-op does not make this game less scary but most certainly makes it funnier. 
- More atmospheric horror than jumpy. 
- Will shave years off your lifespan.

Cons:
- Can be visually glitchy; occassional awkard movement and animation might tear you out of immersion.
- Not sure if intentional but apparently friends don't always see what you see. (This is a pro if it is intentional)
- It's E.A. You'll run into some funny weird bugs: like when you die but you still have full control of your character but can't interact w/ things.
- Cops might get called to check up on you and knock aggressively on your door at 1 AM if your neighbors hear you screaming for your life in genuine terror. Infinitely more horrifying than playing the game itself.

Because the game makes you feel actual anxiety and fear. There is no jump scares, no sudden flashes of adrenaline that quickly fade. The tension and axiety build up as the time passes for each mission, cumulating in a couple hellishly freaking moments towards end where things start flashes, and potentially a friend dies.

Its simplicity and focus on atmosphere over things that are actually scary make it an A+ execution in my book and im quite excited to see where the game ends up with future content.
