A very good game with surprising replayability. I thought this game would show all it had to offer and become boring after a couple of hours but it seems it's quite possible to play it for a much longer time.
You're not jump scared very often, but it's scary in a much better way which I'm going to try to explain. Imagine this:
You're running around a house trying to find evidence about what type of ghost you're up against (Main task, lot's of exp if you're correct) and suddenly your flashlight starts flashing a lot, this means the ghost is out to get you, and since you don't know what type it is, you don't know how to protect yourself. If you manage to reach the exit, tough luck, it's locked until the ghost stops hunting you. Also consider that some ghosts run faster than you do. If you have an EMF reader, and it's the right type of ghost, it's going to hit it's highest reading and beep loudly as the ghost chases you. Maybe you had a thermometer which could show a negative celsius, meaning the ghost is close. There is also a spirit box you can use to ask the ghosts questions, and if you're lucky, you'll get an answer. A UV flashlight will show you handprints on the doors, and a camera show the invisible ones hunting you. There are a lot of different tools to use, and only three of them will yield results as each ghost has three evidences you must find. This is the charm of the game, as you don't know which ones will give you what you need. You could be hunted even if the EMF reader shows nothing, or the temperature is normal, if it's a certain type of ghost.
And here's the big deal, you got big reason to survive, as you'll get far less exp, and also lose all the items you brought with you to the mission if you die!
May the tools be with you!

Very fun and terrifying. The entire atmosphere is what makes you shiver with fear, and the unknowing of when something could jump out or speak to you. Very immersive for people who have always wanted to do IRL Ghost Hunting as well. Voice communications sound crystal clear, with no issues. 

Negatives:
It is hard to complete objectives in the Abandoned School, the map is super big, and if you don't have big enough balls to walk around on your own, you won't complete much. The difficulty for that map needs to be higher.
Ghosts need to start scaling with different maps. Sanity can drop very fast on different, and larger maps, making it difficult to complete objectives once again. 
BALANCE. This game still needs some good balancing in general.
Some bugs need to be fixed. 

Overall, this game is on the fast track of becoming popular, it is 100% worth it if you love being scared with your friends, or have the balls to do this alone.

Another pleasant surprise indie game success! In the desert of co-op horror games this definitely at first looked like another run-of-the-mill asset flip collecting pages and running away from Slender-man type monster. Very happy to learn that this game really focuses on atmosphere and slow build and burn spoopiness. 

Definitely rough around the edges in terms of UI, UX but the gameplay functionality for a team of 4 friends has already provided more hours of entertainment for the $13 they asked for. Just in time for the Halloween season. I really hope this blows up like Fall Guys and Among Us or at least gets the devs enough to keep going and keep adding more and more haunts, equipment, investigations. 

The greatest mechanic is the voice in game speak with ghosts function which really adds to the atmosphere. For those playing on DISCORD or any other voice app, do yourselves a favor and mute on Discord and restrict yourselves to ONLY the in-game voice.

Nothing is worse than hearing your teammate on the in-game walkie go already I'm going into the basement... then radio silence for the rest of the game as the lights flicker.

LOVE IT.

For VR-Players, this is a phenomenal co-op experience--even in its Early Access state. Hopping into an online session is not only incredibly easy, but also everyone who seems to play this game has the same positive, community vibe that comes from knowing we're all just as easily terrified as each other.

You'll have many frights, but also many laughs along the way. Can't wait to see how it is when fully-developed, as a game like this already deserves to be a VR hit.

Good game, few bugs as to be expected. Seem to be patched fairly quickly when brought up to the dev team.

Would recommend 6/10 atm. In some time could be a great buy, lots of potential for future missions and new places to explore.

Super fun game, really spooky and requires both communication with teammates, and brain-storming.

I really hope the developer continues to work on this game and doesn't just take the money he's earned and stop developing, things like adding different variations of spirits/demons and maybe making the AI a little better.

Sometimes it seems like the particular entity you're dealing with won't be reflective of the evidence you're getting, unless the evidence gathered isn't always indicative of what you're dealing with.

Overall a really fun game to play with friends.

I've played it a bit and I've gotta say, especially for early access, it's a fantastic game!
Ghost hunting, naturally exaggerated in the psychological horror style where not only do you get a ton of activity, but, naturally, the ghosts will try to kill you every now and then.

Tutorial covers basic button layout, but does not cover how to survive a hunt. Basically, if your flashlight is blinking, find a closet, locker, *something* to hide in, and hope for the best. If none are available, then run to whatever room you can find and try to get as many doors between you and the spirit as possible. And keep your flashlight off, if you can.

I am having a massive, game-breaking issue every now and then where I'll be disconnected by client timeout every game I join and I've no clue when it's safe to try again without being booted halfway in the game. This is very unfortunate as I've yet to see any "how to"s to fix it. I'm keeping it updated, as best I can, but it proves unreliable often.
When I do successfully play a game all the way through, though, and up until being booted on unsuccessful games, I am very satisfied with the game. I'm very hard to scare and even I find it eerie as all get-out. If you have a friend who is disappointed by most horror games they play like myself, have them try this, they may not be truly "scared" but they'll likely be kept on edge. Can't wait to see what the 'official release' of this early access game has to offer!
Before I buzz off, for all those new players looking for 'amateur' difficulty but finding games hosted as 'intermediate' or 'professional', the only difference is your grace-period when you enter the house.
Amateur: 5 minutes till the spirit will periodically hunt you
Intermediate: 2 minutes till the spirit will periodically hunt you
Professional: Its fair game from the get-go. Watch your back.
Beyond that, I am sorry to say, amateur is as dangerous as professional if you're trying to take photos of the ghost or stop a hunt with the crucifix (it has to be in the spirit's room and near the spirit BEFORE it enters hunt mode, otherwise it won't work)

It does a great job of making you feel like you're an actual paranormal investigator. You have the freedom to choose how you want to use your tools to identify the various hauntings, and it integrates voice recognition for calling to spirits, which is fun.

The levels are super creepy, with dark corridors and alarming noises throughout. Phasmophobia trains you to fear the dark, for good reason, and it only gets worse as the job goes on, eventually descending into madness and confrontation with evil forces.

I almost shit my pants in the tutorial. So do with that what you will.

In a nutshell, it's a bit of investigation, sprinkled with unsettling atmosphere throughout dark locations where the tension is so thick you can cut it with a knife. The hallways very quickly become claustrophobic as you start hearing creaks and groans from what you believe is "an old house settling in for the night". Then the spooks start seeping in. 

Did you turn that light on? Was that door open when we got here? ...is there someone behind me? The 'ghost box' goes off telling you "Yes". Why are the lights flickering? We need to get out... 'CAN'T RUN, CAN'T RUN' suddenly appears over and over on your notebook. Was that your freezing breath over my shoulder?  Watch your sanity.

Phasmophobia is a must for true horror game fans. Don't let the early access *frighten* you away. The dev team is *alarmingly* active in development and rolling out patches almost by the day. With some solid polishing of noticeable-but-not-game-breaking *creepy* bugs, this is easily horror GOTY.

I had high hopes for this game since the reviews were hyping it up and the 'About this game' sounded great. Without going into too much detail the game wasn't terrible but it isn't anything special and isn't worth the £11 retail price.

From the time playing I saw two ghosts. The first one was in the tutorial and it looked like a low-poly version of the Grim Reaper. The second one was upstairs in a 6 bedroom house, this ghost was a small demon child that looked like if the Demogorgon from Stranger Things had a disabled child with the boy off insidious. The ghosts were more funny than scary and actually probably took away from the scary experience as the suspense was better than the outcome.

I played this game using Keyboard and Mouse and didn't try it on VR, so I can't review the VR experience.

My initial reaction towards the game was negative due to the awkward hand positioning, no inverse kinematics, and phasing hands, however, DO NOT BE DECEIVED! Almost immediately after giving it a chance I realized the true potential of this game! The graphics are great, especially in VR, and the gameplay is immersive, innovative, and unique. The game has great replayability and never once was I getting bored. Overall, probably the best VR horror game out there that has co-op.

There are a few negatives, though, like my progress when playing with my friends did not save, you have floating hands that can phase through walls, and there are many bugs I've encountered, like getting stuck on stairs or getting stuck on the ramp off of your truck. The game doesn’t need full VR physics(as it does have realistic object interactions, it's just that your hands are floating and phase with no collisions), especially when that’s not the point of the game; however, it is 2020 and VR is blowing up at the moment. I just expected a little more; however, I do not know the size of the dev team nor do I know what they plan to do with the VR physics in the future. The game is fairly recent and bugs are to be expected, so that is excusable and as people have said, the devs are constantly working.

Overall, if you want a terrifyingly fun time with a couple of your friends, get this game.  I mean just look at the game ratings, 97% positive with 1.5 thousand reviews, AND its an early access...

Played both in normal and VR mode with friends and I can safely say this game is downright amazing!

You play cooperatively as a group of paranormal investigators to discover what kind of ghost you have on your hands. 
The tension builds slowly as you try to find small clues with your various gadgets and also try to determine which room the Ghost is actually in. 

The more time you take, the more dangerous it gets. Your sanity will decrease and the ghost will eventually try to hunt and kill you and your team. 
What was that noise upstairs? Who turned the lights off? Did something just move over there? Oh god my EMF reader is going crazy... **** RUN IT'S BEHIND YOU!    It's terrifying.

In VR the experience is enhanced tenfold although it was a little clunky at first. 
The tutorial is also a bit slow and confusing but through playing you can quickly learn what each item does.

Overall Phasmophobia is brilliant horror game. Grab a friend or two and jump in!
-The option of VR and non VR is great. 
-Not reliant on lots of jump scares but a steady progression of horror.
-The use of voice recognition throughout the game is something that I've not seen before and works wonderfully. 
-The devs seem to update the game constantly which gives me hope for more bug fixes and content. 
-Playing co-op with friends can give you so many funny moments.
-Great price for the content you get!

I'm super in love with this game right now. I'm a huge fan of horror and games that make me just super scared and don't rely on cheap jumpscares. As it stands at this stage of development. I'd say it's very solid and the dev is keeping everyone up to date and the dev even has a trello of what is coming, working on, to do and the like.

I would say it's worth the price, hell, I'd say it's worth 20 dollars as of right now, definitely 40 when there is more time put in and more places to hunt and more item and such. I digress though.

Pros in my opinion - 

No cheap jumpscares. The fear relies on the location you are at, 
the ambiance of your surroundings.

Lighting and shadows.

Co op doesn't take away from the fear which is rare.

Item diversity and their uses. 

Character models because some of the moments with their movements are hilarious.

I don't have many cons to the game. it's more personal gripes for me than overall gameplay.

You can only have 3 items at any given time, one in your hand, two on your belt in the desktop version. You lose EVERYTHING you brought when you die, even if you leave stuff on the truck. You do get like a 60% insurance though so it's nice. It's easy to miss little things if you rush around and in the heat of the moment when being scared and hunted, you miss a lot but again, it's a personal con, not an overall flaw to the game.

Anyway, I'm done ranting. This game is great, especially if you have a friend or two and want to really do something for a youtube video or a twitch stream. This is a yes for me.

Every mission goes like this:
-Check ghosts name and objective
-Grab things you need (usually just like a picture, an EMF reading, finger prints)
-Walk into one of three house/buildings
-Press V and say "John Jackson, show yourself."
-The ghost pops up after a bit, doesn't really do much
-Snap a picture
-Leave and repeat
Basically this is Pokemon Snap: Unity Assets Edition

I've never highly recommended a game but this game, i highly recommend. I haven't played this without VR but i'm sure its still just as fun. If you're a horror fanatic, or just looking for something you'll enjoy, this game is for you. Alot of the mechanics are spot on with only minor bugs that I've seen that the Dev's will most likely fix thanks to the community that tells them when bugs pop up. The Dev team seems to be very active.. To best describe this game you are a Paranormal investigation team that goes into places looking for enough evidence to then be able to send in a team of people to remove whatever is there. You get this evidence by setting up cameras, taking pictures of potential clues of paranormal activity, etc. Lights will flicker, cups and knives will randomly be thrown. It's accuracy to what people think when they think of the Paranormal, is very accurate. If you have friends IRL that can play this with you it"ll make it that much better. Some of the "Ghosts, or Demons" prefer only one person in the house when they are being contacted, so send in the person on the team that no one likes lol. They'll be in for a good time for sure. The tutorial is important so make sure you do it or you'll probably be lost. This game really brings a whole different level of fear into gameplay and submerges you into its world.. 9/10

these devs are definitely on some opp shit.

As of my last time playing (Sept. 25 at around 11pm) there are a few bugs that need to be fixed, such as randomly getting stuck on nothing. However, I saw a dev comment that this is being fixed already. Another major bug is the audio occlusion on voice chat. You may notice that your teammates voices get muffled even if they're standing 2 feet away. The reason for this (I assume) is that the game thinks you are two different 'areas', and applies occlusion to the voice chat to give the impression of you being in different rooms. If this can be fixed, it would be a great improvement. I'm not sure if this game uses Steam Audio, but I would recommend it if the devs can do so. 

Now for the positives:
This game is absolutely terrifying, I've legit never screamed during a horror game before this. Even with a friend I am still too scared to walk into the rooms that the ghosts occupy. The fact that the ghosts react to your voice as well is an amazing decision. Huge props to the devs for that inclusion.

Overall, this game has a very bright future. As long as the major bugs get fixed, this will definitely become a must-play for anyone looking for a proper horror game in VR.

-Better payment system. A higher base pay for completion of the job and the optional task should be just bonus cash.

-It would be amazing if we could be the evidence gathering crew and the removal crew. I want to fight these a-hole's. ( you could at first make the objectives be finding out what kind of ghost we are dealing with and then once that's completed the objective becomes cleansing the house.

I feel like you only really see them once they are trying to kill you, so it's hard to really look cause I'm running away in terror. Or hiding in the corner and dying. It would be so eerie if you are walking around checking stuff out and you just see them peeking around the corner and then they disappear. *shudder*

It's a great game to play with friends, has alot of spooks and chills on the first few hours. After some time the spook factor is gone, but it's replaced by the addicting gameplay loop and unlockables as you level up. If you have friends to play with, going into an asylum for the first time is a really overwhelming sensation after you get to unlock it. And ussually the most challenging part is finding where the ghost is on the building. This game has a bright future, and i would recomend buying it because it gave lots of fun hours with my friends. There are currently 5 maps in the game: three houses, one High school and one Asylum. And with 2 more maps in the making. The only complain i have are the character models, They are janky and weird, it's like your eyes are on their stomach. That is probably because this game was meant for VR, but i hope that for non-VR players they improbe on the animations.

PS: Even if the spook factor dims a little, It never completely vanishes. Being in a situation where you don't know what's gonna happen. Or even when you know the ghost is coming to kill you, and you can only run and hide from it to try not to die.

Though I don't have much time in the game at the time of writing, I highly recommend this game for anyone with or without VR. It is the perfect mix of "holy shit this is terrifying" and "I wanna play again". Even when you die there is a sense of being alone as your team can't hear you at all (from what I can tell). Just a hint, if you're the one opening doors, take the flashlight. You'll thank me later. ;)

This game is extremely fun to play. Luckily my friends and I were looking for a co-op horror game right at this time and I stumbled upon this game. None of us regret it one bit. It's very promising for an early access game.

Pros -
While the game still has jumpscares, it doesn't rely on them very much at all, and instead relies on the natural tension of large, dark areas and the natural activity (or lack thereof) of the ghost in order to build suspense. This means, for me at least, the feeling of dread doesn't end up wearing off and I can still feel genuine fear when going on a new mission, even if I've been there 20 times before, while also letting those jumpscares still be somewhat scary. A win/win in my book.

The voice recognition is something I wasn't sure would work out to be very enjoyable, but boy was I wrong. It creates a great experience, actively speaking to the entity, trying to provoke it to show you what it can do, risking your life for the mission, but it's gotta be done. It's thrilling and fills you with dread. Having the mission react to the things you say is extremely immersive, one of this games biggest strengths.

Immersion as I said, is huge in this game. I always feel like I could actually be in the level. Especially if you are playing in VR, it's hard to be ripped out of the experience, even if you're fucking around with friends, like I was. Being able to be the one in the truck tracking movement and and activity throughout the location is just as thrilling as wandering the house itself looking for activity. It's been hilarious and immersive the several times my friend got impatient waiting for clues and went into the house to insult the ghost only for it to immediately lock the door and begin hunting him. 10/10

Cons - I don't really feel that it's entirely fair to list these as cons, as the game basically JUST came out as I write this, and I have very little to complain about and feel very positively about this game and it's future, but these are things to keep in mind, and that they may and will likely change in the future.

When playing in VR, you can hold a video camera in your hand and carry it around, and others can have a clear view of what you're pointing it at as you move through the house. I would like to see this also become a feature for desktop play, while you still can equip the camera and view it, the angle is very low and bobs sporadically, making things hard to see. You can buy a headmounted camera that I assume fixes this. I am not a high enough level to buy one yet so I'm not sure.

VR players definitely have an advantage in many scenarios as you can turn on equipment such as the EMF reader and the spirit box, then but them on your belt to use them hands-free. I would like for at least the EMF reader to do something similar, instead of turning off when you put it away. It makes a noise when you get a reading, and I think that could stay, while requiring you to pull it out again to see exactly how strong the reading is, I feel that would be a good compromise.

As for VR QOL, my only 2 concerns right now are 1. placing cameras. Currently you grip them by the left or right side in a set direction, and it's only different for each hand it's held in. It can make it difficult to place a camera facing a set direction. I would like to be able to grip cameras from a front angle, as well as from the top, in order to make placing them much easier. And 2. switching hands, currently you have to drop an item manually and catch it if you're fast, or pick it up off the floor in order to switch hands if you don't have room in your belt. Many other games allow you to grab object out of your other hand and I feel it would be very helpful. 

Mission design - Again, keep in mind that I'm writing this in very early access, so I expect this to change at some point. Currently, the only missions are identification. Go in, find clues, deduce the ghost type, leave. I Don't have a problem with map design, but I would like to see other mission types, such as full on removal, as the game talks about you, the identification team, doing the research for a future removal team, missions like that would be great. Another is finding out how the person died and became a ghost, the journal mentions a few times about death and people becoming a ghost. Finding clues about the death of the ghost would be a very interesting mission design and I'd love to see it come to light.

Sanity is also something I expect to become something much more than it is currently as the game goes on. I feel that is obvious but I will give my 2 cents anyway for complete transparency. Right now, with my current understanding, it doesn't matter until you hit 50% at which point the ghost becomes more aggressive against you. This on it's own is interesting and can be useful for drawing the ghost out, but I would like to see more, such as hallucinations, both visual and auditory. There's not much more I can say on this, anything I could is just as obvious as that so I won't bother, and again, expect changes to this.

Lastly, when you die, you become a ghost and wander the map as an invisible entity. I think this has a lot planned for the future, but currently that's all there is to it. I think it would be extremely interesting if you could interact with the world in a similar way to the spirit your team is still hunting. Things like flicking the lights, writing short phrases on walls, or maybe being able to speak in a ghostly filter for just a couple seconds to give them a clue, would be very fun and make it so you're not just a passive and clueless observer if you are killed. If done in a way where it isn't always clear if the interaction is between the hostile spirit or your fallen friend, it would be possibly the most unique thing I've ever seen in a co-op horror game.

All in all, this game is a steal at it's current $15 price, and I got it on sale for less than $13! Even if you want to wait to play it when it's more developed, pick it up now! I have no issues recommending this to anyone, and I anticipate a very bright future in those dark corridors.

Happy Hunting

Phasmophobia, is a 4 Player Co-Op psychological thriller Horror game where you are a Ghost Hunter trying to determine what type of ghost is haunting the area. Maps include (from what I have played) a Small 1 Floor Home, a 2 story home, a High School. a Farmhouse and an Asylum (the Early access states there are 7 maps currently but so far I've only encountered 5). 

The maps are very well done (More maps are planned for the future) and every ghost hunt is different from the last. Just did the Farmhouse and your ghost was a super Aggressive Demon that killed everyone? Next time you could have the most talkative, friendly ghost you ever encountered.

Speaking of Ghosts, holy cow...Phasmophobia Has NAILED the Psychological and ambience part of this game. The whispering that can happen in your ear, the Gasping and moans...I won't tell you everything ;) but man this game knows how to scare your pants off. There are many types of ghost including Jinn, Demon, Wraith, Spirit and many many more (with way more ghosts planned for the future) and each ghost type will react to you in different ways and can change game to game (some are more talkative than others, some react more aggressively to certain actions/phrases).

There are many (I believe 22? currently with way more planned in the future) Ghost Hunting Equipment you can purchase and use to help you hunt and figure out the different ghosts roaming.

Regarding the Gameplay itself, It is very much doable Solo but the real fun comes with playing with a group and working together. As it stands, VR has an advantage over Non-VR users as VR is allowed to carry 4 items whereas non-VR can only carry 3. VR users also have an easier time lighting Smudge Sticks (Though Devs have stated they will make it easier for Non-VR users in a future Update). 

Regarding bugs and other issues, Honestly, I haven't encountered any MAJOR gamebreaking bugs that has hindered our progress entirely BUT I have encountered some mechanics not working as intended such as Cameras placed in the Haunted Room do not always pick up Ghost Orbs (especially when one of the Evidence is Ghost Orbs) and the Spirit Box not always picking up the Ghost Voice (Again, Especially when one of the Evidence is Spirit Box) but despite this, it is very much possible to still figure out the type of ghost.

Regarding the Scares, There are no REAL jump scares in this game besides stuff being thrown at you, lights flickering, and the occasional times where the Ghost shows you its true form and rushes at you before disappearing or you know....when you are the chosen victim for its HUNT....then all I can say is....RUN, HIDE & KEEP SILENT! This game is 100% open mic so even when you are talking, the game still hears you and so does the Ghost...so unless you want to have a meet & greet with Destiny, its best you stay quiet until it tires of you.

TLDR: I HIGHLY recommend this game for people that love Horror games and just getting that chill down your back. It is extremely fun, great game to play with friends and the experience is constantly changing (no Scenario is usually ever the same.) Being just an Early Access game, this game is already an incredible experience, has already had 4 updates within a week release (Devs are all over their Discord trying to improve their game as much as possible) and I have high hopes for its Full Release! 8/10!
Easily the best CO-OP horror game I've ever played. Super fucking scary. Preparing to get evidence and recognizing the types of ghosts is REALLY fun.

This game is definitely a new type of experience. I would highly recommend playing it at least for the new experience. But the game is really glitched. Some of the problems that you can expect from the game are the Spirit Box glitches to where it doesn't here you; items will disappear in the floor;  you can randomly get kicked from a game and then every 5 seconds you get respawned at the home screen with a welcome message; when someone dies, their items glitch and disappear into the floor. When you try to join a session, you usually get kicked because there is no way for people to invite their friends to a private session so they always have to do a public session. I wish there was a better way to have private sessions where you can invite your friends and also a session description so you can describe whether or not you want people with mics only, if it's a friends only game, if there's a level expectancy for the game, etc. Also I wish there was a wiki or something for this game because I barely know how to win and I can't find any research on it.

This game isn't Valve Index-ready yet. It requires you to modify the rotation of your hands in-game but then picking up items will give you a weird offset. There's no hand presence. Picking up and dropping items is toggleable between two options that are both very janky. Opening doors is the worst of all words - either doors should be animations or physics objects, but in this they're in a weird in-between. It looks like it does not render at the correct native resolution of the VR headset as well. There's also a very obvious bug with the UI on the main menu that belies that this is a Unity game that's using some common VR prefabs from the Asset Store - the same UI bugs that exist in VRChat exist in this game.

Overall if the devs need some ideas on how to fix things up, they should take a look at a map like The Devouring on VRChat, which is also in Unity and has had the VRC devs hack away at their controls for several years to the point where it's very polished, and the four devs who made the map have then used that platform for a co-op horror experience. ATM the experience in this game is tangibly worse than playing a VRChat map.

Amnesia? Outlast? Resident Evil? No game, that in my lifetime of epic gaming, has scared the absolute shit out of me as much as this game has. I don't normally have much any huge emotional reaction, especially with horror games as they've all since become the same thing. Linear, jumpscarey, predictable and mediocre.

The strongest part about this game and why it works so well is the total unpredictability and impossibility to control the situation. There's no force scripted events, there's no linearity, you just go in and try and find ghosts, and no matter how much pre-planning and discussion you have with your teammates to execute trying to find evidence, you'll never be able to know what will happen.

This game is a prime example of horror done absolutely right. The horror here is more tension and atmosphere based rather than jumpscares. Although they exist, because of the nature of simply what ghosts are, the horror here is the total feeling of unpredictability and the want to just leave the house and never return, but the need to overcome that and get more evidence.

tl;dr this is the only horror game. get it.

(also, i played regularly with a monitor. i cannot begin to imagine how much you'd piss yourself if you were playing in vr. only execute if you are a masochist.)

Absolutely Terrifying! The way the player interacts with the ghosts is so well done, the voice recognition and the "always listening" aspect make this all the more horrific.

I played for around three hours solo and was treated to some major fear sweats and heart pounding. This game is brutal.

I played with a friend thinking it would be easier and less scary...those thoughts were very wrong, now there were two grown men screaming and nearly crying.

The developers have either a history with paranormal investigation or have done some research on the subject, their gear selection is pretty accurate...aside from not needing a coin to keep the EMF detector on while not holding it...I'm hoping for more equipment to be added, such as laser grids to detect movement and DVRs for EVP work. I do wish there was more of an "investigation" aspect to it than just find room, get two or three clues and choose what spirit type it is, I'd just like a bit more depth to it. I would also like to have one or two more monitors in the trailer.

The locations are fantastic, lots of variety, the high school is the newest one I have unlocked and it is a place of nightmares... I would love to see more interactivity from the ghosts with the environments. Have the ghosts open cabinets, move items from room to room, change things and add to the fear and threat of each job.

There are a variety of different ghost types to contend with and they are described well, I would like to see more variety in terms of appearance for the ghosts. So far they seem to be either shadow people, character model copies, or full body apparitions, I'd like to have some translucent forms, as well as a fade in/fade out effect rather than them just appearing.

The sounds and ambiance are well done, very spooky. I feel like the game would benefit from more random sound effects or more so sound effects related to the individual ghosts for each job such as a ghost with a bat - have some knocking sounds of the wooden bat and such.

Each job has brief descriptions and they're fine for now, but I wish there was more variety and detail to them. How did the person die, giving clues to where the ghost might be and also tie into the look of the ghost itself. Or through investigation, have the players figure out the cause of death and such.

The graphics are fantastic, aside from the somewhat wonky player models (hopefully they'll get a bit better). At times there seems to be some visible seams in the buildings and environmental clipping. All in all really well done could be incredible with a bit of polish.

The controls are a bit weird to get used to on M&KB, but I assume that's due to the VR aspect? Hopefully they can be made better with more options for keybindings. Once you can get used to them, the controls are fine, but not great.

So far, I and my co-op investigator are having a terrifyingly good time with the game and we're very excited to see what is to come! 

Highly recommend so far!

After some hours of playing this game, I can finally review it. 

To start off, the devs has something special here, and I can safely say that it guarantees a lot of potential. I've been lurking in the discord for quite a bit and I can see that they genuinely do care about the game, as they've already pushed out an update and couple of hotfixes. They're very responsive towards bugs, and they do have a roadmap planned out in Trello (which also lists known bugs that'll be eventually fixed).

As for the game, it's decent when you're playing solo but the experience ramps up when you're playing with friends or with other people in the community. The game does a very good job on the horror/terror aspects, as the game isn't filled with cheap jumpscares. It's filled with ambience and nuances of sounds that's designed to bring true terror or dread for when you first enter the area. 

Focusing once more on the horror aspect, this game is moreso designed in a terror kind of way (which makes sense because you're a ghost investigator). There's a lot I'd like to list here, but I think it's a lot better to keep it as a surprise to get that kind of experience ingame. 

The only tip I have for new players is to definitely play the tutorial, and don't worry about going in alone because the ghost is always non-violent in the tutorial. 

Edit: I also forgot to include this in, but the map sizes for each area are insane. Some of the maps you'll have (when starting out) will most likely be streethouses and roadhouses. You'll be able to unlock bigger maps when you get enough xp to level up (you get experience from completing optional objectives and guessing what type of ghost you're dealing with correctly). 

TLDR: If you have a knack for spooky experiences, or you remember watching 'Ghost Adventures' as a kid, get this game. You won't regret it.

For as early as this game is out of release, I wasn't expecting a whole lot when I bought it.  However, this game is amazing!  The ambiance is perfect and the manifestations of the entities plays perfectly on the innate fears people have of the dark and unknown.  Perfect terror material.  Not horror, terror.  Horror is just flat out disturbing imagery and events (take Resident Evil for example).  Terror, on the other hand, leaves most of the development of fear and anxiety up to the mind of the individual (Subnautica, despite not being a horror game itself, does this excellently as well).  Phasmophobia does this astoundingly well, and I can't give the game enough praise for how well the developer has executed the premise!

One thing to consider before buying, though.  "Do I have a mic, and am I willing to use it to communicate with my teammates?"  If the answer is no, I would not recommend buying this, as teamwork and communication is a huge part of the immersion.  Unless the solo horror thing is your scene (in which case ignore this point).

Before I get into detail, let me just say that this game is AMAZING. 

Phasmophobia is one of the best horror games for VR I’ve ever played. Despite it still being an Early Access title the game is still packed with content. For $14 this game is a MUST have for any horror or VR enthusiast.

With the ghosts being random each time you start a level and so many other variables this game has the potential to be played over and over again for hours! Getting to hunt with your friends only enhances this experience as well. This game is the perfect combination of horror and strategy that allows you and your friends (or strangers) to work together to hunt down and identify ghosts. 

The game does have its quirks and glitches but the developers have been very invested in the community; listening to feedback, taking suggestions and working hard to fix bugs as soon as they appear which is something I greatly admire as this will allow the game to continue to grow. 

In conclusion I would HIGHLY recommend this game to ALL my friends. I can’t wait to see this game grow and to play it more in the future!!

Good. That's one less loose end.

(Foreword: I do not watch youtubers "lets plays" and certainly do not purchase games based on them. I am an unbiased source who feels a large disgust toward anyone who uses "content" as a word to describe sitting infront of a screen and saying random nonsense to an audience comprised mostly of children.)

With that out of the way; this is the most enjoyable co-op horror game you will ever play. Death is meaningful, you lose the expensive equipment you bring. So even after you get used to the atomosphere the tension of losing what you earned remains. This inturn makes whatever you are facing always something to be feared.

Teamwork is essential and you *will* need a mic. I usually avoid games like that but this one looked so good and it didn't disappoint. You need a guy in the van to monitor things and multiple people to set up equipment. However, to test certain things (spirit box for example) you need someone on their own. Thats extremely risky as the longer you are in the dark by yourself the more your sanity decreases which inturn opens you to lethal attacks.

The only real negative in terms of mechanics I would put to this game is that there are two movement speeds; super slow-mo or extremely casual walk (or "sprint" as the game calls it). Thats just too slow. Even if I know every hiding place I basically have to be right next to one during an attack to stand any chance of using it. I get why the devs want to limit speed but this causes frustration which inturn breaks immersion. A happy balance between pacing and speed needs to be found.

Overall this gets my recommendation with an obvious caveat; this needs work. If you want a fully polished product this is not there yet but it works fine and is alot of fun. Worth the price.

Back when Paranormal Activity was released, I saw it in cinema. I laughed, I couldn't take it seriously or understand why everyone was screaming and crying. 

As a kid my parents and I would watch ghost hunting shows, to which I got bored and knew it was all staged.

I'm not a believer in the paranormal and am pretty desensitised to most horror and games of that nature. 

This all being said, this game has brought out the ghost hunter in me that I never knew existed. 

I've never let out blood curdling screams in the same way that I have when some AI spirit locked me into a haunted barn.

I've played this game with grown ass men too afraid to enter a basement where the temperature was dropping. 

We've been chased down hallways by a blood thirsty oni which for some reason dwells in the chemistry lab of a western high school. 

The character animations are comparable to that of a deckchair folding in half but this only adds to the charm. 

As far as early access games go, this is a cut ahead of the rest and just a genuinely enjoyable game. Give it a shot.

The best and most memorable games I have played are those with emergent gameplay, and by that I mean gameplay which was not specifically programmed, but occurs because of the way the human player interacts with the game environment. And Phasmophobia has it in spades.

Definitely meant to be played in teams of 2 or more and best experienced in VR (although reportedly still great without VR). The core gameplay requires you to enter a haunted house, locate the room the ghost is haunting, then perform tests to gather three positives that allow you to identify the ghost. If you take too long or make the ghost angry, it will try to kill you, and you need to run and hide to survive.

The genius in this system is that to perform the tests, you have to do things which are psychologically repellent, such as locking yourself alone in the room with the ghost, turning off the lights and trying to provoke it. This leads to bravado followed by hilarious displays of cowardice from the teams of players, as people try to "out-brave" each other, then get the pants scared off of them by the ghosts. Half the time the player's own paranoia is the real cause of their fear, and every footstep or door slam from one of your teammates causes terror. But when the ghost wants to be scary it will leave you scrambling back to your mystery bus gibbering with your tail between your legs.

I'm really excited by the potential of this game, and it is already absolutely great fun, especially for the price. Every encounter I have had so far has been memorable and unique. If you don't have friends with the game it seems (My situation) it is easy enough to find a server or start your own and wait for someone to join you, and the community at the moment has a lot of great people who play in a cooperative spirit. Make sure you have a mic and speech recognition set up though - communication is half of what makes this game as great.

For an Early Access title, this game is quite fun, polished, and highly re-playable.  It really shines with friends in tow.  While there are bugs, and a few tweaks I'd love to personally see, this developer is totally on the right path forward.  I can't wait to see where this goes.

So far, really enjoying the game. I can understand how the evidence would get old after a little while; hopefully there's more types of evidence in future updates. 

My biggest "complaint" is that you don't keep special equipment like a thermometer, crucifix, etc., after a mission that it's used on. So, you have to constantly buy new ones and may miss out on some of the optional objectives/evidence if you don't have them. But, we could also just be bad at the game. Total possibly. 

All in all, who ya gunna call? NOT US. We cried and died so many times and had a blast doing it. Can't wait for more to come to this game!

This game is a CO-OP horror masterpiece that is rough on the edges.
I went into this game not expecting much because of the low price, I played with 4 other friends for 3 hours and am eager for next session.
This game really manages to capture a nail-biting atmosphere which can be hard in horror MP.

Pros:
Good ambience
Lots of gadgets
Good SFX
Great VOIP
Extremely Scary
Large Ghost variety, giving a lot of replayability
Great VR mode, outdoes normal kbm mode.

Cons:
Bad ghost animations
Not as much ghost to prop interaction as I would have wanted
Lack of jumpscares

My thoughts -
While this game manages to capture an incredibly scary ambience, it does not do well on jumpscares. My worst one to date was seeing a player teammate ghost copy that phased through me with a loud pitch. I was scared shitless.
I would love if there was more jumpscares scattered through ghost interaction. Another cool addition would be if ghosts would knock over more things such as vases, glasses, plates etc.
The animation when you get killed is super underwhelming and would love to see this get refined overtime.

The developer seems really active and has under my time of playing this game reworked voip sfx through radio and fixed multiple issues.
If this game keeps getting content and maintains this variety in gameplay, I will definately be putting this in my top horror game with friends list.

Immediately, the message I was given when walking into the house for the first time was, "I will not be able to explain what I have seen. You face it head on with all the equipment you need and all the health you need, and the threat of the ghost still remains. 

You can not run from the ghost either. Get in, identify it, get the fuck out. Your goal is leaving as soon as possible, as you have just 5 minutes to identify it before it gets angrier. You have to talk to it too, and it reponds! 

I am so impressed at this game, despite the muddy graphics. The sound design is damn near perfect. There's not a lot of music, especially on a case, and jumpscares are very limited. The game relies on chilling you to your core and I love it. Can't wait for more of this.

I was originally unsure if i was going to enjoy it as much as i did, but once i got into game and found a couple of good groups i suddenly found myself up into the very late hours of the night diving back in. Wanting one more Ghost hunt. I've obsessed with this game and have nonstop talking about how great it is. 

It touches that Paranormal horror, Jump scare, Goosebump rending chills each time i go for a round. There hasn't been a moment where I haven't felt "Safe" outside the 5 minute set up period. Calling out the ghost's name and talking in game is immensely immersive. Solving the Dark Unknown of what kind of ghost it is while also fearing for your life at any given moment is such a thrill. Theres so much potential in this game that I've dumped countless hours into this each session without feeling bored once. 

If you're looking to be a Ghost Hunter, Have a couple of friends that you want to share a terrifying but exciting time with where you will question whether it was a whisper in game, from your friends, or actually behind you. This is that game for you. Its terrifying with a full group, and its down right horrifying by yourself.

Here is my review of Phasmophobia
I have been playing this game for 10 hours straight and continue to play even more.
I love horror games and have played hundreds, most of them use cheap jump scares or for the story driven ones usually fall a bit flat or seriously lack replayability aside from games such as dead by daylight and perhaps Left for Dead 2 (if that even counts tbh)

Not this game, this game has a very promising future ahead of it and I guarantee it will blow up in popularity when the polish starts to rub on which the Developer has been actively working on improvements for the game and constantly fixing bugs, adding content, adding features (such as recently adding the ability to easily invite friends with private lobbies)

[h1] The gameplay [/h1]
You are a paranormal investigator who has been called out to the job you have selected to find out what type of ghost you are dealing with. You need to use your equipment to locate and find Evidence as well as the ghost itself when you have 3 pieces of evidence you can leave and hand over your findings to a Ghost Removal team that will take care of the threat.
You Cannot fight the ghost, you have tools to help you avoid it and find it but remember YOU ARE NOT WELCOMED HERE
There are currently 12 [u] DIFFERENT [/u] types of ghosts all with different combinations of evidences to confirm what type it is.
This means you will have a different experience 90% of the time with only a repeating offender occasionally, some ghosts are much more violent or less common to be in a mission such as the Demon or Wraith which is one of the most horrifying experiences you can get.

[h2] Game Mechanics [/h2]
This game has special mechanics that honestly arent really seen in other games for example
-Your microphone will be on while you play the game, meaning the ghost is ALWAYS listening to you, speak the ghosts name and it will be angered and annoyed and start doing things such as cutting the power, throwing objects around, flicker the lights, bang a door, moan, turn on a TV or radio, and so much more.
-Your Breath revealing the rooms Temp, its a very subtle but extremely useful mechanic. When you're outside you'll notice you can actually see your own breath due to the cold. However some ghosts when they enter a room will cause the freezing temperatures and showing your breath (This is a piece of evidence linking to what kind of ghost you're dealing with!)
- The Hunt, its a phase during the course of the game in which the ghost will start to flicker the lights rapidly, possibly shut the power off (depending on type of ghost), and [b] LOCK ALL EXIT DOORS [/b] you are trapped in the house with the ghost and it is looking to kill you, you have only one primary option and that is to HIDE. You have only 5 seconds to break the line of sight of the ghost or hide in a closet or locker (similar to outlast!) The hunt can last anywhere from a few seconds to a few minutes and the genuine confusion and mayhem is terrifying. 
There's more but for the sake of length we will stop there.

Overall this game is very promising and just needs more polish and this will become an amazing title that all the boys can play together. I highly recommend playing it, the Dev is constantly updating the game and so far is very promising!

8/10 needs more time!
PS: Level 3 you unlock Medium sized maps! have fun!

This game is terrifying for all the right reasons. The subtle noises, the creepy atmosphere, all the subtle things that the ghosts do to almost toy with you.

From everything to preparing in the truck to all the way in the hotrooms, you are always going to be unsettled. You know your are in for a good time when you are going to the mental asylum and hearing many voices, seeing many different figures, and not sure which one wants to kill you. 

Just some tips, keep your lights on. Keep your sanity high and your hopes higher. Dont be stupid. Think about what just happened to you, what they looked like, what they sounded like. Every detail may be helpful, but if you can see their face, if they do have one, good luck.

Phasmophobia is the best vr horror game out there! It is the most immersive game I have ever played! It is a beautiful game too. The main object of this game is to enter a house, find the ghost’s room, set up shop, get the hell out of there, gain some evidence, go back in, shit your pants, possibly get chased by a ghost, gain some more evidence, discuss what type of ghost it is, guess what type of ghost it is, and leave. There are objectives for each mission that change every time for you to gain money and experience. Some can’t be completed once you first get the game but hey, do what you can do. Each mission is randomly generated in a select house. This includes ghost type and objectives. When you first play, read the journal located on your right shoulder. Just read the whole thing. Once you understand the game, it’s still as scary but twice as fun. Also please do the training a couple of times to see evidence and learn some tricks. Playing with friends is the absolute best, my favorite part is finding a big piece of evidence and discussing what type of ghost it is. A lot of games at the start end in a guessing game but once you get it right, it is a great feeling. Overall, Phasmophobia is an amazing, immersive, and terrifying horror game that you should definitely pick up!

The dev is constantly updating and providing support to players in the Steam forums as well as the game's discord.

Phasmophobia is a horror survival mystery game, where up to four people can play ghost-hunters in a myriad houses around the US. The locations range in size and style. Whether it be a suburban house in a typical neighborhood, a farmhouse in the sticks, or one of the two larger locations, the High School or Asylum. You search for evidence around the premises (all interior spooks at the moment) ranging from moving objects and doors, to finger prints found with blacklight. Each house *cough* houses  one of a dozen different ghosts. Each one of these ghosts has their own unique spooks, and range in hostility. You and your team must gather clues before the ghost slowly picks you or your team off. If you mark down all three clues each mission requires, you can input your guess as to what breed of ghost you think it is, and head back to base and collect your pay, which relates to how you guessed, and the bonus side quests you achieved. You and your team can purchase a slew of unique gear with your savings, which can then be added to a community equipment locker, and taken on the job with you. Be careful not to get got though, because if you die, you lose the gear you brought in with you.

This game is scary, and the atmosphere and mechanics are really well implemented. Socially, each player set you are paired with will have their own style of playing. Like all rando pick-up games of this ilk, these play styles may or may not jive with your own. If you can find a team that share the same mentality, Phasmophobia can be extremely fun. If you find a teammate that doesn't care, yells in your ear, or can't count to ten...you may have a less than enjoyable experience. I prefer a gentle mix of RP, legit work, and balanced chatter. The ambiance is designed to lure you in subtly with creaks and faint whispers, or hit you with a slammed door and a heart throb. It's important to take in the milieu, and not constantly chat, especially about things not apparition related (my personal tastes).

I love what this dev team has done with the game. I highly advice you bury your ADD for a few minutes and play the tutorial--it will definitely be needed if you want to experience things how they are meant to be experienced. 

One really cool thing I love is how Phasmophobia has implemented voice recognition within the game. Talk to the ghost. Talk to the Ouija board. Ask it questions. Call out it's name and get it all riled up--just be ready to either run for the door, hide in a nearby closet, or freeze like a deer and pray the Demon, Wraith or one of the other malicious specters doesn't rip your head off. 

There is also a VR mode, although I have not tried it, it seems to be 10X scarier and slightly more cumbersome than playing with M&K. Although there are a few unique perks to VR. Like the ability to slowly place items in more advantageous positions, or carry two cameras on tripod at the same time. If the devs (or VR company) would kindly send me a VR unit (Index please) I'll gladly write another review. ;)

There are a few assets and production bits that can and probably will be improved. The character models and animations need a lot of work, and a few of the mechanics can get buggy. I would also like to see even more voice recognition implemented--it's a lot of fun, and can really encourage some fun RP and immersion. 

Phasmophobia is in early access, and after putting 10 hours in, I can confidently say that if you find a good team, you will have an absolute blast playing this game. And it's only $13! More than worth it. If you ever wanted to be a Ghostbuster, or a Ghost Hunter...you'll love this title.

Early Access Score: 7 of 10

This is one of the scariest and funnest co-op games I've ever played in VR. Most small studio games are absolute shit, but this game really crushes it and it deserves the accolades it receives. Hunting ghosts with friends and strangers is awesome.

How are more people not talking about / playing this game? I was pleasantly surprised to have stumbled across this gem while looking for games similar to my library consisting of multiplayer horror genre games, ie: Dead By Daylight, Deceit, etc.

This game is fantastic even in it's early state and definitely worth the price (12.59 or 13.99 when not at 10% off)

Pros:

While the game doesn't give you a super detailed tutorial, I feel that makes the game that much more enjoyable as you are struggling to figure out what haunts these locations. I haven't encountered any game breaking bugs in my 7 hours on record.

This game is a lot of fun while playing with friends or even randoms you may encounter while matchmaking. You can explore these locations by yourself but I have yet to do so.

Cons: 

I will tell you that the amateur missions seem to be harder than other difficulties due to fact that the ghosts seem too shy come out right away due to the missions being intended for smaller party sizes. This causes long games of trying to figure out where the ghost may be located as some of the ghosts only react when players are alone. This becomes an issue when your party size is larger than 2 on early missions.

The high school map is labeled medium however with the movement speed it feels way larger than it actually is. This wouldn't be an issue if character movement was enhanced past a slow crawling speed.

MOVEMENT SPEED. The "Run" in this game is more of a brisk walk, I would like for them to implement a faster "Shift" speed. Smaller maps seem fine with the option provided, however like stated with school map, it tends to cause issues. Forget going back to the truck after you're on the second floor. 

All in all this game has great potential. It has VR support and is fun in groups of friends and strangers.

This game in early access is the story of four goofy pals with incredibly flexible bodies signing up to do a potentially dangerous job for no real money at all. The actual lore is something about amateur ghost hunters trying to see what they can see or something, I haven't paid much attention to that because we're all too busy in the lobby laughing at each other hiding in cabinets and poorly throwing a basketball.

The actual game itself is a nightmare in the best of ways; you and your friends (or some people playing publicly) grab your spook hunting gear and go trouncing into various haunted locations to try and gather evidence on what type of ghost is haunting the place and then get out. Typically the match is everyone grabbing a thing and then trying to slowly creep through the house because everyone is a coward (especially me) and when we don't find any major evidence or see anything too crazy we assume the house isn't haunted. Then the lights turn out. Then we see shadows. Then all hell breaks loose as we spent seven minutes laughing and having fun and now the ghost is annoyed that we still exist. Oops, they killed Dave, welp sucks to be Dave we're outta there!

The game is honestly amazing so far and my friends and I have had a blast. There is plenty that needs tweaking, changing, expanding on, etc but the game is Early Access and I have more than enough faith in the dev team to keep the ball rolling. This game has been worked on for quite a while and is gaining popularity somewhat quick! Go into the Community Hub and look at the screenshots, they are hilarious as can be but know that wrapped up in all the laughter and joy this game brings there is a whole mess of scary craziness waiting to happen.

Spooktober is around the corner folks, if this is your kind of game I'd highly recommend picking it up while its still on sale, or pay the extra dollar or two when its not on sale.

This game is not your typical co-op horror game. It masterfully builds tension with great ambient noise and sound design.
You survive a haunted house with 4 friends or you can brave the ghosts by yourself, but personally with my at the time of writing this review 4 hours in the game recommend playing with friends. It keeps the tension up as you explore the dark rooms of these haunted structures knowing that anytime you can be picked off one by one these ghosts at anytime.

The one thing i absolutely adore is the lack of jump scares, i find jump scares cheap and not very exilerating and get boring extremely fast as they become almost too predictable. But having the ghost as an AI allows for always new experiences to keep the player base active and always asking for more. As one of the most terrifying moments for me in this game is where i was hiding in a closet asking the ghost where it was. It then said what i beleive is "here" as the closet door ripped open. Not many times in a game have i expereinced true horror on the scale like that. Phasmophobia is atmospheric horror and it does it very well. not allowing gamers to increase the brightness in game so they can see better in these unseen horors is great and id keep it that way. Though the flashlights should have increased radius are better lighting effect because even the strong flashlight seems only mildly better over the base one. 

The use of the mic in game to contact your demons, spirits and ghouls feels fresh and unique, and to see it in a unity build is almost jarring. The mic in game seems to work well, but i have experienced bugs in where you cant hear other players but they can hear you. So some work is needed to be done to flesh out the voice chat. Overall the mic in game is servicable.

Servers are a bit of an issue, during my short time with the game the U.S servers seem to be completely down, as they don't show up for me at all, so at the moment im currently stuck playing in EU servers. Not a big deal as it seems to have just fine connection and little lattency, but for other players this could be a major issue. 

Graphics are your typical unity projects, not the best looking games but its not going to overload your pc like crysis or modern AAA titles. Though where it truly shows that its unity is in the models and animations. Animations are ROUGH, even watching people that are playing in VR its very jerky and un natural. The models are stiffer than a bundle of 2x4s and the models you do see are ugly. id say a big improvement needs to be updated quite heavily on all the models and animations. 

By no means is this game bad, i recommend it. Its 15 dollars CDN at the time of writing this but i do think for the way the game is now the price should be lowered a little bit. Its not quite what id call a 15 dollar game, more like a 10 dollar game. But with updates to the main major issues in this game, adding more maps and ghosts. I can see this game taking off, and being put on many peoples wish lists. I would even say after some updates i would pay more for the game. But at this time and in the games state a 10 dollar game is the best i see it. 

Im looking forward to see where this game goes in the future and i hope the devs continue to update this game for the community.

Even as someone who usually avoids VR horror games, Phasmophobia is quickly becoming one of my favorite VR games. Unlike many other horror games, it is not built around escaping, hiding from, or defeating some spooky monster. Phasmophobia's gameplay centers around investigation and information gathering instead. You can leave whenever, but the more you stay in the location and learn about the ghost, the better your payout will be. For me at least, this has been far more interesting than a lot of other horror games and also more replayable.
The VR implementation is a bit janky in places, doors in particular come to mind as frustrating, but the oddities are far outweighed by how fun it is to play. It even manages to stay suspenseful and scary while playing with friends, something a lot of other multiplayer horror games don't succeed at.
Especially for an early access title, Phasmophobia is rich with content and I see myself playing for many more hours. The dev seems to be very active with updates and I am excited to see where the game goes with more content.

It is a breath of (cold, terrifying) fresh air to see a horror game that breaks some molds and offers some unique experiences.  If you are familiar or a fan of the various paranormal investigative reality shows of present or past (Paranormal Lockdown, Ghost Hunters, etc.), the gameplay will be instantly familiar to you.  To those that aren't, the game gives an interesting look into the field of paranormal investigation with the scary twist of fictional psychological horror.

While still an alpha and in early access, Phasmophobia offers an interesting take on asymmetrical horror.  Either alone or in a group of up to 4 hunters, you are offered jobs in locations of various types and sizes.  From simple street houses, farm cabins and even an abandoned school and asylum, you are tasked with entering the location, finding the ghostly entity, and collecting enough evidence to successfully identify it.  As of this writing, there are currently 10 ghosts and about 6 unique locations (with more on the way).  Each ghost has different behaviors and detection requirements, and can originate in any of the locations rooms at random.  Numerous events can occur that help finding the ghost and ratcheting up the tension.  Normal jobs give you five minutes to get in and locate the entity.  When the time is up, players sanity will begin to rapidly drop while inside and the ghost will become more active and aggressive.  Unlike the reality TV counterparts, the ghosts in Phasmophobia are as capable of killing you as they are scaring you.

Whether solo or with randoms or friends, the fear factor remains high with creepy atmosphere, sounds and creeping dread.  Phasmophobia never relies on jumpscares to invoke terror and, in fact, has virtually none throughout the game.  There are plenty of tools at your disposal to help you as well as ones you can purchase with money you earn from completing jobs, daily tasks and optional objectives.  Gear includes many staples of paranormal investigation ranging from standard flashlights, UV lights, EMF detectors, still cameras and video cameras that can pipe a real-time stream of footage to your van/command center, and the like.  Many of the tools are grounded in real life and utilized by actual paranormal hunting teams, though a bit of fictional flair is added for the sake of the game and both enhancing their usefulness and enhancing the tension.

As said before, as of this writing, the game is still an alpha and in early access.  There are places where it's rough around the edges and some bugs do exist, but rarely do they prove detrimental to the available gameplay or lessen the experience.  In my personal opinion, the jankiness of the character models and animations (especially in VR) is actually kind of endearing, though I suspect much of it will be smoothed out over time.  More ghosts and locations, updated and added game modes and more are in the works and on their way from what is proving to be a very proactive developer.  The community is rapidly growing and the potential of this game is beyond impressive.  So if you are looking for some terrifying gameplay that doesn't rely on cheap scares that you can play with friends and laugh together about possibly requiring a change of underpants following an investigation, then this is the game for you.

I and many others are eager to see this game grow and improve, and hats off to the developer and everyone on his team for this budding experience.

This game is incredible. Regularly on PC, its terrifying. In VR, its horrific. You'll be playing with friends, walking into the room where your EMF reader spiked. The lights turn off and you hear a hiss in your ear, on the back of your neck. The spine chill from that experience - the pure terror is unmatched. This game is actually incredible. The ghosts function very well. They will stalk you, try to split your group apart, and do everything they can to absolutely scare the actual crap out of you. I have never heard me or my friends be sent into such states of pure panic and fear. You would think that the fear factor in a game like this would run dry rather quickly, but it doesn't. I think it's partially because you never know what you're up against, and trying to figure it out can lead to some scary crap. This game's replayability is astounding. It seriously doesn't get old. and if you ever think it does, I dare you to try playing alone. Bonus point for alone in VR (there's no way that I wouldn't have a heart attack lmao).

By the way, when you're in a house, and ALL the lights start flickering, INCLUDING your flashlight, run. Run and hide. The front door will be locked, and it is on the hunt.

This game is a freaking masterpiece and I am so excited to see where things go.

I am in LOVE with this game. Spooky with jump scares even hours after playing you sometimes just don't expect things. So I'm horrible with horror games... So naturally like the idiot I am I got Phasmophobia and unsurprisingly nearly cry every game. I didn't think it'd be as terrifying as this game tends to get. The ghost is always unpredictable and random. Your ghost can be chill and it can be an easy get in and get out in ten minutes. Or it can be the most terrifying half hour or more of your life as your ghost gets pissed off and hunts at level 10 until every member of your team is dead. They also tend to throw stuff around, make random noises, walk towards you from the darkness, hum near you. Hell, I had a moment where I was being watched on a camera in the basement and only the camera could see the ghost approaching me, leading to me frantically waving my flashlight around like an idiot to fend it off. 

This is an incredibly immersive and impressive game, and I hope to see more continuous updates to it in the future as time progresses. It a terrifying experience that I'd 100% recommend you to play with some friends.

I'm going to just make a short review because I need to say it. 

This game is [b]FUN.[/b] It has an insane amount of potential. I'm a big fan of Ghost Adventures, and ghost hunting in general and I love getting the chance to role-play as Zak Bagans and making the easily scared people of my group go do isolation. I do hope that the devs add in more areas, or give a community workshop with people making their own maps to explore and hunt on, but I cannot express properly how much fun I've had with this in the short time I've played it. It's been a very fun, and startling, experience.

This is like the type of horror that genuinely terrifies you and doesn't rely on schticks and gimmicks to do so.

- Minimal jumpscares, and even then the jumpscares are used sparingly and are integrated amazingly into the gameplay.
- There is depth of play. Easy enough to understand the mechanics and gameplay but there is a steep learning curve.
- The ambiance, the maps, and the visuals all work into making your brain go wild. What I really appreciated about the game is that there are little to no outright "scary" imagery. It only uses small things to make you break into cold sweat such as the creaking on the floor, doors being slightly open, the lights flickering occasionally.
- Even if you play it over and over again, the fear factor never disappears. We've gotten to the point where we think we're already desensitized, but the game still manages to drop my sanity (heh) whenever the EMF reader goes off (even if it's exactly what we wanted to happen). 

All in all, this game is a terrifyingly good experience.

This is without a doubt one of the few horror games that I truly love.
It's a co-op ghost hunting game where you use different gadgets to identify and deter the ghost.
There's many ghost types and each have their own "personality" like they only do paranormal stuff when someone is alone or the person is in complete darkness for example.
You can play this without Vr, but Vr provides absolute terror.

I got into a group of randoms and we literally spent 20 minutes setting up cameras and salt "traps" and discussing what kind of ghost we're up against. It's not only the scares it's the immersion that goes in so well.
Barely any jumpscares, the true fear is being in the area knowing the ghost could be stalking you in the room itself.

Oh did I mention it has voice recognition? The ghost reacts to questions and it also can get annoyed when you repeat their name multiple times.

Rating: 9/10

A streamer introduced me to this game on his stream and it looked really fun, so I decided to buy it and give it a shot!

The game is very fun and creepy overall, especially if you're by yourself, but the real fun of this game is playing with random players. You never know who you'll get, which gives excitement to the game. While the game play itself gets repetitive (I actually found myself bored playing single player after hours of multiplayer), playing online was always a blast no matter what.

The groups I ran into could be very serious, super casual, hilarious, or even extremely scared. I remember a group of people where our tactic was to insult the ghost to get it to react and she got mad and attacked a guy and we just hear him screaming upstairs and die. There was a kid on cameras who was too scared to be in the house and we could hear him yelling from the van, "I saw it! I saw it! It killed him!"

We tried to get more clues only for a short time after because we didn't want to make the other guy wait too long while dead; the one disappointing thing about this game.

While the game is fun while you're alive, it really sucks when you die. You can't do ANYTHING but walk around, listening to repetitive ghost music that starts getting really annoying. You can't even hear what your teammates are saying. My one recommendation for this game is they really need to revamp the ghost aspect. Maybe allow you to hear your team, write a message on the mirror, maybe even flicker a light or two to mess with your teammates. Anything, honestly. Being dead just makes you want to leave the game instead of wait it out for your team.

To summarize, this is a very fun and interactive game with a detective vibe due to figuring out what you're against, has a creepy atmosphere that can make you uncomfortable and on edge (which a horror game should do), and a lot of fun things you can do, especially online. The one drawback to this game is when you die, its extremely boring waiting for your team to finish the investigation. Because of this, I will investigate for only a couple more minutes (usually less than 5 minutes) I always ask my teams if we want to wrap up the investigation early, so that way the dead teammate doesn't have to be extremely bored and listen to annoying wispy music.

I 100% recommend this game because there is only ONE drawback to an overall extremely fun game! Can't wait to see how many more interaction they make with the spirit box, more maps, more items, more ghost types, and more words and statements the ghost can understand to anger it. You should give it a try, especially with it only being less than $13 USD.

This game is great, one of the best horror games on the market.

Imagine the ghost hunter shows you watched as a kid, but everything is actually real. You might have to go in a room with a "spirit box" which is one of those radios you talk to ghosts and actually use your microphone to talk to them. Next thing you know EMF levels go to ten, you hear a noise, you turn around and see a fucking ghost bro!!

This game is fun solo but even better with friends just to see everyone's reactions because when you first start this game everything is very unpredictable. This game does not use brute force jump scares to scare you, it uses tension and suspense created by discovering what ghost you are dealing with. Hopefully by the time you gather enough evidence to figure out what type of ghost it is you are not already dead.

Horror fans this should be an instant buy!

This game is in early access at the moment of writing this review, but this has by far been one of the most interactive games I've played for VR in quite some time. It has a lot of scenarios that make every ghost unique. Oh yeah every ghost is unique by the way. There are 10 different types of ghost you have to identify and even with almost 5 hours in the game I have many I haven't encountered yet. I see a lot of potential for this game taking a simple concept of ghost hunting and making it a real nightmare to come true. 

Things to keep in mind about this game
-Solo is fun for being scared but it extremely difficult to accomplish many things because this game is focused on teamwork
-Leveling up in this game is really hard, so getting new gadgets for you and your team will take a lot of time (5 hours into the game and I just got level 2) its quite a grind but a fun one.
-A fantastic game for friends who own VR

Other than that there are some rough things around the edge like item interaction sometimes is whack and you have to drop items to swap them into another hand and can be hard to navigate when dealing with an encounter. Some bugs with audio but mostly minor things and nothing game breaking, it is mostly stuff that will improve over time in development I'm sure.

9/10 experience and would highly recommend as a must have to VR users with VR user friends.
